Bottle. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Small lacing. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Taste very rich with chocolate and malts and mild coffee finish. Very good. 

----Hophaze out

Pours very dark with huge brown head that fades to a thin layer and moderate lacing.  Aroma is roasted coffee and a little chocolate.  Taste is sweet roasted malts, cocoa, and coffee underneath.  Palate is smooth and creamy.  I¬ím not clamoring for more, but this was a pleasant experience overall.

Pours a nice dark brown black color with a rich creamy head, smells of roasted coffee chocolate and a hint out carmel, taste is amazing very pleasing on the palate you get that roasted malt, carmel chocolate flavor everytime, but every time you take a drink it seems you taste one over the other then the next its something else.....Love this beer very good stout...

Pours a wonderful black with a thick tan pillowy head. Smells of roasted coffee bean and dark chocolate escape from the cloudy head. Taste is of strong malts and cocoa with nice coffee undertones. A small taste of alcohol is also there. Nice lacing sticks to the side of the glass as the lingering head follows the beer down. Overall this is an awesome beer. Very smooth and creamy. A must try.
Best stout I¬íve had so far. Pours black with a really thin light brown head. Smells mostly of chocolate, tastes like it with some coffee. Great beer.
Pours black with brownish foam, light roasted smell.  Awesome creamy roasted taste.  Great finish, one of my favorites.
Pours dark black with a tanned head. Nice smooth aroma of coffee and chocolate. Pleasant mouthfeel, and somewhat bland finish. Decent brew, but Kids! Intoxication inhibits your ability to rate beer!

This beer pours a nice dark color with a dark khaki almost brown head. Coffees, bitter chocolate, roasted malts, maybe some dark fruit on the nose.  Taste is very similar. A bit more milk chocolate on the taste. Finishes with a sweet bitterness... bitter chocolate. Mouth feel is incredible.  So creamy....insanely impressive considering this beer is NOT brewed with lactose. Great beer and 6.1%abv to boot!
Black pour with a frothy, tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, tar, 75% chocolate, and weak coffee. Taste is bitter and has a milky touch. Medium, silky palate.
More roasty than I remembered, dry with a clean hoppy finish. I enjoyed this more than most cream stouts.

12 oz. bottle. It pours dark brown with a fine tan head. The aroma is a little on the weak side with light notes of roasted coffee, raisins, anise and a hint of toffee sweetness. The flavor is sweet with mild notes of soda pop, but cut nicely with some dense roasted malt, toffee, and only light notes of fig and dates. The mouthfeel is soft and pretty thick. Nice beer.

missing an aroma for a double creme.. the head is a gorgeous off white.  taste is smooth and creamy.  Really well balanced, has the bitterness but is nicely balanced with sweetness.  not their best beer by any means but still better than most
On tap at 1839 Taphouse in Columbia. Pours a black color with tan head. Roasted, coffee, oatmeal, milky aromas and flavors. Pretty fucking good.
chocolate stout with a dark pour and little head with little lacing.  Good overall smooth feel and good finish.  Good stout.

Black brown opaque body with off white cap of foam. Nose smoke, dark chocolate, coffee. Taste same notes with sweet coffee slight roasted finish. Mouthfeel milky with medium carbonation. Over hyped imo. Grows on you after warms up. Sweetness more noticeable mouthfeel creamier.
Thick creamy body, slight coffee smell.  Tastes like a good milk stout, with a nice coffee finish.  Doesn¬ít knock me over, but a decent brew.
Very pleasant smell. Smells almost creamy. Not bitter. Very heavy bodied beer with almost no head. Thick tasting as well. Truly creamy to taste. A+++++

Bottle, dark brown color.  Aroma of vanilla, roasted malt, lactose, nuts.  Medium light sweetness.  Medium body.  Average to below average carbonation.  Smooth drinking, starts off sweet and ends with just a bit of bitter and dry finish.  Cocoa in taste.  Nice mouthfeel, good throughout.  Enjoyed this one.
Sweet coffee and chocolate taste but in no way cloying, enjoyed this one in a way comparable to Founder¬ís Breakfast Stout.
Excellent beer.  It is very malty and creamy, but not quite as heavy as a Guinness.  There is no roasted bitterness, yet it is still malty.
Black pour with very little tan head. Roasty creaminess on the nose, some nice chocolate. Nice creamy mouthfeel and taste, vanilla/chocolate deliciousness.

Pours a near black color with a small beige head that quickly fades.  Aroma is cream, roasted malt, and chocolate.  Taste is slightly sweet, lots of cream, some roasted malt and some chocolate.  Smooth creamy finish with a little chocolate.  A really good cream stout.

Nice thick head on the pour.  No much of a nose but all I smell is grease in this bar but noticeably sweet.  Nice creamy taste with sweetness and a touch bitter on the palate. A nice stout but still prefer left hand milk.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours almost black with a nice reddish brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Not too complicated.  Rich and cream.  Very nice!

Bell¬ís has done it again with yet another masterful craft brew.  For stout lovers, you can¬ít go wrong.  And, a nice stout for those not into stouts.  A sweet tasting stout with a chocolate malt aroma.  Pours a deep, rich black color with little head.  A silky, creamy texture with little carbonation that is long on the finish.  Best sipped and savored, not chugged!
One dimensional - coffee and some chocolate. Feels thin and over carbonated. Not very good, least favorite bells stout ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2012 Not one of my favorite stouts... This starts straight roasted malt for me not much else. Pours deep brown with light lacing and heavy carbonation (less CO2 and I would like it a lot more). Palate is medium to heavy. Overall, not gunna buy it again.

Pours black with brownish foam. Smells roasted beef/worcestershire sauce and coffe notes.
Mouth is a bit acid, dry, bitter, foamy with a nice ink and cocoa flavour with a nice medium bitterness.
Great.

Bottle at Kasey¬ís Tavern, Chicago - 03/11/12.
Black with a thin tan head that soon clears to the edge of the glass.
Nose of roast malts, creamy milk chocolate, dark toffee.
Tastes of chocolate, roast malt, molasses, all round creamy feel.
Medium bodied, rich with soft carbonation leadinf to a dryish finish.
Another good stout from Bells!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: UPDATED: NOV 24, 2016 Aroma is sweet, some chocolate, lots of roasted malt, coffee.. Appearance is dark brown with a light tan head, poured thick. Taste is very malty and creamy, some chocolate but more coffee bitterness. The mouthfeel is perfect. Velvety, creamy, wonderful. Overall, this is one of the go-to stouts of the season.

black color, tan head, aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, pine, flavors of dark chocolate, bitter coffee, rich roasted malt, smoke, vanilla, pine, dry finish, pretty bitter, very creamy texture, good brew with a high drinkability

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2013 Black with a tan colored head about 1 1/2 fingers worth.  Aroma was mostly cocoa chocolate with some roasted malts.  Flavor was sweet with milk chocolate up front  with coffee following And some burnt malt on the finish. Had a thin almost water mouthfeel.  Overall an ok nothing special stout.
Shared from a 12 oz bottle. Pours black with a tan head.  Coffee and chocolate in the nose.  Rich malty flavor.
Aroma is a bit muted, appearance deep and rich but not grimy, taste is complex with malts and other deep flavors, yet, not robust.
Nearly a year old bottle. Deep dark brown, tan head. Nose is coffee and rich malts. Taste is rich malts, vanilla, and fresh coffee. Medium mouthfeel, incredibly smooth. A really easy drinking stout.
12 oz bottle. Huele a chocolate y un poco de cafe. Sabe igual, con demasiado cafe pa¬í mi. De todas formas sabe riquisima y es tan suave como indica su nombre.

Bottle (12 oz). From a trade, thanks dresden! Black with a small beige head very little lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and hints of dark chocolate. Taste is about the same with a dark chocolate chocolate finish. Interesting creamy mouthfeel with a dry finish. Good Sweet Stout!

Bottle->tulip.  Cola pour.  Aroma is more complex than the standard coffee and chocolate stout nose.  Malty with some fruit.  Tastes like a Diet Java Stout, but not unpleasantly so.  A nice alternative stout to the strong chocolate route, but nothing special.
Pours a dark brown almost black with a mild foam head. Taste a little liquorice, cereal, coffee and chocolate.

12oz pour into glass: I actually like this stout because it has many features which are exactly opposite of what is described on the label.  There is nothing "creamy" and "smooth" about it.  This thing is burnt roast and coffee, pretty much in your face with no apologies.  I happen to like that.  I would never call this a cream stout, yet, this is what I was looking for.

Pours fark black with tiny head. Aroma is very roasty with vanilla and chocolate. Taste is a nice balance of roasted coffee, toffee and chocolate. Full bodied but not syrupy. Good carbonation to keep the sweetness in check. This one is good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours deep dark brown and turns black as it pools in the glass with almost no head. Nose is roasted coffee, vanilla and almond extract, light molasses and hay. Taste is sweet but has a good
Bitter balance.  Mouthfeel is light bodied, crisp, clean with a long finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from 12 oz. bottle into my Founders Brewing snifter

A: Pours dark brown, almost black. Light cannot pass through. Nice one finger tan head that stays throughout the beer. Beautiful lacing as the head dissipates.

S: Big roasted malts with a slight bitter hop undertone. Dried coffee beans come through as well. 

T: Bitter dark chocolate up front with a vanilla coffee through the middle that ends in a creamy sweetness.

M: Coats the pallet with a smooth, sweet, almost chewy liquid gold. Can almost feel the beer linger on your teeth. Perfectly balanced carbonation.

O: A much roastier, sweeter stout than usual but still excellent. Easy to drink due to smoothness.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-03-2011 02:27:30

Bottle pours an opaque black with a small tan head. The aroma is complex. Chocolate hit me first, then coffee, then a bit of dark fruit, then roasted/smoky malts. Full body with just enough carbonation. Finish is long and full of roasted malts.

17/IX/2012 12Fl. Oz. bottle  @ home - BB: XI/7/14 (2012-1053) Thanks to Jeremy for the bottle!Clear dark brown beer, big irregular aery beige head, unstable, bit adhesive. Aroma: chocolate, and lots of it, also chocolate milk, mocha, dark caramel, fudge. MF: lively carbon, medium to full body. Taste: bit carbon sour first, cocoa powder, chocolate milk, mocha, little bitter, dark chocolate, forest fruits. Aftertaste: mocha, dry hops, bit dusty, cocoa powder, bit earthy.
Bottle.  Dark black pour.  Nice flavor and aroma of quality dark roasted coffee.
Pours jet black.  Smells a bit sweet and roasty, but not over powering on either.  Taste is slightly sweet that is amazingly balanced with the roast.  Feel is super smooth.  Amazing beer.

Pours a dark brown/black with a generous tan head. Notes of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate on the nose. Very robust flavor with coffee and almost a dried fruit quality to it as it starts to warm a little.Solid cream stout.
Small head, slightly sweet aroma, pleasent mouthfeel- slighltly biting from carbonation, smokey aftertaste

12 ounce bottle. Stouts, especially dark and rich ones like this, have the cards stacked in their favor.  They have more facets to watch for and enjoy, and they¬íre usually all smooth about it too.  Bell¬ís Special Double is highly drinkable and sits right between good and excellent without selling out to the imperial extremist crowd.  It¬ís a delicious chocolate beverage that¬ís a dessert in and of itself.  Cherry and malt aroma, black appearance with a thick layer of brown foam, and a heavy amount of carbonation.
Really nice. I had heard good things about this brew, and have been wanting to try it for awhile. It does not disappoint. Glad I picked this up.

This one has been in my fridge for a while, and may not have been at its peak (bottled 1/2012).  However, I found nothing wrong.  It poured dark brown, almost black.  Just lacing for the head.  It had the aroma of brown sugar, chocolate, and a slight hint of worchestershire sauce/soy.  The taste was full, with dark chocolate, a slight  taste of molasses and cinnamon, and a smooth finish.  It goes down well and easy.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: 12 ounce bottle.  Pours dark brown with small brown head.  Aroma is malt, molasses and chocolate.  Mouthful is a bit better/creamier/fuller than Expedition Stout.  Flavor is malt, chocolate, coffee.  Very good.

Poured from a bottle dted 1/25/12 into a pint glass. Pours a very dark brown but not exactly black. Brownish two inches of head and moderate lacing. Smell of coffee and cola. Mouthfeel is thick and decadent but not overly oily or rich. This certainly isn't an imperial stout. Taste is sweet with hints of coffee and sugar. Similar to Kalamazoo but not as bitter ie sweeter and less coffee and no licorice, yay!  Very solid stout but too sweet for me. I like mine a little dryer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours deep brown to black opaque with a medium creamy brown head and nice lacing. Aroma is strong roasted malt, molasses and chocolate. Flavor is rich deep roasted malt, chocolate, raisins, coffee. Finishes sweet and smooth.
Bottle to oversized snifter (from notes).  Looks good; pitch black with beige head.  Smells SWEET.  Tastes sweet and creamy with a good mouthfeel.  Good stuff, but definitely not a session beer.

Bottle picked up in Charlottesville, VA. Pours dark black with a nice big beige head. super creamy, but super flavorful too, especially as it warms. Great combination of complexity and quaffability.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. A big sweet chocolate stout. Nice and easy drinking. Bells does it again, terrific stout.

A: Jet black with a humongous beige head. Great retention and generous lacing.

S: Roasted malt, milk, cream

T: Very creamy and rich with a very noticeable lactose flavor. The milk aspect is present throughout the taste, with mild sourness. A tasty beer, though perhaps the lactic aspect is a bit overdone.

M: Smooth and easy to drink. Bitter aftertaste, with lactose overtones.

D: A really solid example of the style. Recommended.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2012 Not as much aroma as I would¬íve expected. A little bit of smoke. Tastes roasted. Chocolate, a little coffee, with a little bit of biscuit. Not quite as smooth as a cream stout should be, but great on the palate. Pleasant, welcoming aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2012 Sweet milk stout with slight roastiness.  The mouthfeel was fizzy, even after warming up; never gave me the smooth feel I expected.  The flavor just didn¬ít come out on this beer. (Update note: when boxing up the empty bottle, I saw the bottled date. It was 16 months old.  Shame on me for buying it!)
Pours black...brown head  aroma of coffe and burnt toast....taste isa creamy well balanced chocoate malts....awesome
Pours dark. Smooth, creamy tasting stout with the slightest bite at the end.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2012 Thanks to Roy¬ís Liquors in Ft. Pierce, FL. for supplying this one the last 6-7 months. Aroma is heavenly: chocolate, slight coffee and roasted malt. Appearance is pretty black with minimal head. Taste goes right along with the aroma: malty with minimal bitterness and it¬ís not heavy or light on the palate. Some reviews have this tasting thin, but I disagree. Other members of my family love this one, even my mother! Take it for what it is: a great tasting stout with decent drinkability. Highly recommended!
thick dark brown, almost black. one finger head. chocoalte, coffee, and maybe a hit of vanilla. reasonable sweet. very pleasant.
UPDATED: NOV 21, 2014 Pours very dark, almost black, with very little head. Aroma is rich and malty. Taste is great; rich, smooth, and deep. Notes of chocolate, licorice, and malts. Thumbs WAY up!
Bottle. Pours pitch black with virtually no head. Aroma has vanilla and anise. Taste is fairly sweet with some licorice and coffee notes. Palate is full and enjoyable.

Bottle from Ryan - thanks!  Black pour with a froth of tan foam that quickly fades to a slick.  Aroma is dry roast, chocolate (both bitter and creamy soft), light coffee, and some background hops.  Taste is pleasant sweet chocolate with a contrasting dry roast and bitterness.  Just a bit of malt sweetness underneath the roast and a touch of hop bitterness toward the finish.  Clean and creamy mouthfeel.  It¬ís a Bell¬ís stout - it¬ís awesome as expected!
draft.  Pours very dark with a decent amount of froathy head.  Aroma was sweet, and made you want to drink it right up.  Taste was good, but left something to be desired.
12oz bottle. deep dark brown with a frothy tan head. aroma of sweet malts, chocolate and coffee. roasted taste mainly of coffee and chocolate, sweet. full bodied on the palate, smooth and creamy.

Pours very dark with a moderate-sized tan head. Slight sweet and skunky smell, though that does not come through in taste. Hints of chocolate and roasted flavors come through, making this a nice and slightly light stout.

black hue with small tan head, roasted, chocolate, nothing overwhelming, malt sticks around, kind of roasted almost woody but sour aftertaste, smooth, medium to full body, not the best wouldn¬ít but a case but good

Pours very dark with a small tan head.  Taste of roasted malts, chocolate, some coffee.  Balanced.  Sweet but not overpowering.  Understated alcohol with a smooth pleasantly bitter finish.  Very nice and I¬íll say it again: balanced.
Dark brown with brown head, nice lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee. Taste is sweet coffee ice cream. Quite nice.
Sweet fruit aroma.  Deep dark appearance. Taste is medium sweet. I enjoyed this one a lot.

Pours dark brown with little to no tan head.  Aroma is roasted and sweet malts.  Taste is bitter dark chocolate, caramel malts, other things that are dark.  Finishes pretty bitter.  It¬ís ok, but certainly not their best stuff.

Originally reviewed: 3/10/09. Pours a deep coal black with about an inch¬ís worth of tan head on top. Retention was lacking, but the lacing rings were superb. Smells of milk chocolate! Great cocoa tones mixed with roasted coffee beans. Very pleasant. 

Super creamy mouthfeel. Silky smooth. Great dark chocolate flavor that finishes like a bitter coffee. Great roasted characteristics in this one. This was a very easy stout to drink; and most often with stouts for me it¬ís one-and-done, but not this one. I could drink a few of these for sure. Recommend.
Wonderful cream stout. Sweet malts and notes of chocolate and molasses. Nice rich, dark color, making it nice for a black winter night.

Had this in the bottle as wasn¬ít impressed.  I¬ím actually surprised I hadn¬ít rated this before.  Tonight it¬ís a tap flight at Bavarian Lodge.  Very dark brown, almost black, in the glass.  No head.  Light coffee aroma.  Taste is thin but has decent roasty flavor with aromatic hop balance.  It¬ís nothing like I was expecting and is NOT A MILK STOUT for ay of you that might mistake the style because of the name.  I like the roast but that¬ís about it.  Black IPA fans might like this because of the hoppiness but there are literally hundreds of beers I would choose before taking his one again.

Bottle, thx to SecretSanta. A very dark brown beer, finger-thick tan to beige head on top. Roasted malts, chocolate and coffee on the nose, more pronounced than for the Kalamazoo Stout. Roasted, coffee-ish flavor with some chocolate and notes of beef stock. Full-bodied, smooth and dry. Roasted finish. As the Kalamazoo Stout, a bit one-dimensional, but certainly very nice. 110930

Bottle. Very dark brown with old copper penny highlights and a thick tan head. Aroma sets my mouth watering: chocolate liqueur, milk, treacle. Flavour is like liquid brownies from the pan, chocolatey, a little doughy, creamy and delicious.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 12 ounce bottle purchased fourteen months ago at Bruisin¬í Ales in Asheville, North Carolina while on a trip to Knoxville to visit my then-fiancee, now-wife ($2.25).  Pours what appears to be pitch black with two fingers of dark khaki head.  Somewhat muted aroma of salty ocean breeze, toasted grains, and smoky coffee.  Flavor has hard roasty-malt notes of astringent leather, ashy campfire, and espresso but then actually smooths out toward the finish with additional notes of dark chocolate, nuts, and cacao beans.  The harsh roast flavors move into a more semi-sweet finish which is quite nice.  Creamy mouthfeel and rather soft on the palate but it has an astringent mouth-drying effect which is interesting.  (1440, 685)

Thanks to Secret Santa for this.  Pours silky black with a small brown top that quickly disappears.  Aroma of roasted malts, bitter chocolate, hazelnut and some small smoke.  Taste is a little astringent, smooth roasted malts, small smoke and a little hop bitterness.

This beer is great, much like the old ale.  Nose is muted quite a lot, do pick up some faint chocolate, cherry, and hop characteristics.  Head dissipated quickly, not much of it.  Taste is very sweet, lots of light roasted chocolate flavors, spicyness from the hops.  A very nice balance of sweet and savory.  Not terribly multi dimentional, but very well made.  Enjoyability 4.5/5.
Sweet and creamy as expected, not as balanced as it could be, but very good nonetheless. The hops and sweet malts are a bit at odds with each other.

Pours a silky black with a finger of light brown head. Coffee, roasted malts, creamy caramel on the nose. Great creamy mouthfeel, rich chocolate notes. Really luxurious stout. It was gone too quickly.
For a sweet stout (not my favorite style) this is great!  The chocolate and caramel roasts dominate, but the smooth feel and overall character of the beer are pleasantly surprising.

12oz bottle - pours opaque brown with tan head and trace lacing.  Nose is smoky and roasty.  Flavor is chocolate and light citrus hops.  Very sweet but doubly bitter fro the roast and hops.  I would call this a smoked/sweet stout.  Easy to drink.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt. Flavour is coffee, roasted malt, hop, fruit, chocolate. Medium to full body. Nice beer.

Small aroma and bold appearance with strong cream tones and great mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle as shown. Pours a dark brown with small beige head. The aroma is a faint light roast and chocolate. Thin mouthfeel with a strong vanilla flavor and cream. Easy to drink a good sweet stout from Bells.
Taste is vanilla, coffee and dark chocolate, with a creamy finish.  Nice, smooth alternative to Kalamazoo.

Pours a beautiful opaque dark brown with a mocha colored head. Smell is sweet with vanilla and mocha predominating, with some hints of coffee. Taste is sweet with a lingering taste of coffee and dark chocolate, and perhaps cappuccino. Finish is sweet and lasting, and just bathes the palate. Quaff Score ( drinkability with heart enjoyment ) 9 / 10

Pours a dark brown with a creamy tan head and a sweet aroma of chocolate. Taste is sweet, of chocolate and roasted malt with a nice, smooth finish, with a nice creamy mouthful. Very drinkable and tasty, great brew from Bells.

Gorgeous midnight pitch-black, with nice half-finger tan head. Bubbly, with decent retention and solid lacing, sticking to the glass attractively.

Nice aromatic touches of sweet roasted barley and cocoa, and other dark aromas/flavors. Kind of faint, have to sniff hard to notice.

Sweet toffee, light milk chocolate, vanilla and slightly roasted barley dominate the tongue. Fairly medium body, low carbonation. Very smooth, like a light chocolate shake, as nay stout should be.

Very good, tasty stout worthy of even the most elite ones. Maybe not the best, but very solid indeed.

Black...thick dark tan head.
Scent is dark chocolate, licorice....roasty.
Taste is slightly bitter dark chocolate, roasted malts, cream.
This is a really nice stout.  Great balance and flavour.

This has almost been my go-to beer since we got to Florida in December. Kind of strange considering it is hot in FL. but it¬ís a damn tasty beer. Sweet, smooth, roasted but not too bitter/acrid, chocolate

Bottle.  Pours dark reddish-brown with a small beige head.  Aroma of roasted and caramel malts with hints of wood, licorice and chocolate.  Sweet flavor with caramel, roasted malts and vanilla.  Hints of wood and licorice.  A little too sweet for my taste but pretty tasty.
Amazing!  Sweet coffer and chocolate aroma.  Heavy on the tongue.  Very sweet, but just right.  Great beer.

Vanilla chocolate and a bit of nuttiness
good beer for the late winter to prep you for the looming warmer weather!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle.
Pitch black pour with a good amount of creamy tan head.  Aromas of milk chocolate, cream, and a bit of roast.  Smooth and creamy with lots more chocolate and cream.  Good lord does Bells know how to make a stout.

Bottle. Not an all bad aroma. Pours dark brown with a slight head. Sweet, vanilla/chocolate taste. Pleasant aftertaste, like after eating candy. No offensive. Not refreshing.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle.  Strong roasted coffee aroma, deep burnt taste, brown color, light.  Is okay but not one of Bell¬ís better options.

Black with a thin head that appears light tan in color. Deep aroma highlighting decadent malts (chocolate, coffee, roast) along with a touch of cream for coffee and gingerbread. Rich and chewy malt flavor with notes of chocolate, coffee and brownies.

Bottle from Bell¬ís General Store.  Pours slightly thin and black.  Aroma is dark malt and roasty, more of a porter smell really.  But it has a big creaminess that a porter.  Smooth and creamy, with the last half tasting more of coffee.  Not too sweet, with a nice bitter finish.

Bottle from the brewery shared by kevinsenn. The first thing I notice is how big the bubbles are. Opaque black, no head, but very bubbly. Aroma is more roasty/smoky than I expect from what is ostensibly a sweet stout. Not sweet at all after drinking Moloko Plus. Creamy flavour and texture up front, but surprisingly bitter in the finish. Really smooth and drinkable, leaving a coating of roasted coffee on the tongue.

Bottle/12oz - Pours a very dark black/brown in color with an almost non-existent head and very low carbonation.  Aroma is of dark roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and dark fruits.  Flavor is similar.  Has a very dry, almost astringent, finish... detracts from the overall experience.  Not as good as their other stouts.

This is one of Bell¬ís weakest stouts, in my opinion, but it still is a solid go-to for the value in price in the stout category. Compared to the Java Stout or even Kalamazoo by Bell¬ís, this one is a little more on the extra-bite side. With all of that being said, this is still a quality beer that has a lot going for it. Pours a nice dark head and has decent aromas of chocolate and caramel.

Pours a very dark brown almost black with a small creamy white head.  Aroma is dark roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, and dark fruit.  Flavor is malty, sweet, rich, dark roast, sweetened coffee, chocolate and comes with moderate bitterness on a dry finish.  This is a great milk stout.
Rich, dark apearance and aroma. Heavy body, with creaminess throughout and minimal roasted character. This isn¬ít my favorite style, but this one is a pretty good option for the category.
Pours a nice black with a fair cocoa head and some lace.  Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malts, caramel.  Nice flavor, roasted malts, chocolate, caramel.  Smooth, some carbonation, sweet.

This is close to perfect for me. They do not use lactose in this beer, all the flavor comes from 10 malt varieties used in perfect conjunction.  Smooth and rich with no high or hot alcohol, make this one a year round Bell¬ís!

What a great well balanced Stout.  Definitely moving to the top of my list.  Coffee and Chocolate flavor with a very smooth creamy after taste.  I read in a previous review that the creamy flavor is not overwhelming as the name implies and I would have to agree.  Just very smooth and very tasty.  Well done Bell¬ís.

Bouteille gracieuset√© de la g√©n√©rosit√© de Patrick. Stout brun tr√®s fonc√©e avec une mousse beige. Le nez est passablement similaire au lait au chocolat du commerce, celui en berlingot (quel beau mot!) avec une touche de caramel. La bouche est ronde, facile, chocolat√©, quelque peu courte je l¬íaurais pr√©f√©r√© plus longue. Une finale sur les houblons poussi√©reux.

(Une courtoisie de JulienHuxley)  Un liquide brun fonc√©.  Une robe aux contours rouges.  Une t√™te cr√©meuse et solide.  Une dentelle.  Des parfums de chocolat au lait et de caramel qui r√©ussissent √† contenir des grains r√¥tis qui d√©veloppent une certaine √¢cret√©.  Des saveurs cr√©meuses et malt√©es, du chocolat brun et du caramel qui s¬í√©tendent sur la langue.  Un retour des notes r√¥ties √¢cres qui d√©rangent le spectacle.  Une bouche plut√¥t moyenne.  Une effervescence faite de petites bulles piquantes.  Une texture qui manque de consistance.  Une finale un peu courte sur des notes douces et chocolat√©es.
Delicious stout for a cold day. Caramel and chocolate aroma, sweet finish. Surprisingly bright, tangy note... nice creamy finish. Overall excellent.

Somehow haven¬ít rated this one.  Draft at Dexters.  Brown-black, thin beige head.  Mellow roasty chocolate aroma.  Not really so much a double..but I get it.  Pretty damn nice Cream Stout.  Mellow carbonation.  Choco-roast.  A touch watery.  Very desserty, but not such a thick mouthfeel.
milky black pour with almost no head, sweet aroma, and some roast notes, but it¬ís faint. Very smooth with a very creamy after taste. Lots of coffee right up front

Bottle. Aroma: Caramel, roasty, sweet, with notes of coffee and chocolate. Appearance: Pitch black, with dark tan, creamy head. Taste: Sweet, malty flavor, with vanilla and coffee notes. Palate: Very pleasant, soft carbonation, fully body, and astringent, long, slightly sour finish. Solid stout with great, full flavor and a wonderful feel on the palate. Would be great on a cold day. Average drinkability, but a real treat as a one-off beverage.
Pours stout-black with a fairly small tan head. Aroma and taste are chocolate milk with light roasted notes. Creamy finish but less than expected with a name like "double cream".

Bottle to Pint Glass
Toasty coffee aroma
Tan head, black appearance, 
Creamy, coffee taste, medium body, somewhat bitter finish

Pours a solid black color with a creamy tan head that displays moderate retention and lace. Smells of roast, coffee, milk and dark chocolate, hints of sweet caramel and little to no hop aroma. Taste is sweet creamy and smooth. Whipped milk chocolate mousse with hints of mocha, caramel and roast. Sweet roasty creamy and flavorful. Medium body with a velvety smooth creamy silky mouthfeel and a light to moderate level of carbonation. That is a nice flavorful stout. Its hard to believe there is no lactose in there.

Appearance is a small brown head and almost black color. Aroma is a sweet roasted chocolate. Taste is a very roasted coffee and chocolate with a little sweetness. Overall probably among the best I have had.

From the tap at James Street Gastropub and Speakeasy in Pittsburgh.  Properly black and light on the cream, very much like a normal stout without any overt sweetness or lactose.  Went well with the evening meal of chicken fried steak and fries; especially good with the creme brulee dessert.

A very solid sweet stout in deed! This is a great beer when your looking for a nicely balance stout that you can enjoy sipping on without a lot of heat or a huge ABV. Very approachable, I have used this beer as an intro beer to stouts with some of my beer bud¬ís that were looking to expand their palate but think they don¬ít like stouts because they have only tried high ABV Imperials.
Bottle pours almost black with two fingers of lingering light brown head and some lacing, smooth mouth feel, flavors of chocolate and coffee
Aroma of cocoa, chocolate, and a hint of coffee.  Pours black with a creamy lingering head.   Mouthfeel is light and smooth.  Taste of milk chocolate, slight chocolate.  Easy to gulp.

Poured into a snifter. Bottled 10/10/11.

3.5 A: Black color. Two fingers of creamy light brown head. Retention is about average or slightly better and a touch of lacing is left.

4.0 S: Mild roastiness. Layer after layer of sweet milk chocolate and cocoa. Light coffee aspect with light vanilla. Very subtle burntness and acridity (if that¬ís a word).

3.0 T: The last time I had this I remembered it to be a lot different. This time, it is severly lacking in intensity with an undeveloped flavor profile. All of the pieces found in the nose are here, but are way more mild. 

3.5 M: Lighter medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Reasonably creamy, but not as creamy as I thought this was.

3.5 D: I don¬ít know if this batch is a bit off or if my bottle is, but this doesn¬ít seem to be the brew I remember it to be. Oh well, I¬íll re-review if necessary.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-16-2011 21:51:47
Great beer. I have never tried anything from Bell¬ís brewery but look forward to discovering other great beers.

Bottle. The aroma was a typical coffee noted stout, but then a basement-like peat floated out on the finish. Strange. I sniffed a quarter, half, and upon finish, and still found the same mixed aroma. The appearance was a deep dark brown, a friggin¬í bear, with a light tan head that was barely there at all. The jerk. Palate wise, it was a medium bodied creamy texture (duh!). The taste had an acidic bitter finish with that musty basement peat filling out the bulk of the taste, a foundation of coffee/chocolate laid beneath.

Chocolate, roasted coffee, and light resin in the aroma, this stout pours deep brown.  The tan head recedes slowly, yielding flavor that fits the aroma.  The body is medium, with a creamy slick texture.  A very enjoyable seasonal stout.
Pours almost black with a dense foamy head. Aroma is of a smoky coffee with a hint of chocolate. Palate feel and taste is a creamy smoky aftertaste that stays with you until sip.
better than Makeson¬ís in terms of cream stouts. smooth, chocolatey, some caramel and toffee notes, warm roasted barley, a little peat and grassiness. very nice.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a dark brown almost black with a small tan head that goes quick. Aromas of coffee, cream, cocoa and a nice burntness. Flavor is slightly bitter up front from the coffee and slight hop bitter. Finishes with a nice coffee/cocoa flavor. Mouthfeel is very oily. Overall a pretty solid beer.
Almost a contender....still not as good as European counter parts but damm good
UPDATED: FEB 13, 2012 12 oz bottle pours black with a tan colored head.  Aroma is of burnt malts and a slight chocolate sweetness.  Taste is burnt malts, bitter chocolate and a hint of coffee.
12oz bottle pours dark brown/black with a medium tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and molasses. Creamy mouthful, with chocolate and coffee finishing bittersweet. One of my all time favorites!
Black with soft tan head.   Roasty dominate aroma.  A nice roasty, fairly dry stout with a nice creamy-sweet edge.

Just as a top notch stout should be with hints of dark chocolate and roasted coffee. It has a great after taste that stays in your mouth. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Kennyshomebrewing.blogspot.com

This beer was poured from a 12oz bottle into a Town Hall sniffer.

A. The beer pours a pitch black. About 2mm of a tan head, that faded relatively quickly. Minimal to no lacing on the glass.

S. Smells of mild chocolate, toffee and smoke and light coffee.

T. Strong toffee/vanilla sweet taste. The sweetness never really fades from your mouth. Smooth, but almost a little bit bitter.

M. Full bodied, but a thin feeling on the tongue. It meets it claim, and is a creamy smooth tastes.

O. Overall it is a good beer. I wouldn¬ít have a problem ordering this in a bar. However I wasn¬ít blown away by the flavor. It seemed to be very one sided. The initial cream sweetness holds through, but not as many other flavors come out after. I feel like even with a year under it¬ís belt, this beer might not round out.

Draft. Pours black with a nice tan head, good retention/lacing. Aroma of milk chocolate, cream, espresso, roast, vanilla. Taste is mildly roasty, espresso, milk chocolate, low bitterness. Palate is soft, creamy, average carbonation, creamy/roasty finish. Very nice.
Big creamy head and black colour. Roasty malt and lactose. Roasty malt and some lactose. Really milky foamy feel.

Bottle pours an opaque black with a small tan head. The aroma is complex. Chocolate hit me first, then coffee, then a bit of dark fruit, then roasted/smoky malts.  Full body with just enough carbonation.  Finish is long and full of roasted malts.  I thank the guy at the beer store for recommending this when he saw me looking at a couple of other stouts.
UPDATED: JAN 17, 2012 From tap. Black with off white head. Subdued toasty aroma. Roast sweet slightly fruity flavor.
Aromas of caramel, chocolate, coffee. Appearance is black, cloudy, frothy head. Taste of medium bitterness. On the palate full body, creamy, long finish. Overall a good beer.

Pours black with a short brown head.  Slight aroma of coffee and dirt.  Lots of coffee in the taste.  Little carbonation. Quite sweet with a really creamy mouthfeel but it leaves your mouth very sticky afterwards. Really good!

Pours black with thin chocolate brown head from a bottle.  Roasty, malty aroma lead to a similar creamy flavor profile.  Not as thick as expected, and the high carbonation was a little unpleasant to the palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Batch 10670. Inky black pour with a medium sized dark head. Coffee and earth aromas with hints of sweetness. Flavor is sweet, rich coffee and dirt notes with a hint of milk chocolate. Somewhat thin mouthfeel.
Pours very dark and opaque.  A lightly carbonated and very smooth and sweet tasting stout with little hop taste able to be discerned in the smoked coffee taste of the finish.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2012 A - pours deep dark brown with small brown head, lacing. 

T - Aromas of chocolate and chocolate,  toffee, and  light grass. 

M - lightly syrupy. Nice Mf light creamy drinkable. 

T -  A sweeter stout with chocolates throughout, lightly bitter gassy on palate and smokey coffee grounds ending. 

O - A good average stout. drinkable with lightly smokey bitter ending. 

6+

Pours ebony brown with a long-lasting brown head and good spider web lace.  Imagine what a great "regular" stout (think Guinness or Murphy¬ís) should taste like if it is kicked up a bit, and you¬íll have this perfect brew.  Good tasting roasted caramel malt with a strong balancing bittering that doesn¬ít include noticeable hop flavors.  Some sweet malt re-balances the finish.  An exceptional brew.

12 oz bottle: Thank you Michael! Pours a dark black with a rich brown head. Aroma is sweet and malty with chocolate, raisin and plum notes. Taste is light coffee, chocolate malts and sweet like toffee. Smooth drinker but not much bite. Good one overall.

Bottle from batch 9513. Pours black with little head that fades. Nose is huge aldehydes, sour notes and tobacco.  First sip is sweet malty flavors with vinous tartness but amazingly drinkable. Not what I expected, drinks like a Scottish ale. Finish is mild smoky bitterness.

Bottle at the Monk. Aroma is of coffee and chocolate with some smokiness. Appearance is dark with ruby red hints, nice cream tan head. Taste starts out a little smokey and quickly goes to coffee and chocolate. Finishes smooth with a nice creaminess. Great beer overall.

Pours black with a small tan head.  Aroma of fresh coffee, roasted malts.  A lot more complexity in the taste-  fresh roasted coffee with cream and a bit of sugar,   biter chocolate, toasted malt, burnt toffee, a slight hint of earthiness in the back.  Let it sit  few minutes and the roasted coffee became more amplified.  medium to heavy body, very smooth.  Give it a few minutes for the carbonation to die down.  A worthy winter sipper.

Bottle.  Very solid beer.  Night black color, cappucino foam on top.  Not much aroma to speak of.  Taste is coffee, bitter chocolate, hint of licorice, with a slightly tangy finish, then more lingering bitterness.  Creamy mouthfeel.  No flaws with this one really.

Pours black. Very slight, tan head. sweet, malty, incredible flavor, a bit of coffee, very creamy. Excellent taste easy to drink. Unfortunately I think I had it a bit too cold. Should have left it out for a minute. Cheers!

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown with a slight tan head.  The aroma is somewhat muted, but sweet and malty.  The flavor is nice, but not terribly complex - malts, a touch of coffee, and a little bit of breadiness.  Very creamy mouthfeel.  Not one of my favorite Bell¬ís beers.

Pours black with a thick. fluffy, off-brown head. Strange, I can¬ít get much of an aroma off of this; some chocolate maybe. Flavor is slightly spicy, smooth, creamy, little bite, some dark chocolate on the back end. Not much else going on here overall. This rating seems unfair. I plan to rerate on a different bottle. Strange.
Good stout, I think I prefer Kalamazoo stoiut better but it was tasty.  Very dark, nice aroma...hints of chocolate & coffee.  Taste was mild, I guess I was expecting more...still a nice stout.

1. Look - A black beer with a small tan head.  2.  Sniff - It has a big roasted chocolate aroma.  3.  Sip - This full bodied stout is very smooth, swet, and creamy.  4. Another Look - This is a good looking stout with above average lacing.  5.  Evaluate - Overall, this is a very enjoyable stout.  It has a sweet creamy taste with a mild dry finish.  I would absolutely recommend to my family, freinds, and especially those who only drink Guinness.

This beer rules and is a good starter for anyone who hasn¬ít had a stout or are not big fans of the style. Bottle. Pitch black with milky aroma and a hint of chocolate. Taste is a hint of creamy chocolate, roasted malts, caramel, sugar. Not overly sweet though just good flavor used sparingly. The palate on this beer is so smooth and creamy, cloudy like, fluffiness. A complex and interesting stout made by Bells, and I wouldn¬ít expect anything less.

Black pour with a foamy khaki head.  Rather odd milky aroma ... not much else but I think the beer was still a bit too cold.  Flavor of coffee, toffee and molasses with a tingly bitter finish.  Thick mouthfeel with a tingly carbonation underneath.  Quite nice ... but the weird milk-like aroma was a tad off putting.

Black pour ruby hue thin beige/tan head .... aroma of lactose light roasted caramel malts cocoa ..... taste is of sweet lactose, creamy chocolate, cocoa, little licorice and vanilla with a sweet finish dry lingering..... Good stuff thinner body oily mouthfeel but well balanced

Pours hazy dark brown with light brown head and great retention.  Aroma is coffee, raisins, licorice, chocolate, leather, hugely complex.  Taste is sweet chocolate with notes of nuts, raisins, coffee, anise, cream.  Body is medium-heavy, super creamy, full mouthfeel, dryish roasty finish.  Overall, an incredible brew.

Video review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dECGUAE-DIA

Appearance: Jet black + red transparencies skimming bottom, minimal head, minimal lacing

Smell: Burnt coffee, raw cinnamon, bittersweet chocolate, earthiness

Taste: Incredible body, amazing cloud-like mouthfeel, burnt coffee, chocolate fudge, molasses, roasted carmel malts, black licorice, oak bark + chocolate milk + cardboard residual, hint of raisin + vanilla bean, well balanced, mild carbonation, drinkable

Pairings: Aperitif w/ brie + fresh bread, bruschetta
Date: October 29, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Quad Tasting Event Minneapolis. Full description not available as I was sampling many beers as part of a tasting event.

Pours deep brown with a mocha colored head. Nose is roasted malts, burnt sugar and vanilla. Flavor is bitter chocolate, roasted malt and milky sweetness. Palate is silky and smooth, but a touch thin. Very easy drinker.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2012 Tr√®s cr√©meux en apparence avec un ar√¥me assez ordinaire de torr√©faction cartonn√©e. En bouche c¬íest vraiment onctueux avec un fini sec. Un spectacle de texture plus que de saveurs, je serais curieux d¬íy go√ªter en f√ªt.

A dark brown beer with a red tinge and a small tan head.  The aroma is roasted coffee, very nice.  The flavor is chocolate and coffee and extremely smooth.  Really good all around and super easy to drink.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours opaque coal black with very small dark brown highlight and one and a half inch light brown head.  Some lacing, thick cream body, and well carbonated.  Taste is burnt malt, coffee, some chocolate, a hint of vanilla, and light bitter chocolate finish.  Pretty good and very creamy.

Aroma is dark roasted malt with a little bit of chocolate.  Taste is sweet with a strong malty character including biscuit and dark fruit.  Carbonation seems a little high.  Also the mouthfeel is a thinner than I would normally expect from Bell¬ís.  Very good, but I¬ím not sure if the price reflects the quality.

12oz bottle from Chuck¬ís poured into an English pint. Pours black with a very thing layer of dark tan head. Aroma of burnt toast, light milk chocolate and a little vanilla. Taste is very lightly sweet and a little bitter. Nice dark chocolate and coffee notes. A little smoke taste with some roasted dark malt. Medium bodied with a thick and creamy texture. Soft carbonation and a long finish. Overall, very good. I would gladly drink this every day.

As far as non-flavored sweet stouts go, this one rates high.  Smooth and robust.  They use 10 different malts.  This brew has more grain depth than the typical sweet stout.  No coffee, no chocolate, just straight up smooth and creamy stout.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2012 Pours cola brown to black with a thin mocha head. Nose is roasty, almost woody with a hint of vanilla. Taste is quite sweet, almost like molasses, with a crisp bitterness on the end. Palate is smooth, toward full, and really mellow with a lingering toasty aftertaste. Perfect for fall. Understated yet versatile.

Draught, 6.1%. Roasted aroma, sweet and salty liquorice. Black colour. Good stable brown head. The flavour is milder but fuller than the aroma. Good mild coffee note with only a little bitterness. Very creamy flavour and mouthfeel. Really good and well-balanced.
Dark brown.  Roasted malt, coffee, dark fruit.  Coffee, blackened malt, mild fruit esters, light brown sugar, and a hint of lactose.  Roast residual with mild hops.
lovely beer. opaque black. very roasty aroma. medium-bodied but full-flavored, lots of roast, coffee, bit of burnt toast to it, but very smooth with a dry finish. pour me another.

Bottle. Aroma: Nice roastiness, burnt toast, smoked and vanilla. Appearance: Black pour with small mocha head. Taste: On the sweet side, old grain, chocolate. Palate: Low carbonation and stick. Overall: Nice aroma, but it was an old bottle. I will have to try it again.

On tap at Bells. Pours super black with no head. Aroma is milk chocolate, sugar, coffee. Taste is very sweet, milky lactose, chocolate, roasted malts. Some nuttiness. Licorice. Finishes smooth and medium long - quite sweet.
Bottle. Poura black with a tan head. Aroma chocolate, hay, malt, caramel and roaster. Flavor of sweet and roasted malt with some coffee, chocolate and yeast. Medium body, average carbonation.
Bells makes awesome beers. This is no exception. Great color, toasty sweet, great balance. One of my favorite stouts.

Pours a dark black with a thin, somewhat persistent head. The taste and aroma is a complex mix of several malts, raisin, chocolate, vanilla and nuts, balanced by just the right bitterness.  The mouth is full and lightly carbonated. I¬íve sampled a dozen batches of Double Cream Stout. Each one has been slightly different and each one has been great. My favorite beer.

Pours black with a rich caramel head, flat carbonation.  
Rich chocolate, caramel, sweet roasted malt notes.
Sweet taste.
Bitter sweet finish, chewy & creamy, lively on the tongue.
12 oz bottle, poured black with a thin off-white head. Aroma of coffee, sweet malt, and dark chocolate. Not as strong smelling as many stouts.Well balanced and very drinkable

Tasted on 8/2/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Lush Roscoe, batch 9357.  Pours absolutely jet black with a thick tan head that slowly recedes to rocky lace, leaving a thick layer of lace residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is dark and malty with brown sugar, raisin, and prune sweetness, dark chocolate, mocha, and just a hint of roasted bitterness.  The flavor is lightly sweet with some vanilla and brown sugar up front, moving to the fruity prune, raisin, and milk chocolate notes, and finishing with just a hint of roasted coffee bitterness, and even more vanilla.  The body is full and creamy with average, mouth-filling smooth carbonation, and a long milk chocolate and vanilla finish.

12 oz bottle from ksurkin. Black with a small spotty light tan head. Aroma of sugar, roasted malt and light coffee. Flavor is sweet with some roasty and coffee bitterness. Full body with mild carbonation and a thick, creamy mouth feel. Nice beer, sweet but balanced with the dark roasted malt.

12oz bottle. Dark brown with a mocha creamy head. Roasted malts, coffee, chocolate but mild. Nice and creamy, medium bodied, nice carbonation, slightly bitter at the beginning with a hint of sweet which disappears as you swallow, becomes more bitter, malty and some hops. A good beer although not as sweet as I would have expected (not a bad thing though).
Really nice sweet stout.  Rich and creamy mouthfeel with taste notes of sweet cream and roasted coffee.  Some slight acidic sourness detracted a bit from the flavor.  Overall great stout.
UPDATED: DEC 15, 2011 Very rich creamy stout, delicious toasted malts. Very smooth cannot taste any alcohol, amazing stout wish I could get it

12oz bottle. Light-brown one-finger head, nearly pitch-black color. Was putting this one off for far too long because I feared it would be too rich and thick for the summer, but it turns out that this is perfectly drinkable. Doesn¬ít taste too full, very smooth going down. Wonderfully gradual deep-malt aroma. Roasty, with a sweet aftertaste. Special, indeed.
Dark with a thin and light brown head. Roasty malt with a smooth thick taste, creamy with hints of nut, coffee, and sweet burnt caramel.
Big chocolate notes on the nose. Pours black with an inch of khaki foam. Nice roasted malt on the tongue. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy a bit like pudding. Fantastic!

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2011 Roasty, so roasty, with a chocolate-cream heart and a dry soul, this bottle makes for quite the tasty pint.  The nose is no big hoopla, as does the pour;  not the best opening, no, but the flavor makes up for lost ground.  Full of bitter cocoa and roasted malt, but with a modestly hoppy finish that accentuates the blackened fade.  The feel is bubbly yet with a decadent smoothness that makes this brew disappear much too quickly.  Nice stout.

Not quite what I expected. The beer poured balck with a frothy head. The flavor was somewhat mild, definitely creamy. Not really as strong as flavors as in the Kalamazoo. A bit of a cherry metalic twang.

Cremig s√º√ümalziger Antrunk, hierbei ist die S√º√üe allerdings nicht sark und st√∂rend, wie oft bei solchen Bieren , er unterst√ºtzt hier eher das nur mittelm√§√üig w√ºrzige Malz. Frisch und gleichzeitig aromatisch im Mittelteil, das Malz verh√§lt sich zum Teil zur√ºckhaltend. Zum Ende deutlich w√ºrziger werdend, sehr cremig und weich-malzig mit ansorechener Frische, wenig holzig-karamellig, im Abgang stark karamellig. Sehr gelungenes Stout von Bells. Danke an den Doppelbock f√ºr das Bier! -/12/12/11/9/12

First beer @ The Foundry, KC .. . Pours a dark chef black .. . medium foam, good lacing .. . solid mouth, velvety .. . mild sweetness, goes down easily- tar and chocolate mostly .. . Last night I lay in bed looking up at the stars in the sky and I thought to myself, where the heck is the ceiling.

12oz bottle from Plaza liquors in Tucson 
Appearance: Pours black with a small tan head and some light lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, sweet roasted coffee and chocolate 
Taste: Dark malts, chocolate with roasted coffee in the finish 
A nice sweet stout, easy to drink and smooth.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2012 tap at foundry. beautiful black with dark khaki head. surprisingly thin mouthfeel. sweet and easy to drink, but not as complex as i would expect. good but overrated.
bottle from red x: still beautiful. better aroma than last entry. roasty with some cream there. yeah taste is not as vivid as i would expect from a "special double cream" but it is a great beer. since last entry I have quite smoking. no doubt i have given some undeservedly low aroma marks when i had been a smoker....
actully it¬ís coming around taste wise as it warms. my bad. great beer.

12 oz bottle from Horrock¬ís Farm Market in Lansing, batch #10151. Served in an English pint. Pours clear reddish black with a small light brown head. The head fades to a bare cover and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has big aromas of roasted malts, smoke, chocolate, earth and a hint of coffee. The flavour is moderately sweet and intensely roasty, with notes of coffee and chocolate, with just a touch of herbal hops for balance. The finish is long and roasty. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, silky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice stout. It has a beautiful smooth texture and very nice roasty overtones. Not quite as full bodied as I had expected, but nice nonetheless. 2011-05-17
I¬ím having this firkin at TJ¬ís in Phoenixville and I think this is the Bell¬ís I¬ím having. Very dark black body and nice lacing. Very smooth and more complex than a typical stout.

Poured nice and dark into a wide brandy glass. With a tan head and wavy lacing, tis¬í one of the finest looking beers I¬íve laid eyes on.  The scent is a little bitter, full of coffee and chocolate notes with a hint of smoky goodness. The flavor follows the scent well... tasting malt and chocolate. After that there is the bitterness of coffee, which turns slightly sour with a smooth smoky undertone. This beer settled incredibly well, and is nothing short of what I expected from Bells.

Very black with nice looking tan head.  Roasty almost burnt coffee nose.
Very smooth and silky.  Pleasing sweet malt coffee like flavor, with some chocolate.  I like the balance, meaning it isn¬ít too sweet.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2011 Bottle.  Pours a black with a semi thick tan head.  Some splashy lacing throughout.  Smells of a little alcohol (which is surprising considering only 6%), coffee and a bit of chocolate nibs.  Taste is of sweetened coffee and chocolate, but the alcohol in the smell is not  in the taste.  Nice creamy mouthfeel.  Overall, a really nice beer from Bells again.  Really nice as a late night sipper.

12 oz. bottle, pours black with a small beige head. Aroma of sweetened chocolate, a lactate-y quality and slight roastiness. Flavour follows suit, with the roastiness and sweetened chocolate upfront - milky body that leaves the slightly sweetened chocolate lingering. Quite good though nothing overly special.

Pours a dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla and toffee. Very sweet roasted taste from the malt, with a bit of chocolate and a hint of coffee. Extremely smooth and creamy body, exactly how a cream stout should be. Very good.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2011 Pours a dark brown body with a small creamy head.  Aroma is burnt with chocolate, toffee, and cereal.  The mouth feel is full in body and high in warmth with a medium finish. Flavor of dark chocolate, toffee, and nuts...

Apr 23. Bottle @ Bell¬ís Store, Kalamazoo. Pours ruby black brown with a great brown head leaving lace. Aroma of chocolate, heavy roasted malt, coffee, sweet candy, molassis and bread; excellent. Lean fullbodied mouthfeel. Smootth, roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, fruity and slightlysweet flavor; very nice! Slightly acidy fruity palate. Finishes acidy tart with a fruity touch. Great stuff indeed.

Pours an opaque dark brown-black, with a light tan head.  Sweet aroma with notes of sugar, vanilla, and caramel--almost reminscent of a cream soda or root beer.  Taste is of burnt malts at first--smoky.  Opens up to reveals some choclatey subtlety--but retaining a relatively roasted character.  Mouthfeel is rather watery, a bit thinner than one might expect.  But it doesn¬ít detract from the experience.  In summary, another excellent stout from Bell¬ís--the aroma is at odds with the taste, but both are worthy.

¬í07 bottle drank in April 2011.  Held up really well.  Not a thick, sweet gross mess like some cream stouts (I¬ím looking at you Sam Adams).  Sweet but not cloying.  Opaque.  Very thin head.  Medium body.  Nice molasses aromas on the nose and vanilla.  Taste is more roasted malts and coffee.  Terrific if you are in the mood for a slightly sweeter stout.
Charcoal color and taste. Tan head and lacing emanates from this beer that is like chilled coffee...heaven in a glass.

Black pour with dense, creamy brown foam atop.  Aroma is roast, molasses, brown sugar, chocolate and a touch of tangy coffee.  Velvety, creamy mouthfeel.  Good malt sweetness with more cocoa, coffee and roast notes on the palate.  An excellent sweet stout that packs a ton of flavor and a lush feel into a mere 6.1% abv.

Soft caramel roasty aroma from a dark brown near black pour with nice head and lacing as I dranketh from my cupeth.
Tasted of roasted and boasted.  Nice beer.

Bottle. Poured deep black but not as black as can be. Coffee colored head. Nose was alcohol and roasted malt/caramel. Taste was nice with hints of caramel, cream, light chocolate and a hint of alcohol. Smooth. Good stuff.

Just on the light side of black with little to no head. The lacing is also very minimal and it appears to be on the carbonated side. The aroma is quite interesting with notes of bitter coffee and sweet cream. Just a tad of alcohol in the nose. The flavor is quite smooth with a bitter coffee front and a roasty finish. Very smooth.

Smell: slight chocolate, airy, NestleQuik
Taste: milk chocolate; balanced with a little hops; vanilla mocha notes;
Mouthfeel: watery, little creamy
Overall:  Okay.  Enjoyable but doesn¬ít stand out.

12 oz bottle from PA: Pours midnight black with a quickly dissipating tan head. Notes of bitter cocoa upfront with slight notes of licorice and caramel. Nice creamy medium body. Well balanced stout that isn¬ít overly sweet. Nice toasted notes upfront give way to some bitter cocoa, vanilla, and slight roasted coffee and a very slight dry finish. Not a typical sweet stout in that it¬ís not sweet like others such as Young¬ís Chocolate Stout or Southern Tier¬ís Choklat, however really great! Overall: (A)
Bells sure does like their dark beers. Works perfect for me! This is is especially dark, meant for dark days and dark treats. Exceptionally good. A+. Get it. Drink it!

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2011 Bottle @ home. Dark black/brown appearance with a small brown head. Dark roasty brown malty, nutty, light espresso nose. Creamy mouth feel. Dark roasty, light chocolate malty flavor with some coffee, nuts, and toffee. Sweet, creamy, nutty, coffee finish. Excellent beer.

12oz bottle poured into my Bruery tulip... Good looking beer, black, with a big medium tan head, great retention and lacing... The aroma reminds me of an oatmeal stout, a little sweet and super creamy, cocoa, a hint of chocolate, smells great... The taste loses a lot of the creaminess and relies mostly on the cocoa notes, a bit of bitter chocolate. While¬ís it good, just didn¬ít live up to what I was expecting. Some interesting prune notes come out, a touch too much alcohol on the finish... The feel is a bit too hot, could be more full too.

This was pretty darn good, frankly I¬ím surprised. I¬íd gladly have this again.

Bottle at a recent BA/RB gathering. Colour... dark brown with no head. Nose... very roasty with hints of malted milk balls and creme brulee. Palate... gentle on the palate with fudge cake and fudge bars laced with creme fraiche, vanilla bean and sugar sirop, then lingering with a charred pot de creme finish.
Pour is black with nearly no head, small dark tan carbonation. Nose is of coffee malts predominately. Taste is of extremely sweet coffee, very easy drinker for 6%.

Pours A creamy dark brown/black in my pint glass leaving a thin tan head. Aroma is Sweet chocolate with hints of coffee, and roasted grain. Flavor is much the same. Very rich, and smooth. I could drink this all night. Excellent!

Poured into a snifter. Pours a pitch black sea into my snifter with a dark tan head that recedes at decent rate. Chocolate of the bat in the nose. Very sweet aroma from the 10 different malts. Also has a very roasted aroma. The double cream stout has an extremely rich flavor. So much flavor with all the malts. This is perhaps my favorite beer from Bell¬ís. Coffee, Chocolate and molasses are all over this one. This beer makes the mouth salivate. Great sweetness with matching bitters. That roasted flavor is lingering for a while. At 6.1% this could become my new session stout if it wasn¬ít so limited. Pick this up, you won¬ít be disappointed.

Pours pitch black with a nice thick dark tan head.  Nose was a bit funky but you did get some chocolate and vanilla notes.  Taste almost reached the point of "just ok."  There is some chocolate in the taste but this stout was not the least bit sweet.  My hope that this was a funky batch but I am left with not much desire to try another.

Black pour with dirty brown head. Nice chocolate aroma. Taste is milk chocolate (not bitter) and very smoorh bordering on a milk stout. Great beer that is easy to drink, not overly filling and has no noticeable bitterness. 
12oz bottle english pint

12 oz. bottle from Oades Big Ten

Ar:  Roasty, somewhat nutty nose with a bit of woodiness.  
Ap:  Pours a deep creamy black with a 1/2" head that leaves spotty lace.
T:  Rich, creamy sweetish stout.  Notes of chocolate, roasted nuts, and a bit of wood on the finish.
P:  Thick, creamy body.  Luscious!

O:  Delicious.

Very nice dark brown, almost black color with some faint ruby highlights around the sides and edges.  A nice, full, creamy, fluffy, smooth khaki colored head with very nice retention and real nice lacing.  A nice malty tone in the aroma.  Some roasty aspects.  A bit of coffee.  A bit of chocolate.  Neither aroma is very robust.  Might be picking up a bit of raisin and a small note of the oatmeal and/or cream.  Seems to be balanced pretty well though.  The taste had a lot of the proper characteristics of a Stout.  Some roasted coffee and chocolate, but like the smell, not real pronounced or robust.  A minor hint of bitterness and maybe even a hint of some dark or burnt grain.  Medium mouthfeel.  Rather smooth and mostly creamy.  Did a nice job of leaving flavor on the palate.  Mostly dry, but not too dry.  I¬íve had better, more robust, complex Stouts, but this one is solid enough to be considered a good example.  very easy to drink and worth a shot if you see it.  Nothing over complicated.  More than anything a no-nonsence, pretty enjoyable Stout.

Aroma very sweet chocolate, cocoa, slightly roasty, hints of vanilla, a touch of caramel and slight nuttiness. Pour deep brown no visible light creamy beige head, minimal retention and lacing. Taste chocolaty, cocoa, slight hop bitterness, roasty malt, vanilla, nuttiness, heavy cream. MF full body very little carb. Overall an ok stout not my cup of beer.

Roasty smells. Dark, it is a stout. The head is oily. The taste is pretty sweat and roasted. It feels a little too fizzy on the tongue. It is what it is, if you like lots of cream, then you will like this.

A-deep black color with a thick two fingers of coffee colored head that lingers for some time and leaves a nice lacing on the glass

S-light nose that consists of roasted malt, hint of chocolate cake batter, and some light citrus sweetness

T-a roasted malt hits first followed by some bitter sweet chocolate, cake batter, touches of coffee, dark fruits, some raisin and prune that gives it a sweetness at the finish

M-very smooth and creamy as the name would indicate, medium body with a fair bit of carbonation.

D-this is a solid tasting beer with a great mouthfeel and robust creamy flavors. I could drink this beer quite frequently

Pours a dark opaque, with slightly brown foam(which I love).  Aroma is very light malt and semi-sweet.  Palate is a bit lighter than I usually like my stouts, probably because this is a "sweet" stout.  Taste is light coffee, light malt, not much hop. Overall a solid sweet stout.

Pours an oily dark black with a full head.  No lacing left behind.  Rich chocolate and roasty qualities come out nicely in the nose.  Maybe some molasses and anise as well.  Has a bit of an oily mouthfeel.  Heavy roasted malts and some sweet lactose sugars coming through.

Batch 8842.  Deep brown-black pour with a thick tan head.  The nose is very chocolatey.  It has the bright cocoaish intensity of the Expedition but in a much lighter body.  Very rich and chocolatey with a nice milk chocolate backbone.  Unctuous/silky body with a great balance of sweetness and cocoa.  There is a bit of vanilla and brown sugar rounding out the back.  Chewy, rich and very tasty.
Thanks to Chalsk.  Pours deep dark black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is toffee, roastyness and espresso.  Taste is espresso sweet.  Exceptionally smooth.

Bell¬ís just knows how to make beer.  Pour a dark brown color with an off white head.  Has a roasted, caramel aroma.  It is essentially a sweet stout with a nice bitter layer and chocolate notes through the finish.  Creamy yet refreshing.  Very good.
Great beer. It was like a dessert. Would have enjoyed it with a dark chocolate tort of some kind. Extremely smooth and yes creamy. Full bodied and roasty.
POurs dark brown with a minimal head.  Notes of sweet malt show throughout this mild bodied stout.  The sweetness shows through to the end and also seems to offer a bit of a milk/lactic note.
On Tap. This is one creamy and delicious ale. It just makes you want to suck it down. Bell¬ís serves it too cold though.

This one¬ís aroma is overwhelming with coffee. There is a clarity of this note, but no dynamics, which means it smells like coffee and nothing else. The tan head never forms fully, even if aggressively poured. The brew is black. The taste is more than just that of coffee, but barely so. There are vague hints of chocolate and nuts, but just that. It is robust in that coffee flavor and it is to be appreciated for that. A bit carbonized on the palate, the brew is heavy and filmy, though it does not take away from it. This stout is enjoyable and well done, but of a singular hook.

12oz bottle, pours a deep dark black, great tan lacing, nice sweet aroma, almost caramel. Interesting sweet taste, a bit of sweetness on the front and bitter on the back end. A cream sweetness becomes more prominent as the beer warms. Nice.

12oz bottle thanks to savvy1982.
Appearance : Pitch black with a small (even if I worked hard) brown and slightly creamy head.

Aroma : Coffee and roasted malt. Light notes of green olives. Faint nose overall. Light chocolate and light hops. Light alcohol.

Taste : Roasted malt and chocolate. Some resinous hops. Notes of coffee too. Palate is rather creamy but still a bit thin. Great dark chocolate on the finish. 

Overall : A little bit disappointing. Perhaps it¬ís a bit old. Nice stuff but nothing really special. A bit too much alcohol on nose and taste for such a not so high abv beer. Maybe a waited a bit too long to have it.
I could mix this with my Cocoa Puffs in the morning.  Great flavor...wonderful aroma.  Glad I have 4 left.

Beautiful dark black color and a cola colored head.  Slight smokey aroma.  Nice dark coco flavors mixed with some vanilla and smokey tobacco notes.  Bitter chocolate aftertaste.  I can totally see eating a rich chocolate dessert with this. Overall, nice sipping for the winter months.  It may even go well with a cigar.
Very drak brown with a thin light brown head. Warm, roasty flavor, with coffee notes. Reminds me of a very expensive coffee brand (in a good way).
Very smooth tasting cream stout. Not as thick as a stout and has a slightly bitter kick of a pale ale, which I definitely like. It is like a hybrid mix between the two types of beer, enjoy.

12 ounce bottle-  pours out an absolute opaque black, with an incredible syrup-like thickness.  Head was almost nonexistent.  Aroma was dark fruit and bog.  Amazing pallet, thick and smooth  Sweet and bitter at the same time, a very complex flavor mix includes cherries, toast and caramel.  Rich, defines a stout.
Can taste the chocolate and cream and makes it so very little is wrong with the world and all is good.
12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark black with a nice creamy head.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate, vanilla. Full bodied yet creamy, a great winter beer
Bottle purchased from Tiffany¬ís in Kalamazoo, Mich.  A very solid cream stout.  I must say, some of Bell¬ís has been hit or miss for me.  But, this beer is spot-on.  Well done.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2012 Bottle. 12 oz. Pours a deep, thick brown-amber with a tall, quickly diminishing amber head. Aroma of vanilla, cream, oats, milk, coffee, honey, toffee, caramel, tart cherry, figs, toasted malts, barley, and hints of maple. Firm, yet supple body with a soft, creamy, smooth palate. Awesome sweet stout

What a wonderful stout! Beautifully chocolatey goodness. Wonderful creamy texture and a Goldilocks texture (not-too-thick, not-too-thin) makes for a great beer. Aroma leaves some to be desired, though. Very little nose at all.
Pours black/brown with little head.  Light aroma of toasty oak.  Taste is pretty smooth, with medium toast malt and some cream.  Not as creamy as I thought it was going to be, but good.
Pours black with tan head.  Flavor is sweet, but less so than other sweet stouts, and balanced with a graininess.  Smells of chocolate and slight soy sauce, but soy is absent in the flavor.

Great Majestic dark stout. A fine refreshing drink. I would recommend not having more than one in an evening. Heavy.   Something to sip on. burnt Carmel undertones, creamy, thin coffee-ness, mild chocolaty taste. Good to let it breath in a glass. Not happy with the palate, a bit too sharp.  A fine beverage overall.

Pours heavy black, labors out of the bottle. Frothy, dark tan head on the pour but little head lingers and the lace slides down the glass.

Smells sweet, licorice and molasses with some coffee. The malt lingers subtly under the other scents. Smells like a roast-enhanced syrup.

Chewy beer. Roast is the primary taste with sweet edges. Chocolate, molasses, with a licorice tinge. Dry aftertaste.

This beer is most notable for its thickness. Chewy, malty, mostly roast flavor with sweet edges. Tastes more of a high abv beer than what it is.

It becomes smoother and roastier as it warms.

I poured a 12 oz bottle, aged approximately one year (batch #9446), into a snifter. This poured inky black with a thin khaki head that quickly dissipated and left little lacing. As expected, the age on this added some complexity to the beer. Its aroma of prunes and roast malt now mingled subtly with flavors of stone fruit, espresso, and Belgian-ness. Some of these flavors certainly are surprises for a stout, but I attribute that to the aging, and I hastened to add that they did not in any way diminish the beer. This is a decadent treat at any age.
Bottle (thanks guyinchicago)...  Dark brown pour with a thin, tan head.  Lactose, oaky, vanilla bean, coffee.  Thin palate, short clean finish.
Sweet and creamy.  Not particularly thick.  Notes of roasted malt and chocolate.  A nice session stout.

Dark brown/black color with mocha brown head. Aroma is lighter than I expected from a double cream stout. There is some toffee, milk chocolate, and roasted malt in the aroma, but they¬íre more hints than reliable signposts of flavors to come. On the tongue the beer is more bold with its flavors, but they¬íre more subdued than they are balanced. Balanced boldness is what I wanted, but I was disappointed. The sensation of this beer on the palate are definitely pleasant and uniquely creamy, but instead of being a "wow" sensation it was more of a simple sensation of comfort. Definitely nice on a cold day.

Whole Foods, DC six-pack ($11): Pours a nearly black color with the brown head. Aroma of creamed coffee, coffee creamer, cream and coffee, and a mocha latte. Double Cream is actually a little on the bitter side for a sweet stout, although there is still a sweetness. Also a little bit more watery than one would have expected, though creamy none the less. However, the bitter chocolate elements coupled with the superbly prepared malts make it all worthwhile.
Picked up at the brewpub. Pours dark brown with tan head. Light coffee notes, dark malt, medium body. Taste of sweet chocolate, light roasty coffee, caramel and toffee notes. Decent sweet stout.

What the heck? This was lame. Very dark brown, almost black beer, with a brown head. Sure looks nice. Weak chocolate aromas. Tastes of melted down bittersweet chocolate and chalk. Some tiny hints of watery coffee too. That is probably the best way to describe this one: a watery stout. Maybe the tap was bad? Oh well, next time.
pours dark and ends darker. aroma is chocalate, caramel, plum. taste is balanced milk chocalate. palate is medium mouthfeel. overall a solid beer.

Poured very dark with a big, fluffy head. Burnt caramel, coffee, fig, and dried fruit notes. There is a lot going on up front and ends smoothly. Great balance and a well made brew. It could be more complex, but I¬ím happy.
Almost black with a foamy tan head that contained a slightly red tint.  Roasted malt aroma.  Roasted malt, dark fruit, cherry, and molasses notes.  Somewhat watery mouthfeel.  Low carbonation.
Overall an enjoyable beer. Not much of a head or lacing. Black in color, looks just like a good stout. This is only my second "cream" stout (the other being Sam Adams) but I liked this one a lot.

Bottle from Sonoma in Delavan WI....black as night pour; dark tan head - faded quickly.  Definite hints of sweet chocolate; smooth.  Bittersweet chocolate on the longish finish.  A definite one to repeat.

Bottle. Mahogany near black with a quickly disappearing tan head. Roasty malts, and nice chocolate notes in the aroma that has a light sweetness cutting through.  Roasty, and bittersweet chocolate and a bit velvety texture with nice bubbly carbonation.  Thinner, but good for the style in terms of the weight.  Very dessert-centric in my opinion, and a very easy and tasty drinker.
12 oz bottle. Ours a dark brown with dark tan head. Roast malt and ripe fruit aroma. Roast malt with slightly complex flavors, some cherry notes as well. Nutty, or toffee finish.
UPDATED: JUN 20, 2011 Pours an imperial stout black. Taste is very light roasted campfire wood and slight acid coffee, with a nice body to it. Good stuff. Like a better Guinness.

12oz bottle.  Pours a jet black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is roasty, malty, and chocolate.  Heavy on the palate with mild carbonation.  Nice roasty flavor with a smooth chocolate finish.  An excellent sweet stout.
Poured from a 12oz bottle.  Pours nearly black with some head.  Smells of chocolate and vanilla.  Very sweet taste of chocolate and toasted malts.

Pours a dark brown/black color with a thin, deep tan head. Aroma has a smooth dark roasted note in combination with sweet chocolate and a very light vanilla and coffee presence. Flavor has a very strong grainy toasted note early, fades to a modest roasted presence and finishes with a very light coffee and chocolate flavor. Body is light with a low amount of carbonation.  Overall not too shabby of a brew. As a sweet stout, its not too sweet and resides on the lower end of the sweet stout in sweetness. As a stout, its very solid and definitely worth a sixer.

Pours a chocolate brown almost black with a very small almost non existant tan head. Aroma fills the nose with coffe and small hints of coca. Taste a mixture of coffee and a splash of soda water or cream soda. Dry tingling finish. Not as good as expected, but solid beer. Must try at least once if you are a stout lover.
Pours a dark brown color with a reddish brown head.  Smells of chocolate and coffee with some woody aromas mixed in.  Taste is a bit woody with some nice coffee flavors bursting through.

Pours black in color with a brown head.  Aroma is of malts, licorice, cream, chocolate, and some slight soy sauce.  Flavor is very malty.  There is definitely some cream present along with chocolate and a bunch of roastyness.  Leaves a big time malt finish.
Black with beige head, nice lacing.  Somewhat dried fruit aroma.  Thick mouth feel.  Sweet in the beginning.  Floral earthy notes in the finish.  A very thick and creamy stout.

This is good stout.  The deep black color and brownish head were perfect for a special stout.  The roasted malts were more evident more at the end of the beverage.  The chocolate flavors were smooth and added to the ale. There is  sweetness that is noticed from the beginning.  The medium body ale is a joy! A great stout to enjoy while watching the Steelers and Ravens.

It pours a dark brown sugar color, with not much head. It has a slightly bitter, yet sweet, chocolaty taste in the beginning. Better yet, it actually has a taste that lingers around well after, turning more roasty at the end.  Delicious for the winter.
Pours black with a tall brown sugar-colored.  Aroma of bitter dark chocolate and coffee.  Lively carbonation.  Flavor is bitter, sweet, and chocolaty,

Super black pour with a beige head. Lots of lactic notes in the nose with tons of bitter roast, cocoa nib, and milk chocolate. The flavor is much the same- creamy coffee and chocolate abound. Thick rich mouthfeel with a sweet finish.

Pours a chocolate brown with a small beige head. Aroma holds lots of lactic notes with heavy cream and milk chocolate- smells like a Lindt truffle (can¬ít argue with that). Also a bit of cocoa, roast, and slight bitterness. Flavor is roastier with heavier chocolate notes, but the cream still comes through. A touch of coffee bean sneaks in as well. Palate is light and drinkable for a stout. Really nice stuff.
