From my 64oz growler...aroma is not very present, but roasted malt notes are present.  The beer pours black and thick with a brown head that is moderate and lasting for a stout.  The taste is roasted malts and toasted almonds with some coffee flavor sneaking in.  Very chocolatey as well.  The palate is medium body with average carbonation.  Overall, one of the better stouts from Bells.  Not on the top of my list, but a very solid, drinkable stout.

Poured super dark with a thick, foamy mocha head.  Smooth, almost unassuming nose, sweeter and lighter than some of Bell¬ís other offerings.  Chocolate, coffee and cream aromas abound.  Flavors follow suit.  Finishes with shots of espresso.  The lactose kept this one smooth and the bitterness to a minimum.  Chocolatey, rich and smooth....the coffee and chocolate compliment each other well as neither stands out.  Nice stout and undoubtedly a good dessert brew.

Black brew with a somewhat fizzy medium brown cap of average size and some slippery ropy lacing. Interesting aroma - sour cream, lactose, dull chocolate, hazelnut, something like cherries or closer to raspberries. Deep sniffs expose more of a richness and a deeper roast and a better milk feature. The oddness seems to hang around but if you breath so damn hard that you can actually manage to lift the beer up in the glass on negative pressure alone you can find your own personal nirvana. The taste is also on the same odd line of overlying sourness. Sour cherry/raspberry to be more precise. Richness underneath, sweet and caramelly a bit, milky, roasty. Finishes a bit tart.. is this normal?

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours pitch black with a nice tan head and some lacing through out the glass, the aroma is balanced perfect with chocolate, coffee and malt, the flavor is smooth and is not overpowering by the chocolate or coffee but rather they compliment each other very well, delicious brew from Bells.

12oz bottle in a tumbler.  Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee with roasted malts.  This much better than a standard stout, with a strong roasted malt/coffee/chocolate flavor.  The hops are there, but covered up by the malts.  Average body, with a long finish.  Great beer.

G: Poured into a Bell¬ís pint glass.

A: Quite dark with a fairly dark head, and a little bit of lacing.

S: Dark malts and a little bit of milk and coffee.

T: Again, dark malt and some coffee with the typical milk flavor.

M: Nice and creamy, yet at the same time dry. I¬ím intrigued.

D: This is a slow sipper. However, it¬ís not terribly thick and might be nicer once the heavier stout season has passed.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-23-2009

Absolutely opaque black in color. A simple dark tan head holds for several minutes and then drops to a thin surface covering and very nice collar. The aroma reveals licorice, sweet milk chocolate, creamy coffee, mild buttery biscuit, and a touch of raisin. Roasty. An interesting fruity tasty up front becoming quickly mildly sweet and creamy like a rich sour cream. The bitterness deepens as the beer warms and breathes on the palate. There is a touch of alcohol but it burns off quickly leaving a dry finish that¬ís loaded with lingering bitterness, dry coffee-like roastiness, and a light touch of mildy tart dark fruitiness. The body is medium. The texture is softly fluffy as the beer seems to expand on the palate. Oily on the finish. Drinkability is high, because this beer invites you back with the promise of another intriguing sip. One of the best I¬íve had. A very nice stout.

This is the rare stout that I prefer slightly chilled over cellar temp.  At cellar temp, it is a bit harsh in the finish, but chilled it makes me think of oreo milkshakes; a dust of cocoa, a bit of sweet cream, and a bit of crispy wafers. There¬ís a delicate touch of smoke that I also like quite a bit.

Sweet, smooth, and a bit sour, this stout is meant for indulgence. Goes down like smooth chocolate milk with a chaser of light carbonation. Very nice stout that would pair nicely with some chocolate or vanilla ice cream- float time?

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours like motor oil. Thick and pitch black. One finger mocha color head.

On the nose, im getting chocolate, coffee beans, and roasted malts.

The taste is very nice! Bittersweet dark chocolate and roasted malts. Light hops and coffee bitterness on the finish. Lingers for a second or 2.

Thick mouth feel. Reminiscent of a milk creaminess.

A very nice beer to sip on and savor. The thickness makes it kinda of weird to down one after another.

awsome! It¬ís everything the bottle stated. Special...check. Double...check. Cream....check. Stout....check! Lots of burnt goodness. Nose has a rugged aroma of burnt malts, humidor at a fine cigar shop, coupled with wet oak, and a rounded end of vanilla extract. Taste is full, bodied and a meal in itself. Oatmeal, bitters, vanilla, earth tones with some vanilla and licorice. anyone else pick out the hazelnut at the end? Loved that!

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2010 Pours dark black into snifter.  Nice tan/cola head that sicks around, with decent lacing...very thick/creamy/rich looking.  About the way this beer feels on the tongue.  Aroma is malt, with just a touch of licorice?  Tons of flavor, burnt malt, coffee, chocolate, vanilla...just delightful.  Very nice beer.

Bottle, pours just short of motor oil-black, sizeable tan head. Nose is all chocolate, coffee, tinge of smoke, firewood and vanilla. Exceptionally smooth taste: goes down like a cross between an oatmeal and a milk stout. Finishes clean. I could drink this all night. I think I will.

Bottle poured a clear dark brown with a lingering brown head. Aromas of dark chocolate, roastiness, coffee anbd a hint of vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of dark chocolate, roastiness, vanilla and light coffee with a smooth lingering roasty finish.
UPDATED: FEB 26, 2011 On tap at Zeno¬ís.  Black with thin tan head.  Aroma is milk chocolate.  Flavor is chocolate, coffee and cream.  Delicious.
Good taste, chocolatey, a little simplistic, not enough mouth-feel slightly watery in this department... overall good and a stout that is very drinkable for multiple bottles

Chocolate and charcoal aroma. Black, with a medium tan head, good lace. Charcoal flavor, dry, ashy and smoky. Finishes with bitter chocolate. Nice texture and medium body, flavorful. Dry for the style, but not overly so.

Pours black with a quick brown head with decent lacing. Nose is coffee with a little dairy sweetness and generic malt. Flavor is similar and well balanced, not too different from a good cup of coffee with cream and sugar. Finish is bittersweet and long. Not quite as sweet as I expect from a cream stout but still very good.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2010 Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a nonic pint glass. Bottled on September 14, 2010 per dating code on label.

Appearance: Pours motor oil black with a 1-2 finger creamy tan head. Nice lacing.

Smell: Coffee, bittersweet chocolate and roasted malt. Aroma is a little milder than I would have liked.

Taste: Coffee up front followed by creamy sweetness and bittersweet chocolate in the middle and ending with roasted malt and a mild hoppy bitterness at the finish. Aftertaste is burnt toast.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a decent amount of carbonation. Pretty creamy.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. You could knock back a couple on a cold winter¬ís evening.

Overall: Good beer overall. Not my favorite stout but it¬ís worth a try.

Bell¬ís Special Double Cream Stout - 6.1%
Had at Lititz cask ale festival 10/29/10
Soft black with small creamy tan head.  Roasted coffee aroma, earthy.  Extremly smooth and quite dry.  Not a lot of carbonation.  Tasty is creamy milk chocolate with a hint of coffee.  Silky mouthfeel, I could drink a few of these if I didn¬ít have anything to eat.
Exceptional cream stout, well done.

On tap at the Brick Store Pub. Pours pitch black with a medium, brown head that leaves tons of lacing. The aroma is light coffee and chocolate, milk and caramel. The flavor is very sweet, with a background of cocoa bitterness. It¬ís smooth and silky. Overall a tasty and mellow stout.

Malty chocolate aroma.  Pours very dark brown.  Big head, lots of lacing.  Roasty, chocolate, slight coffee taste with a very slight bitterness that sticks around in the aftertaste.  More carbonation that other stouts, which I enjoy.  Very good in my book.

Mmmm.  Pours a deep dark brown, with a well carbonated head.  Smells sweet and a bit chocolaty.  Tastes of fresh cream, sweet malts and a very well balanced character of coffee , with a creamy mouthfeel.  Bell¬ís is still in my top 10 favorite breweries and for good reason.

Bottle; Pours a very dark brown/black, with a nice beige head with nice retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet chocolate, vegetables, lactose; medium bodied, a bit bitter as well, and there is that lactose sugar again. Coffee, Chocolate, lactose sugars - very nice brew!

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2016 I picked this up at Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL, enjoyed at home watching some playoff baseball.  It was a hard day getting my flu shot, and this uber-sweet brew is delicious right about now.  Appearance is pure black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is faint but consists of chocolate and lactose.  Taste is super creamy and smooth, rich in chocolate and coffee, also great roasted malt undertones.  I think I¬ím ready for dessert!  Re-rate 10/06/16 after new packaging.  Updating rating because it¬ís an exceptional stout.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2014 yet another stand-out stout from bells.  pours dark brown, almost black - with an everlasting tight tan head.  aroma of malted chocolate and coffee.  feel is super smooth and creamy.  lactic quality in addition to the chocolate coffee flavor gives it an ever so slight sour finish, which is the only thing preventing this very good brew from being a world beater.  still one of the best cream stouts out there.

aroma- dark rich chocolate, heavy cream, alcohol, toffee, coffee.  pours black with brown/cream head.  taste is cream, coffee, dark chocolate, some sugar, slight bitterness in the finish.  palate is slightly acidic and slick.  body is light with little carbonation.
This is a nice heavy beer that was sweet and good on the palate. Nice color and a good lacing after each sip. Good beer.

12oz btl. Pours a medium to thick bodied, dark with a hint of burgundy undereath. Nice coffee malt aroma. Love the taste, I¬íve been drinking a lot of high gravity stouts lately and this is a refreshing change of pace at 6.1 percent. Sweet cocoa start then a pleasant balanced bitterness into a roasted coffee finish. Great easy going stout.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark walnut with a fairly large, creamy, frothy, sticky, light khaki head. Decent retention with a nice creamy layer of lace.

S - Plenty of roasted malt with a lot of coffee and vanilla aromas. Also a fair amount of bittersweet chocolate. Some creamy lactose aroma as well. Maybe a touch of licorice and cinnamon/nutmeg spice as well. Dominated by a nice coffee, vanilla, and cream aroma.

T - Similar to the nose with strong coffee, vanilla, and cream/lactose flavors being the strongest flavors. Some roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate comes out as well. A bit of an earthy flavor mid sip as well. Hints of spice in the background, but not a lot. A little bitter, especially for a sweet stout.

M - Medium body with a good level of carbonation. Pretty smooth, and a little thin.

D - Not too sweet for a Milk Stout and a nice balance. Enjoy the coffee, vanilla, cream mix, although it could be a bit much after maybe two in the night.

Notes: A nice Sweet Stout with a nice mix of flavors. Just a hint of bitterness keeps the sweetness in check. A little on the thin side, and I probably wouldn¬ít want to drink a number of these in a night, but it was definitely a nice treat.

Bottle. Pours a nice black with a generous mocha head. Was expecting this to be very malty, creamy, thick beer. Instead it was very sour and roasty-bitter. It took some getting used to, but I came around to it. Nice, complex malts and a great bitter finish.

Tap @ HopCat for RBSG¬í10 - dark pour with tan head. vineou, roasty chocolate goodness. Not finding the body especially creamy, however. Hops stick to the tongue. Molasses with plenty of carbonic tartness. Mixed feelings about this one.

Bottle pours deep brown/black with a dirty khaki head.  Aroma is chocolate, caramel, coffee, and roast malt.  Flavor show the same with some additional dark fruit.  It starts with a juicy, yet sour dark fruit, that is quickly followed up with a creamy midpalate, and a light to moderate bitter roast finish.
On tap at HopCat while in town for RBSG.  Pours a deep black with a medium to thick beige head.  Soft toffee, coffee and roast.  Smooth and creamy, light chocolate bitterness.

Appearance:  dark coffee, with a short tan creamy head that shrinks to a baby collar with nice lacing.  Aroma:  toffee, dark bittersweet chocolate.  Taste:  rich bittersweet chocolate, hint of coffee, lightly dry.  Finish:  surprisingly short and clean, crisp and sweet, and a little bit dry.  Notes:  Wow, great beer.  Very rich, very complex; like an unsweet dessert.  Amazingly full-bodied.  Winter can¬ít come again fast enough.  I was foolish enough to only buy a single bottle.  Next time I find this bad boy, I¬ím going to get a case to last me for the whole year.  This is a year-round kind of stout.

Bottle thanks to Punkrkr27. Batch 8902...Black with a light brown head... Aroma is very light, can¬ít really pick out any one note...Flavor is light roast, slightly sweet with maybe a little caramel at the end...Super easy drinker.
UPDATED: APR 4, 2016 I am not in love with it but this is a rather good stout. A hint of red in the color.  Rather creamy.  Well done Bell¬ís.  Serving: Bottle

This beer looks like oil as you pour it into the glass. Of course, this is not a bad thing. Quite the contrary, actually. I find that if you can see through your stout, you are not going to enjoy said stout because it is going to fucking gross, but I digress. This beer has a delicious aroma, taste, and palate of chocolate and coffee. All the essentials. It is one of the smoothest stouts I have found and would love to have another go with this magnificent creation. If I could fuck this beer, you better believe I would.

I remember trying this one before and couldn¬ít figure why this brew had such high reviews.  I decided to give it another try, with the same results.  There is a lot of complexity to this beer but the finish completely threw me off.  A sour metallic taste is about the best way I can put it.  A different finish would have sent this one into the 4+ rating for sure.
Bottle pours a jet black beer with a thin dark brown head. Scent is sweet malts with coffee and chocolate. Taste is sweet with coffee and a tangy sour finish

Bottle thanks to secret Santa. Pours black with small tan head. Nose is milk, lightly toasted malts and creamer. Taste is very smooth cream, chocolate and lightly roasted malts. Very satisfying stout.
Very interesting aroma and taste, reminiscent of molasses cookies.  A very smooth and satisfying finish.
12oz bottle. Pours jet black with minimal head. Aroma is of dark choco malts. Mouthfeel is smooth with moderate carbo. Taste is of dark malts, chocolate and maybe a bit of patent. Decent stout.

Draft @ Taco Mac in Kennesaw awhile back.  Poured black with no substantial head to speak of.  Aroma was of some sweetened roasted malts.  Drinks super smooth with an awesome creamy mouthfeel, kinda reminded me of A Guinness like consistency.  A really nice smooth and creamy stout.

12oz bottle thanks to dukefan.  Poured a dark brown body with a fizzy tan head with reddish highlights and nice legs.  Aroma is cream, roasty, some alcohol showing through(?) and lightly sweet.  Flavor is roasty, fresh coffee, creamy and a very smooth bitter (coffee) finish.  Medium mouthfeel with active carbonation.

(12 oz bottle). Pours black with red hue and explosive caramel head that cascades a bit-pillowy on top.  Aroma of roasted coffee beans, dark chocolate, some caramel (sweetness). Brilliant!  Taste is sweet/sour balance with a dry roasted after taste.  Medium bodied with creamy texture.  Carbonation is low and the finish is bitter and becomes more prominent as you keep drinking. This is a wonderful beer.  It has the perfect mix of sweet and dryness-many stouts emphasize the dryness which is not to my liking.  Well done again!

Dark dark brown, basically black, milk chocolate tan foam.  Oatmealy aroma, chocolate, creamy milk chocolate, coffee, light roast.  Taste is roast, big creamy body, oatmeal, chocolate, coffee, very nice.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a blood red hue.  Head was fluffy tan at first and disapated quickly.  Smells of coffee and dark chocolate.  Tastes of simple syrup at first, then fades to a rich cappucccino, dark chocolate, and a little smokey.  Residual sweeness is almost fruity.  Body is way thin for this style, but flavor is very nice.

A: Pours a deep brown with beige lacing.

S: Smells very sugary like molasses with some chocolate notes

T: Heavy dark chocolate with a strong malty profile.

P: A bit sticky with too much carbonation.

Pours jet black with a creamy dark brown head. Strong aromas of sweet dark malt. Creamy dark chocolate with hints of coffee.

There¬ís some alcohol evident in the flavor but lots of creamy dark malt underpinned with the earthy dark chocolate and roasted coffee. An incredibly smooth mouth. Downright velvety. The roasted coffee flavors linger in the finish and aftertaste.

A little bit of everything in this one but it is still undoubtedly a cream stout. Very nice and very drinkable.

"Brewed with a blend of 10 malts, Double Cream is an incredibly rich stout composed of dark, sweet and smooth tones intermingled with a soft, toasty finish" - so sayth the bottle
Ahh, Bell¬ís, so many good beers, here¬ís to hoping this one is good as well.Poured from a bottle (batch 9357) into my favorite tulip glass.
Dark brown almost black appearance with a thin tan head
Chocolate, sweetness, slight soft cofee notes
Bitterswet chocolate taste with a very smooth long finish with a slight bitterness. Chocolate coffee milk for grown ups!
Honestly, felt a little lighter in the mouth than expected. Would have liked a little heavier feel

12oz bottle from CBX. Pours a darker than black color with tan super bubbly head which evaporates quickly. Nice sweet smell of chocolate and roasty goodness. Very crisp and refreshing taste. I get a bit of burnt toast, with a good bit of sweet creaminess and light finish. Very refreshing.

aroma is organic top soil, deep and rich, plenty of java and strong scents of chocolate as well.  so well rounded!  appearance is dead opaque with wisps of head and tiny ring of lacing, minor carb.  flavor is hint of cola and this mornings coffee at 3pm.  juicy, crunchy chocolate follows and satisfies.  sweet indeed, but none to my dismay.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James and Tony. Pours a deep, thick brown-amber with a tall, quickly diminishing amber head. Aroma of vanilla, cream, oats, milk, coffee, honey, toffee, caramel, tart cherry, figs, toasted malts, barley, and hints of maple. Firm, yet supple body with a soft, creamy, smooth palate. Outrageously delicious stout.
Had with James and pat. Pour is dark brown. Nice medium brown head. Laces. Aroma is filled with vanilla and caramel. Flavor is creamy vanilla and malts.
12 ounce bottle-dark pour-off white head-aroma and taste of chocolate, caramel, -super creamy smooth finish

Bottled. Black with a dark brown head that almost totally disappears. Aroma is sweet coffee and chocolate with hints at sourness. Flavor is sweet with notes of booze and coffee, but really kind of boring. Some sourness comes through roasty sour in the taste that gives a nice dry bite. Long and sweet lightly sticky finish.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is onyx with 3 fingers of sudsy brown head.  Nose is roasted malt and lactose.  Taste is roasted malt, cherries, dark fruit, and plums.  All this, from first taste to the end of the finish, is done in a lavishly creamy elegance.  I am not a fan of the astringent fruit cocktail that is going on in this brew, but the creamy malt is a wonderful touch!
Pours black with tan head fading to a strong lace. Good oak notes balance bittersweet chocolate. Strong velvet cream mouthfeel.

Bottle enjoyed with Andrew and ryguy. This was the best sweet stout I¬íve ever tried. Great aroma suggests some sort of bastard child of a Porter and sour ale. The taste is similar wig a nice medium, well carbonated mouthfeel and notes of light roast, cherry, and sour.
Bottle in Philly.  Tastes of dark swert cocoa porter and sour ale. Cherries and sourness present... Coupled with deep malty base

Had this on-tap at bocktown

A- Body is a thick, deep, dark brown hue. Is served with a wonderful 1/2 finger cream colored head that eventually fades to a thin collar and leaves little lacing behind in the glass.

S- Roasted malt, vanilla, cream, coffee, and a hint of chocolate. The slightest presence of phenols as well.

T- The flavor is more typical imperial stout than imperial milk stout. Roasted coffee flavors come through first along with a smooth creamy sweetness. The finish is pretty much all roasted malt-but this doesn¬ít get overpowering or intense in any way. A minimal roasted malt bitterness lingers on the palate.

P- Low to medium carbonation and a pretty smooth and creamy mouthfeel. The feel is great-but for the style it is a but hindered by a slight phenolic presence.

O- This is a good milk stout. Certainly a much better imperial cream stout than creme brulee. Its good-but not as good as sessionable beers of the same character. I still do like this one and will have it again.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 03-21-2009 02:17:07
--

Tried this courtesy of Tim at a tasting at his house in Dallas. Aroma is of coffee, raisins and dark cocoa. Deep brown in color with a light tan head and delicate lacing. Tastes of raisin with a touch of cocoa. A little more bitter than expected with lots of carbonation.

Bottle (from Cracked Kettle). Very deep ambery brown colour (close to black), with a small beigeish brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, caramel malts, some slight wooden notes as well as mild liquorice and chocolate. Flavour is roasted malts, some sweet malts, mild syrupy sweetness as well as some wood, vanilla and liquorice as well. Quite tasty beer.

Dark Pour. High head. Roasty, caramel, slight bready aroma. Medium body, would have preferred more body. Roasty, chocolate, coffee, faint burnt with a smooth and creamy texture from the lactose sugars. Very tasty beer. Highly recommended for stout lovers.

Thanks to savvy1982 for the bottle. Pours black with cola coloured highlights. The head is large and laces well. The aroma is sweet, fruity, and roasty. Red licorice, chocolate, coffee, berries, soft fruit, and plums on the nose. The flavor has coffee, milk and dark chocolate, black and red licorice, banana, bread, cream, plum, and spice. Soft mouth feel. Very nice.
Dark ruby brown beneath a medium khaki head. Rich aroma of roast, sweet caramels and toffee. A nice blend of milky sweetness, caramel, and roasted barley with just a hint of coffee.

Nice roastiness in the nose.  Little foam to note, just a small edge lace.  I¬ím drinking this almost 15 mos after bottling based on bell¬ís batch numbers.  A nice mouthfeel just coats evenly and smoothly.  Taste is nice and light chocolatey with solid malt.  Would be interested in a fresh bottle to compare.

Stuff looks fantastic, dark with tan head, pours nice and smooth.  Tons of coffee in the nose.  Taste is coffee and cream, but be sure to let it warm up a good bit to get all the flavors.  Nice bit of hops up front as well, which I really like in a stout.  Great beer.

Aroma is of strong coffee with cream in it.  Besides the temp, I¬ím not sure I could have told the difference.  Appearance is jet black with a medium tan head.  Taste is of coffee, chocolate, and some hops.

Pours a pitch black with a tan head.  aroma is of roasted malts, milk chocolate, and some coffee notes.  flavor is of roasted malts, sweet creamy mily chocolate, some coffee, and some hops.  has a light body for a stout with the a super creamy mouthfeel and a smooth, sweet finnish.  overall, a excellent creamy, smooth, and tasty sweet stout.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2011 received in trade from foppa78 (along with Founders BS).  this is like a toned down version of Founders - and that isn¬ít bad...

5/5 for palate mouthfeel; extremely creamy and full.

ending was subdued - no bitterness, some carbonation, slight alcohol.
will re rate with second...

re rate 03/11 - bumped up a few more points- sold and a great creamy smooth finish!!
A dark brown pour with tan head.  It has a sweet aroma of chocolate and caramel.  The taste is thick and sweet with a creamy body and roasted finish.

Typical opaque brown/black color for a good stout.
Not as robust flavor as some of the premier stouts, say medium sweet, I liked it.
A quick fizz for a stout, but not too distracting.  finishes smooth.

Bottle.  Pours nearly black, with no light or other highlights, with a medium tan head that doesn¬ít linger but leaves lots of lacing.  Aroma is sweet malt, creamy, some chocolate.  Flavor is milk and bitter dark chocolate, roasty malt, quite a bit of sweetness.  Rich and tasty but drinkable.  Palate is creamy but not too heavy.  Another awesome stout from Bell¬ís

Poured a very dark brown (very close to black) with a small brown head that didn¬ít stay very long. Aroma: sweet, roasted malts, dark chocolate and cream. Taste had those same elements but also some milk chocolate and espresso. Aftertaste: roasted malts and a mild bitterness. Nice body, not heavy as I thought it would be. Overall a good cream stout.
Great. Very full bodied, but not heavy or syrupy. Lots of roasted malt and cream. Some lightly bitter chocolate. Lightly bitter throughout. Lasting dry finish.

A black beer with a good 1 finger head. The aroma is sweet, chocolate, and some roast. The taste is like sweet roasted cream. It is creamy, chocolate, some roast bitterness & I can see why it is called double cream. This has some sweet to it but by all means it is not that sweet. Just a nice smooth stout.
One of the best Cream Stout I have ever had. Very complex malt characteristics, mouthfeel was rich, and strong nose make it all around a winner!

One of my favorite things about drinking beer is the moments when I try a sweet stout to top off a good dinner. A beer like Bell¬ís Special Double Cream Stout can sometimes be even more satisfying than a piece of chocolate cake because it¬ís much more complex. While I wouldn¬ít call this a chocolate stout per se, it definitely is one of the sweetest, creamiest stouts I¬íve encountered. It¬ís also surprisingly lighter in body than you¬íd expect which makes it highly drinkable and, I think, accessible to beer drinkers of all experience levels.APPEARANCE AND AROMAI poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. I was surprised to see this beer was a dark shade of completely opaque black (no ruby red highlights at all). It formed a thick, creamy, brown head which lasted throughout the life of the drink and left some decent lacing on the glass.The aroma was surprisingly mild, although it did live up to its name as the most noticeable scent was indeed cream. There were faint hints of milk chocolate, but otherwise the nose was rather quiet.TASTEI went into Bell¬ís Special Double Cream Stout with a bit of an expectation, but was a little surprised by what I actually got. The thick creamy head was quite roasty-tasting, while the beer itself was very sweet not unlike a cola. In fact, it¬ís so sweet it actually dried out my mouth and had me craving for a sip of milk or water between each swig. What¬ís weird is the beer is actually not quite as rich or intense as it may sound. There is a distinct cream and milk-like combination of flavors going on, but the overall palette is rather reserved. There is mild roasted malt flavors in the mouth, although they seem to gain strength in the aftertaste. There is only faint bitterness which I would attribute to subtle notes of chocolate.DRINKABILITYThis brew is more reminiscent of an Irish Dry Stout with a sweeter body than a traditional milk stout. It¬ís actually quite light in body, but not watery like a Guinness Draught. Still, the mouthfeel itself is velvety and smooth and the aftertaste is strong and pleasing. At 6.1% ABV Bell¬ís Special Double Cream Stout is the type of beer I¬íd rather drink on non-special occasions and probably in greater quantities than any kind of imperial stout. I think almost anyone would find this very drinkable since it¬ís not too intense and goes down so easily. FINAL THOUGHTSSpecial Double Cream Stout is, at the very least, a solid performer. It has everything I look for in a good beer and I think it¬ís the type that would appeal to pretty much anyone. I¬íd be surprised if it didn¬ít.NOTE: I cannot comment on the price of this beer since it is not available where I live and was a gift from a friend from Michigan. However, I¬íd say upwards of $13 for a six-pack would be a good value.
Black pour with small creamy head.  Dark chocolate, roast, vanilla and wood in the aroma.  Smooth and flavorful.  Nice.
this beer has a great flavor and color.  A little chocolate flavor, and a very nice taste on the palate.
On tap at Ashley¬ís Westland.  Bell¬ís is the best.  This is a very smooth creamy/chocolatey/coffee stout.  Somewhat lower rating due to poor finish.

Can Bell¬ís make a stout or what?  Reminds me a bit a very toned down version of the Brooklyn Black Chocolate Stout.  Nose of black licorice.  Plenty of lacing.  Not surprisingly, a very creamy, smooth stout with a toned down bitterness that only becomes apparent after an initial sweetness.  Flavor of chocolate malt and a bit of coffee.  Outstanding beer from one of the best craft brewers out there.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Norm¬ís, 2/26/10 


Aroma: Roasted malts/coffee, some chocolate, and earthy notes

Appearance: Pours a dark brown color with a small brown head, some light sheets of lace

Flavor: Tastes is mild sweetness, smooth malty flavor, minimal bitterness

Palate: Quite smooth and creamy beer, medium bodied, soft carbonation

Overall Impression: 
This one is pretty solid.  I enjoyed the smooth and creamy feel it has to it, but I think I like creamy beers a little more then most do.  This is some good stuff, another very solid beer from Bells.

From a trade with Smith4489.  The aroma is very sweet, cream, chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar, some spicyness. The pour is deep brown/black,  decent tan head, slightly oily on the glass.  The flavor is creamy chocolate, light coffee, brown sugar - sweet, lightly roasty, very enjoyable.  The finish is suddenly roasty, maybe slight hop bittering.  The mouthfeel is very creamy, the body is medium to med/thick, not as thick in body as i would have thought.  Excellent beer, however.  Thanks, Jason.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2010 Bottle. Pours dark brown with a thin light brown head. Sparse lacing. Smells of coffee, nuts and malt. Nice medium bodied palate; but I expected more. A little short and bitter on the finish. A decent stout.
33 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Deep black colour, uneven creamy head. Very smooth, velvety, with balanced roasted malt and long lasting bitterness.

Bottle sample at work... gosh, just didn¬ít like this as much as I was expecting.  A good stout in all regards, but I was expecting a little bit more from this beer.
  Nose is quite good, vanilla, caramel, some bready character that incorperates some spice, perhaps ginger.
  The palate was a bit lacking in body, and the bitter finish didn¬ít really play off as much of a malty body as I would have expected.  I suppose I may have given it a higher score 3.6 - 3.7 if not for the description of "Double Cream."
  This implied... well, something I couldn¬ít find.  Not sure if I was expection lactose sugar (though I know this isn¬ít the cream being implied) or more of a sweet malty body in the middle.  But IMO, it was missing something... None-the-less a well put together stout, one worth trying... but it just didn¬ít do it for me.

12 oz bottle from Princeton¬ís.  Deep brown, almost black pour with a velvety tan head.  Milk chocolate aroma, silky creamy mouthfeel with a roasted chocolate flavor.  Finish is a slightly bitter chocolate.

A: The pour is just about black. Very little highlights, if any, that I can see. A nice tan/mocha colored head perches itself on top.

S: The nose is full of roasted malt and sweet milk chocolate.

T: A very interesting flavor profile. A light roasted malt flavor with a very sweet finish. There is quite a bit of chocolate coupled with a mild bitterness.

M: A very creamy, smooth mouthfeel. The body is medium, and there¬ís a moderate level of carbonation.

D: The Milk/Sweet stout is a style that¬ís beginning to grow on me. Generally I am more of an RIS fan, but the sweetness is quite a welcomed change of pace. A great beer, and I¬ím glad I have another.

Pours a rich brown, almost black with a thin tan head. Nice aroma of sweet chocolate and light roasted malts. Tastes quite sweet with chocolate, malt, and some coffee and smoke flavors with very little bitterness and a sweet finish. Medium bodied with low to medium carbonation. Not bad.

Bottle. A super-solid beer. Pours a dark brown with a fluffy tan head. Nose of bitter chocolate and roasted malts. Flavor was lightly sweet with considerable bitter, burnt malt character. Very rich, big-bodied and smooth. Some mild hop bitterness in the aftertaste. Awesome.

12oz bottle, batch 9513 bottled Dec 18, 2009.  Pours very dark brown, black, medium body, large foamy light brown head that retains well and leaves rings of lacing.  Aroma is pretty potent, chocolate, coffee, smoke, roasted malts, and a lactic quality  Almost like cream cheese frosted chocolate cake.  Hmmmm...and maybe some chocolate chip cookies, too.  Interesting and unique.  Flavor is more coffee up front, some chocolate, roasted malts, and lactose.  A bit watery.  Bittersweet finish.  OK.  Mouthfeel is pretty full, yet still a tad thin, medium carbonation.  The aroma > flavor in this one for me.  If it tasted like it smelled, it would be an easy 4+.  As it is, I prefer Bells Kalamazoo stout, which is also cheaper than this Double Cream stout.

Pours black with a hint of brown a the edges.  Tan head disappated quickly.  Big cocoa/bittersweet chocolate nose.  Sweet chocolate malt flavor up front but finishes dry and roasty and finishes clean.  Big rich mouthfeel, slightly prickly on the tongue.  Another solid brew by Bell¬ís.
Deep black with fluffy cocoa head. A real chocolate note on the nose. Roasty flavor and a bit of astringency. Mellows to not much of a finish. Nice.

Pours a very dark brown to near black that allows some light to pass. Head is light tan, and the nose has a caramel-cream sweet aroma to it. Roasty flavors are noted up front on the palate as it moves towards some general malt sweetness, some traits from the milk components, and a sweet to somewhat tart finish.
Pours thick, thick black.  Not much head.  Flavor is sweet, malty.  A very rich beer.  Enjoyable, but one is enough.

Here¬ís a nice beer.  It¬ís black with some very dark brown highlights.  There¬ís very little head even when I aggressively pour the beer into the glass.  I smell vanilla, chocolate, and some other nondescript malty things.  Tree bark.  There.  Tell me you smell it, too.  The taste is nice.  Lots of roasty things and chocolate.  There¬ís not much coffee flavor to it but there is a sprinkle in there.  Goes down smooth.  I¬íd say it has a medium body to it.  Finishes quick at first then a sudden burst of flavor.  Like a second wind.  I don¬ít know.. forget the chocolate dessert to go with it.  I think this stands fine on its own as a dessert.  Good stuff.

Bottle, pours a dark brown body with a tan head.  Nice aroma of dusty sweet malts.  Palate is fluffy and light and way way WAY too drinkable.  The flavors are of dark sweet malts, some light cocoa, and maybe a hint of toffee or hard caramel.  I found the flavors to be on the sweet side as the beer finishes somewhat tangy or tacky from a lack of bitterness.  Very delicious indeed.

12oz bottle. deep dark pour with a generous tan head. big dark chocolate aroma. taste is silky smooth to the tongue, sweet chocolate with a light roast finish. creamy is a very apt description. wish i had a little chocolate cake to enjoy this with.

Pours black into the glass with a brownish head.  Aroma is beautiful chocolate and roasted malt.  Flavor is rich with chocolate, nuttiness, and some roast along with a bit of hops coming through.  Really velvety palate on this terrific brew

12  oz. bottle poured into snifter. Aroma thick creamy hints of chocolate and cream. Appearance was dark black nice thin head and minimal lacing bit watery. Taste is sweet and subtle chocolate cream bitterness and finishes a bit dry. Palate feelsmedium, thin with creamy tectures. I will have to drink again not bad at all.

Bottle. Pours a suitably viscous black, with an odd two-tone head, pale tan for the first 1/2 inch, then dark tan for the latter 1/2 inch. Nice lacing. Nose is definitely creamy, smells like whole milk, tight roastiness, chocolate. Mouth is rich and chocolatey, nice roast throughout, light on the coffee, the sweetness and choco-vanilla notes remind me of Aphrodisiaque, but not quite so over-the-top. I¬ím warming up to this beer more and more as I drink it. This would easily be my favorite session stout if, as I said, I didn¬ít have to drive to North Dakota to get it.
pours a deep brown with a light brown head aroma is chocolate lactic cream malt and roasted barley taste is the same with a creamy mouthdeel.

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  All right, out of the gate, I just have to say that for such a nice beer, people aren¬ít putting any effort into the ratings.  This beauty pours a really dark brown, almost black, with a small tan head that leaves some really cool lacing behind.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, earthy hops, dark fruits, coffee, a little smoke, vanilla, and molasses.  Flavor of chocolate, fudge, vanilla, earthy hops, berries, grass, sweet roasted malts, metal, and cola.  Medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a mouthfeel that¬ís hard to characterize- maybe sweet roasted cherry juice.  That doesn¬ít make any sense.  Anyway, this is a really nice sweet stout, and I¬ím starting to wonder if I mix this and Expedition Stout if I will get the highly sought-after beer with such high ratings.  Maybe.  Expedition Stout is better by itself.  I¬ím going to see what equal parts will do...

Black with a big frothy brown head. Good lacing. A wonderful chocolate and roasted malts aroma. Medium to heavy body, has a nice chocolaty, vanilla, creamy taste with a light to medium bitter finsh. One of the best stouts I¬íve had in a long time and at a very reasonable price.
pours black with a thin head. Aroma is insane malt! Coffee! Chocolate! Bacon! Wow! Rich and malty, coffee, caramel, coffee smoke,  this is one great stout soo creamy, this is one hell of a stout!
pours black with no real head. aroma is sweet with malts and chocolate abundant. drinks smooth and creamy with roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, molasses, and sweetness.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2010 Aroma is creamy and almost sweat with hints of molasses and coffee as well as a sour note. Appearance is very thick reddish black with zero transparency. Flavor is full and rich with mild coffee. All of it is evened out by a very smooth creamy flavor (and texture). Finish is slightly sweat and coffee with no bitterness. Overall I would buy this beer again and again. It makes me happy that I live in Michigan where this is brewed.

(12 ounce bottle - pint glass)  Pours a opaque black brown color that has a tan head.  Aroma is of roasted chocolate malts.  Taste has a roasty, nutty, coffee, chocolate malt taste.  Also has notes of vanilla and wood.  Texture is creamy, soft carbonation and thick bodied.

Pours dark brown to black with a khaki head. The aroma is awesome, smells like a mochaccino along with some roasted malt. The flavor is very creamy with coffee and roasted malts. The aftertaste is dominated by the coffee and you get some good bitterness from that. The mouthfeel is thick and creamy. Low carbonation.

Bottle. Poured a jet black color with a creamy tan head. Aroma was roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate. Flavor was amazing. Strong coffee flavors, very sweet. Chocolate, rich and complex. Finish was kinda nutty with burnt notes. Full body. Very sticky and oily texture. Very good beer from a great brewery.

Pours a deep chestnut tinged with auburn and a thick peaty head purple around the edges, aroma is heavy roasted nuts w/ some alcohol, medium to full bodied with creamu nutty nose and moderate bitterness on finish
Black in color although brown towards the edges. Smells like charred firewood, wonderful coffee aromas, breakfast blend. Tastes great. Nice palate. A bit sweet with a lingering finish.
In the bottle thanks to hurrisnow. Black with a creamy thick off white head. Smooth body with a silky chocholate flavor. Carob flavors. Great stout.

On tap @ Sergios World Beers. Pours opaque black with a tall tan head. Roast aroma with some toasty notes in the aroma. Full-bodied mouthfeel, rich roasty, malty, chocolately flavors with an underlying sweetness. Long finish of all those flavors. One not to pass up.

Pours out black with a small tan head. Aroma is slightly sweet, with notes of coffee, chocolate and vanilla. Taste is similar to the aroma, chocolate with a creamy vanilla taste also present. Pretty damn good.

Batch #9376 bottled September 30, 2009. Poured a very dark brown, almost black with a hint of orange highlights around the edge of the glass. There was a tall creamy light brown head that gave some nice lacing. The aroma was mild, with scents of sweet chocolate and coffee. The texture of the beer was not creamy to me, but more of a thin dry stout. There was a mild coffee flavor and some chocolate. It ended with a dry finish with a mellow bitterness. I prefer the Kalamazoo Stout and think it is sweeter and smoother than this. This is still a nice beer.

Pours a jet black hue with a guinness-like tan thick head and light lacing on the glass. Nose is chocolate, coffee, roasty with faint hints of anise and dark fruits. Flavor is full-on chocolate-forward malts with big roastiness and backing tones of coffee, slight esters and anise in the semi-sweet and bitter finish. Full body, smooth creamy texture, mild carbonation. A smooth and easy drinking stout that excels in texture and sweet malt profile, an easy and flavorful drinker through and through!

12 oz bottle. Interested by the ratebeer description of being sweeter and smoother than the Kalamazoo stout. Pours an opaque black with a small tan head. Smells of sugary chocolate, a hint of roasted coffee, and cream. The taste is light chocolate, a hint of coffee in the backbone, some sugar, and creamy-ness. Very smooth going down, but not much character to it. Not bad, but I think I prefer Kalamazoo stout over it, and greatly appreciate Expedition stout as far as Bells¬í stouts are concerned.

12 oz. Extra from BeerBaron 420.  Nice creamy stout.  Dark black tan ring yadda yadda yadda.  Taste is oats and dark fruit.  Not overly rich or thick.  Rather light in the mouth for such a  formitable looking brew.  Coffee and cocoa are there.
This beer pours a black tan head with some really nice lacing. Smel of coffee, chocolate, carmael, and smoke. Flavor is caramel, chocolate, coffee with a nutty finish. A very good beer.

Pours a deep black color with a very thin short lived head. Aroma is roast milk chocolate. Very clean aroma. Flavor is a little sweet, some milk chocolate with just a tinge of acrid roast on the backend. Very drinkable. Tast beer.

(br-btl pu-lbl, 6-pack, 6.1%, 10 malts)

opq-bk, thin-br-hd, too^co2.

roasty chclt ¬ßleafy(silage) aroma.

astrngt Ts, dark-malt ¬ßlcrc T1, ^chclt roasty ^co2 ¬ßastrngt T2, roasty ¬ßchrcl T3, chrcl ¬ßcloying-lcrc-swallow Tf.

Bottle. Double Cream Stout? More like Double Head Stout. Huge foamy tan head sits atop a nice dark body. Nose is full of coffee and chocolate - all malt. Tons of chocolate and roasty flavor in this one. Fairly sweet, very smooth, very drinkable. This beer fits the milk stout style to a tee, and it¬ís a very well-made example.

Pours black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is of caramel, toffee, and a hint of coffee.  Nice thick body.  Excellent sweet flavor of caramel, and roasted malt with a little bit of chocolate.  This is a great beer, and one I will definitely buy again.

Thanks again to Adrian!  Sweet, coffee aroma.  Fairly astringent coffee flavor, with a bit of citrus and smoky malt tones.  This may have 10 kinds of malt, but there is not much double or cream going on here.   For a sweet stout, it is not that sweet - fairly close to a porter.
12 oz Bottle -- Pours black with a moderate tan head.  Good amount of smoke present.  Very smooth and mellow mouth feel.

A: Pours jet black with a creamy one finger head. Not much carbonation and no lacing to be seen. 

S: Not very strong, rather mild to be honest. Picked up some milky chocolate and malt. Not much else. 

T: This is a rather mild beer. Has usual chocolate and coffee notes, but nothing really stands out here. 

M: Expected it to be a little more full bodied and creamy. It came off as medium, with little carbonation. I would call it dry in fact.
Bottle from DuffmanSW. Poured dark black with nice tan head. Aroma and taste was creamy roasty with mild chocolate notes and some smoke. Lower carbonation but very frothy. Overall pretty good.

Bottle from Beerlando. Wow this is a nice looking beer. Totally opaque dark brown, nice tan head.  Nose is roasty, slight leather and tobacco and loads of caramelly toffee and brulee¬íd marshamallow sweetness. Flavor is roasty malt and dark sweetness all the way through. Really enjoyable beer, if not the most complex thing on earth. I¬íve yet to have anything less than ¬íreally good¬í from Bell¬ís. Man, I wish we could get them in CO. Thanks, Bryan.

Poured from a 12 oz¬íer into a plastic Dixie cup. Not ideal, but these things happen. Nice tan head. Roasted malts dominate the aroma. Flavor is leather, raisins, dark and bitter chocolate. Nice bitter finish. Very smooth, heavy mouthfeel. A great one.

Aroma boozy coffee roasty. Lactose makes it sweet for sure, little sour bitter finish. Great smooth full body mouthfeel. Good middle and excellent finish the aroma and inital taste through it from above 4 for me. Would be a regular drinker for me if I could get it.
Aroma of coffee and milk chocolate. Appearance was brownish black with mocha head. Flavor of roasted coffee, milk chocolate and honey. Palate was bubbly. Decent.

Bottle from DuffmanSW.  Pours dark brown, almost black, with a beige ring of foam.  Aroma is mild coffee, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, and a touch of smoke.  Flavor is creamy chocolate and roasty coffee.  Palate is creamy with soft carbonation and a full, silky body.
Dark brown with medium head. Like a silky chocolate malt. Light sweet roast and mild bitterness. A little soy. Good round body, not too thin and still very drinkable.

Dark black pour with brown edges.  light beige filmy head.  Aroma is chalky chocolate and cream with a sweet biscuity malt character.  Flavor is again chalky and chocolatey with some hints of rum soaked lady fingers and milky coffee.  smooth and tastey.

Bottle, shared with 3 friends after a great Turkey dinner. Big chocolate aroma with alot of roasted scents on the nose. Great silky texture. I wish Bells had distribution here in So Cal, I have enjoyed everything I have tasted from them.

[12oz bottle] Dark thick and rich looking. Viscous with good carbonation which leaves a good bit of lacing on the glass. Strong roasted barley, a bit of smoke and bitter chocolate aroma. Some sweetness but well balanced and not overbearing and a bitter finish. Creamy and smooth but not as heavy on the palette as I would have thought. A decent beer but not overly complex.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours the expected jet black, with a light to medium-tan head.  The nose gives hints of roasted malt, dark chocolate, some residual sweetness, and perhaps a touch of unfermented lactose.  The palate is quite smooth and pleasing.  It lacks the sometimes abrasive roasted character and hop bitterness exhibited by other strong/sweet stouts of American origin, and instead features a lightly malty note up front, followed by a nice balancing bitterness, and a slightly sweet and almost milk chocolate-like character through the mid-palate to the finish.  Some residual sweetness fills out the beer¬ís body.  Overall, well done.

Smells like a dark version of ovaltine in milk with a tiny touch of black licorice in there.  Flavor is rich with light roast malts and rye or pumpernickel bread, finishing with a little coffee.  The cream in the name definitely comes in the aroma and taste more so than the body of the brew, I would call this light/medium bodied but that makes a few of these so easy to take down.  Nice easy going stout.  Thanks Bells.  2009 12 oz.

Bottle.  Deep black color with a thin layer of tan foam.  Aroma is earthy sweet coffee with deep roasted malt.  Taste is sweetened coffee with a roasted malt bitterness.   Creamy, full bodied palate with a smooth, tangy sweet finish.

Poured to a fluted fest glass at Brixie¬ís Holiday Beer Tasting. The color was a murky, black/brown, with modest, light tan foam to the head which reduced rather quickly to a ring and film, but left some clingy lacing. The aroma was definitely roasted, with "cream to my freshly poured coffee" scent. The flavor was similar with light sweetness, medium hop bitterness and smooth, balancing malt. The mouthfeel had a pleasant creaminess to it. Had been looking to try this for awhile,..very nice!

12 oz bottle. Stouts are one of my favorite styles, this beer is up there smooth and creamy pours a deep dark brown with a small tan head that quickly dissipates. Malty as can be with a wonderful blend hints of caramel chocolate and a wonderful beer smell. Long lasting on the pallet, a true winner for a chilly evening.
28th June 2008. 10 different malts! Very very smooth stout which is creamy. Very lightly toasted malt runs through the creamyness but there is no bitterness.
damn nice cream stout! both nose and taste have a lot of funcky, cheesy notes that work very nicely. it¬ís like a cottage cheese stout! lol!

Pours solid black with a creamy brown head. Aroma is chocltae, coffee, and vanilla. The body of the beer is thin but also full of wonderful flavor. Mocha, cocoa, caramel and rich roast are present flavors. Very nice beer.

Pours a black color with brown head.  Aroma is caramel, toast, chocolate, roast, cocoa, cream, a touch of some, and some earthy hops.  Flavor is creamy, chocolate, smoke, roast, toast, cocoa, and a bitter spicy finish.

Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Opaque black with thick light brown head and major lacing lines.

Rich roasted aroma, highlighting coffee, dark chocolate, and roasted barley, with semi-sweet undertones of molasses.

Starts off slightly sweet (molasses and dark fruit) but quickly becomes dominated by roasted flavors of bittersweet chocolate and coffee. The taste of cream is persistent throughout and then ends just slightly bitter.

Low carbonation, rich full body, ridiculously smooth and creamy, somewhat dry finish.

Fantastic English-style stout. Lots of flavor yet very easy to drink. However, I am strangely not compelled to seek it out again, as I would the Kalamazoo Stout.
dark brown pour, offwhite head...nice creaminess, good anount of balance between sweet and bitter...nice
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2010 one of my all-time favorites. definitely a classic cream stout. creamy, slight chocolate, thick, dark, all-around goodness.

Pours an opaque chocolate with very thin tan head. Aroma is very chocolatey, vanilla and malts. Flavor is bitter chocolate, a blend of coffee notes and chocolate taking the edge off of any potential sweetness. Abit earthy too.

12 oz bottle from holiday market. poursblack with a short lived tan head. big malt aroma, toffee, chocolate, dark fruits, spice. the flavour starts with dark fruit, the there is a wave of roasted malt, the finnish is a astrigent. complex but not the most drinkable. not the best bells offering.

Jet black, admits no light.  medium tan head, disappears quickly, leaves nice lacing.  Aroma of cafe au lait with burnt edges.  Taste begins with chocolate, then progresses to roasted coffee beans, then finally to burnt espresso.  Very nice indeed.  Laid down 6 bottles tonight, hopefully I can wait a year.

Bottle from Chevy Chase courtesy of the Bang-Golly Foods Beer Club.  This was not good at all.  I was hoping for so much more in terms of flavor and texture and was roundly disappointed.  Nose was a burnt coffee-and-grains mess.  Flavor was much the same with a very mediocre porter quality about it.  Tasted like that bottle of Arctic Rhino I rated earlier this year.  My God this was pointless.

Pours deep chocolate brown. Aroma is mildly smoky, chocolate, vanilla, roasted sweet malts, touch of soy and coffee. Pretty smooth flavor, slightly smoky, lots of dark bitter chocolate, slight bitterness on the end. Good stout.

Bottle. Black pour with some dark head. Definitely get some lactose, chocolate, other coffee and sweet malts, could use a stronger coffee and roaster character.  Decent brew, but far from the best at bells.

Pour from the 12oz. bottle: Sinfully sweet coupled with coffee beans, roasted malts, and semi-sweet chocolate. Light/medium carbonation, creamy layers, crisp finish, charred mouthfeel. Drinkability: Delicious and multi-dimensional. Rebuy: Yea. #170 on 28102009, DG.
Great roasted coffee aroma and smell, toasted malts.  Sweet, creamy, stouty and full bodied.  Not as good as the bourbon barrel aged double cream/expedition stout though, by far.  Still yummy.

12oz bottle.  black with a small brown head.  roasted malt and coffee aroma.  flavor is roasty with milk chocolate and has some earthy herbal note.  sweet cream and cocoa flavor.  no bitterness at all.  creamy but still a bit of fine carbonation.  full body.

bottle, pours black with a thin off white head.  Aroma is nice with carmel, condensed milk, and a light black patent malt note.  Roasted coffee rides a sweet sugary note that finishes dry.  Moderate carbonation, mildly crisp mouthfeel.

Bottle, Dark brownish black. Roasted malty aroma. Sweet roasted carmel flavor with light bitter coffee dark chocolate finish. Thick and creamy body and palate. Very drinkable. Excellent mouthfeel and flavor. Very good overall

Bottle at the Bloomington Beer Festival. Poured black with a brown head. Aroma had a sweet creamy chocolate note as well as a roasted malt note. The roasted malts were more present in the flavor with the creamy chocolate flavor relegated to a supporting note. High point was smoothness of the beer, described by one word... Amazing!
Dark brown pour, creamy light tan head.  Creamy milk chocolate, cocoa powder, sweet malt, and a bit of roastiness.  Very tasty, but overall quite simple of a stout.
Pours black with tan head. Smells of milk and bitter chocolate. Very creamy mouth feel that turns to a semi-sweet chocolate. Finishes with a sharp bitter that is well balanced.

Bottle.  Poured near black with big light brown head that stuck to the glass.  Very nice lacing.  Aroma of sweet malts, chocolate, and milk.  Had a roasted malty flavor.  The palate was thick and creamy.  A very good beer from Bell¬ís.  And I love the label.

Regards to Hopscotch for this treat, much thanks!

Opague with a thick tan head.  Aroma of choocolate, malt and metal.  Very smooth sweet milky taste.  Very drinkable.

Good sweet stout, in fact probably the best sweet stout I¬íve had.  But I am not a huge fan of this style...

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet (Batch 9357, bottled September 21, 2009).  Very dark brown to black pour with a tan head.  Sweet chocolate and roasted malt aroma.  Smooth, chocolatey taste with an almost burnt, smokey malt flavor.  Full bodied and full flavored, especially for only 6% ABV.  An excellent stout.
Dark pour with a small head. Aroma has toffee, coffee, cream and sugar. Flavor is sweet and milky with hazelnut coffee and sugar. Nice.

12 oz. bottle enjoyed at the UM/MSU tailgate.  Aroma is a blast of coffee and chocolate with a hint of smoke.  Taste follows, but with a mellow lactic finish. Light body and incredibly drinkable.  A small treasure of a beer.

12 oz bottle fresh from Madvike.
 I have seen reviews on aged bottles, I would be very curious on the differences of an aged bottle.  Intense dark brown, almost black body with deep tan head.  Aroma is a chocolate malt, dark coco and milk.  Taste brings out many of the same flavors, along with a bit more vanilla and a touch of coffee that I did not pick up in the aroma.  It sounds strange saying it, but it is complex, yet simple.  Great beer and a great pickup.

Batch#8842.  Pours near black with a one finger brown head.  Heavy chocolate aroma, with some hints of vanilla.  Dark chocolate, smoke and oak flavors all present.  Creamy texture with soft carbonation.  Good stuff, but I get more bang for my buck with the Kzoo Stout.

Had this one bottled thanks to Chris!  Opaque dark brown pour with a thick, tan head, roasted nuts and dark chocolate nose, oakiness, barbecue sauce and soy flavors compete against sweet, chocolate maltiness.  Complex, yet strong finish.  Interesting.
Very dark, very rich beer. Has a sweet chocolate/coffee taste. I drank it in the summer but it would be best on a cold winter night maybe after Thanksgiving or Christmas dinner.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2010 pours black with very little cream colored head.  smells of swetbitter chocolate, oak, vanilla and roasted malt. taste is about the same but not as strong as the smell.  When on draught has nice tan head

Pours motor oil black with a thin bubbly cream-colored head.  Aroma of malt and oak, touch of vanilla.  Flavors match, but the oak aroma is replaced by a caramel sweetness, some lightly roasted malt, and heavy cream.

Thick and chewy, satisfying but not quite right for the weather at the moment.  Can definitely see this being a dessert pairing though!

Pours black/dark brown with a thick creamy beige head which settles.  Aroma is roasted chocolate malt, smoke, and caramel. Taste is sweet chocolate roasted malt, vanilla, smoke, bitter finish. Very soft and creamy palate.
Pours a dark black with khaki head.  Aroma of roasted caramel, malts, milk chocolate, coffee.  Similar taste.  Very creamy mouthfeel. Enjoyed this one.

Bottle shared with the guys at the Inglorious Emergency Tasting.  Batch number 7733.  Pours a near black with thin ring of tan head.    Coffee, molassis, toffee, milk chocolate.  Good sweetness, but not too much.  Lingering slightly nutty verging on vegetal finish.
Pours a lasting ring of ran head and a dark brown body.  Aromas of dark, sweet, roasted malts.  Flavor is roasted, dry grain, molasses, soy sauce.

Bottle - Pours black with small tan head. Smells of whiskey, cinammon, milk chocolate, nutmeg, and caramel. Taste brings out a lot of the same flavors: caramel and whiskey right off the bat, finishing with some nuttiness and roasty notes. There¬ís cinammon, chocolate, and lots of bitter coffee on the finish. Smooth, creamy, thick and chewy, this is a real treat. I love the way it warms your belly -- will have to have this again in the winter.

Poured from bottle to pint glass. Thick, black color with Light brown head, surprisingly not creamy and minimal retention. What was left however left some decent lace. 

Smell leaves scets of caramel and roasted coffee, and a very sweet smelling milk scent. Very appetizing. 

Initial taste is oddly very vacant as my palate struggles to get past the overcarbonation. Aftertaste thankfully has some style with a nice milky coffee flavor. The hints of flavor come out more with each sip but never manages to overcome the bubbles. 

Mouthfeel is poor, I wanted thick and smooth but the carbonation created the opposite effect. Way too thin for something I expect to coat the mouth.

While this brew goes down way too easy, why even bother? I had high hopes for this one coming in but will likely not be purchasing it again.

Batch 7250.  Another great stout from one of the best stout breweries out there.  Pour is black with a thin short-lived brown head.  Aroma is lactose, hints of soy sauce, chocolate, and cinnamon. Mouthfeel is velvety and luscious...mmmm.  Flavor is creamy caramel up-front with a wonderful roasty finish of chocolate, coffee, and chicory.  Wow, this has really aged well.  I liked it the first time I had it, but the flavors are so much more rounded and well-integrated now.
Slightly lacking in flavor and low presence of complexity. Nice mouthfeel and the finish is strong coffee like they added coffee to the mix, but it doesn¬ít blend well into the whole flavor.

(12oz bottle) Pours a dark chocolate color. Nose is extremely complex. Chocolate, cream, milky caramel. The taste is complex too, creamy, chocolaty, best in class. The creamy linger on the palette is awesome too. Love this one.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with quickly fading thin brown head. Nose is dominated by toast that overstayed it¬ís welcome in the toaster...lots of burnt toast, and a minimal amount of sweet milk. Taste is smooth, sweet milk chocolate. Barely noticeable carbonation, and some roasted malt. Sweet and almost nutty in the finish. Decent beer.

2009-07-19. Pitch black body, nice tan head faces. (3+) Aroma of roast malt, touch of coffee grounds. (6+) Flavour is sweeter than expected from the nose, touches of roast and mocha overtones, but not a lot of roast bitterness, sweet malty middle. Smooth medum plate is lightly carbonated. Aged a bit longer than planned, but it is a decent stout. Aged Bottle via ChicagoDRI trade.

Batch 8902.  Creamy lactose aroma with dense caramely malt.  Very black, small white head.  This is a good beer but kind of misses the mark for me.  Not too sweet, thinnish body, little rough in the finish.  Little dusty concrete finish.  Looks like I¬ím in the minority for this one.  Good, not great.
Poured tan/brown with an off white head, smelled of sweet chocolate and coffee. Tasted of sweet milk chocolate with a slight toasted malt/dark flavor that finished creamy and smooth.

Extremely deep brown in color with a thin tan head. Lots of goodness in the aroma! Tons of roasted malts, milk chocolate, and just enough caramel sweetness to satisfy me. Perfect amount of sugary sweetness in the flavor. You know you¬íre drinking a cream stout without the beer tasting like candy. Very rich flavors and a creamy texture.

Black pour, thin chocolate head. Sweet smells. Great in all aspects. Dark coffee, milk chocolate, and roasty taste with clean creamy finish. Mouth not too heavy, and 6.1% nowhere around. Good swirl is reminiscent of flavored coffee creamer or like french vanilla and chocolate wafers.

Black pour, some head with good lacing.  Good but not overpowering creamy nose.  Taste is very malty¬ócream and chocolate with a nutty finish.  Not much in the way of hops though they are present, but overall pretty awesome.
I love this beer. Roasty, smooth, a bit sweet and chocolatey. Well-rounded treat.

Tons of chocolate in this beer.  Tastes like the base of Kalamazoo, but without the licorice kind of kick.  

Aroma is chocolate, sugar, a bit of dark roast and this weird je ne sais quoi that is redolent of extract chocolate.
Appearance: Khaki head, mahogany brown to black color.  No lacing, slight foam.
Tastes as I said up top, some bit of sweet milkiness in the flavor that is accented by roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate.  A slight sourness pervades.
Finishes slightly sour, a bit sweet and viscous, but quickly dissipates, leaving only a sweet, creamy coffee flavor.
Overall, very good.

I can only imagine the Double Cream/Expedition blend....
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  poured a dark brown with a beige head and some lace.  aorma of caramel, dark roast, and vanilla.  flavor was caramel, dark roast, and vanilla.

RBSG09 bottle at the grand tasting.  Thanks to whoever brought this.  Auburn-tinged brown with a fluffy tan head.  Aromas of lactose, creamed coffee, milk chocolate.  Porter-esque flavor, dark chocolate with little roastiness.  Slight metallic note in the finish.  Creamy body but nice and light.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours pitch black with a small, foamy, tan head.  You can smell the roasted malt from two feet away!  Coffee, caramel, dark fruit, and brown sugar make up a wonderful nose.  Medium carbonation with a medium-heavy mouthfeel.  Nuttiness, earth, light brown sugar, a little fruit, oak, and a bit of soy sauce make up a complex palate.  The overall body is much lighter than I was expecting.  Quite enjoyable!  Medium-long finish.  Overall a great stout with a slightly different twist that I will surely try again.

Bottle from Cracked kettle.

Pours bblack with a light tan head.

Candy hops, rosted malt and chocolate in the aroma.

Sweet, soy, chocolate and malt tasting.

Misses the little extra to be a realy great stout, a bit to "distorted".

Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Pours a deep, dark brown/black with tan head. Aroma of nice dark roast and baking chocolate. Flavor is the same. Mouth feel is medium body with high carbonation....some silkiness as well....Overall, very good shit!!!!!!!
Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11.  Heavy brown pour.  Strong sweet with killer lacing.  Subtle cocoa flavor.  Decent and easy drinking.
Bottle. Laid back stout. Big taste without being that powerful. Chocolate, cream and fresh hops. Lot¬ís of roastiness.

Comes out of the tap a deep opaque sable with a thick tan head. Rich, smoky, mocha aroma fills the nostrils and hollers "Drink me!" Smoky coffee and chocolate flavor has yeasty and toffee hints. Texture is thick, firm and oily, leaving a lively tingle. It leaves a nice roast coffee finish. A must for all stout fans.

Pours jet black. extremely aggressive pour results in a hint of brown head that quick dissipates. Smells of chocolate, toffee and roasted malts. Laid back nose for a stout. Flavors of roasted coffee, nuts, semisweet chocolate. Lactose comes through strong. Mellow, laid back profile. I think it¬ís too light for a stout. Carbonated more then a traditional stout. Prickly and sparkly. Medium mouth feel, bit thin for a stout. Tried warming it, didn¬ít help.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown color with a nice looking tan head.  The aroma is packed with dark chocolate, roasted coffee beans, malted barley, and vanilla.  Reminds me of the complex aromas of some pipe or chewing tobaccos.  THe flavor includes cream, brown sugar and vanilla extract.  Smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  This one has a very enjoyable, long lasting aftertaste.

Pours very dark brown with a bubbly tan head that fades rather quickly.  Aroma is very chocolately and reminds of hershey syrup with some roastiness as well.  Flavor is dark chocolate with roasted malts and coffee and some lactose.  Very smooth mouthfeel but slightly thinner than expected.  Very easy to drink.

A great stout with a not so overpowering cream flavor to it. Pours great with very little, to no foam head, which is a little off white brown. Has a great nose of cream, chocolate, and coffee bean. Sits very well in your mouth and doesn¬ít overpower the palate.

Nice black color with a medium sized tan head.  Sweet coffee aroma with hints of chocolate.  Almost watery flavor that finishes the story the aroma starts.  Easy to drink with nice carbonation to match the smoothness of the beer.  "Sessionable" if you will.  Mild for a stout but warms up nicely.

Bottle thanks to Bigmmartin.  I have had this before, but I have not rated it yet.  Pours a rich dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts with notes of chocolate and coffee standing out.  On the palate, the feel is smooth and creamy.  The taste is rich and brings out the roasted malts.  This is a great beer to enjoy with a cigar.
Bottle. Very dark brown colour with light brown head; aroma and flavours of roastiness, bitter chocolate, coffee, hint of milkiness,  hint of dried or smoked longan, excellent sweet/bitter balance.

Bottle. Black colour with a brown head. Aroma: Roastiness, coffee, light dark fruitiness, oxidation, light licorice. Taste: Roastiness, coffee, cocoa, light saltiness, not very sweet, oxidation?, a bit of hops. A bit too watery and light bodied for a 6% ABV stout, but not bad.

Has a nose of milk chocolate and subtle coffee notes. Thick and creamy. It tastes like it smells: subtle milk chocolate and coffee with cream. It may be sweeter and smoother than the Kalamazoo, as advertised. Unfortunately, it also seems a bit like a watered down (well, creamed down) version, taking away some of the qualities that makes the Kalamazoo so excellent. Still a very fine brew nonetheless.

On tap at the Brick Store for the Bell¬ís GA release.

Pours pitch black with a large tan head that lingers for quite a while and leaves great lacing.

The aroma is very toasty though with plenty of sweet chocolate malts and lactose.  There are hints of vanilla and coffee as well.

The taste is dominated by the sweet dark chocolate malts and milky lactose.  There is a faint roasted character to the malts, but the sweetness is most evident.  Wonderfully full flavored.

The mouthfeel is super creamy with the roasted aspect taking a backseat to the malty sweetness on the palate.

This is a great beer and one of the best milk stouts I¬íve ever had.  I¬ím lucky I was able to sample this on tap.

Pours a dark, almost black cola colour with quickly dissipating tan head. Has a smooth, milky finish with a roasted malt, chocolate, lactose and coffee flavor. Aroma of malts, sweet chocolate and coffee. Nice sweet stout!

velvety smooth, like a guinnes with a ting of carbonation.  a good stout, but which it were a little more stand-outish, cheaper and higher in alcohol.  i also wish there were no more world hunger, bigger airline seats and a chance to redo one event.  beer, making people happy for decaded and decades.

This is a winter beer, and I tried it in may, not that it makes that much of a difference, but it was quite heavy.  Aside from that, it poured a very dark brown/black totally opaque with a caramelly dark head.  Had a definate chocolate aroma, none of the coffee that one gets a lot of times from a stout.  When I tasted it, instantly I got the chocolate flavor, with maybe a touch of coffee aftertaste.  Overall, it was a bit heavy, especially for the time of year, but would be nice with a chocolate dessert.  I liked it generally, and would probably get it again.
Poured black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Flavor was mostly the same. Kind of milky texture. Chewy. Good.

Inky black pour with one finger of head the color of coffee with cream. Outstandingly rich aroma ¬ñ deep roasted malt, coffee, toffee, chocolate ¬ñ yum. Flavor is incredibly rich and well balanced ¬ñ sweet malt, burnt malt, chocolate, just a hint of hops in the finish leaves a clean and refreshing flavor with no aftertaste. Mouthfeel is rich, creamy, chewy ¬ñ yum.  Avoids being overbearing while delivering a rich and fulfilling flavor. A really fine stout.

Bottle.  Dark black pour, quickly dissipating head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor of vanilla, roasted malts, smooth chocolate and lactose.  Very good, but not my favorite Bells offering by far.

A vigorous pour yields a heavy and nearly black looking beer with almost no head. A few seconds later a small one forms that leaves nice lacing. The aroma is the best aspect of this beer, loaded with chocolate, coffee and dark dark malts. The flavor and mouthfeel also deliver what was expected from Bell¬ís Brewery. It is very sweet but balanced with malt and surprisingly, a moderate hop bitterness. If this beer had a better head and was a little less hoppy, it would be a favorite.

This is batch 8825.

Appearance - Dark brown, with a 1 finger light cream head. Head recedes to a fluffy ring clinging to the edge of the glass. Looks watery in thickness.

Smell - I get lots of smoke, slight tartness like cherries, blueberries, and roasted barley.

Taste - Roasted barley comes through strong. Tastes kind of "woody" to me. There is some slight coffee and maybe even some chocolate too.

Mouthfeel - Very light, just how it looked. I was expecting more, maybe even a creamier feeling.

Drinkability - This is very easy to drink, however it is not my favorite so I wouldnt really wany to drink it much.

On tap at Reggie¬ís. Good, solid sweet stout. Ar: Caramel/burnt sugar, chocolate and signs of the dominant honey to come. Ap: Creamy brown head w/ good retention. Color was a very deep brown bordering on black, but couldn¬ít be sure in the reddish light of Reggie¬ís. Fl: Creamy coffee au lait, roasted malts, milky sweetness, chocolate pudding and above all, honey. The Mocha aftertaste was pleasant. Improves considerably upon warming up and the honey was delicious.

a solid brew, pours black as night with minimal head.  despite lack of head the effervescence was noticeable while drinking (not in a way that disrupted the taste).  The aroma was quite impressive, a sweet malty, almost wine-like aroma with abundant roastiness.  The flavour, while it paled in comparison to the aroma, is still quite good.  Deep roasted malts came through in the flavour along with  a milky taste/texture.  The mouthfeel was quite nice also.  Overall a nice brew.  Not quite as sweet as I had anticipated but would go for another with no doubt
Bottle, The Den, Kalamazoo. Dark brown colour, small tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee cream . Flavour has coffee, chocolate, cream, vanilla and some hops. A bit too sweet, but still ok.

Bouteille de 12 oz achet√©e chez Knightly Spirits (Orlando, FL). Ar√¥me: Odeur de caf√© et de chocolat avec une pointe de caramel. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Pr√©sence d¬íun mince col beige mousseux et d¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt de caf√© et de chocolat au lait. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. L√©g√®re pr√©sence de caf√© en arri√®re go√ªt. (Rating #2357)

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2009 Pours a almost black brown with a tan head. Smells of coffee and toasted malt with a bit of chocolate. Flavor is similar. Quite sweet on the tongue with a creamy texture and a mostly coffee bitter finish. Not as roasted as Kalamazoo Stout, but has more chocolate and coffee. Really nice stout.
Insanely roasty toasty.   Lighter and with more acid edge than the Exp or Kalamzoo.   yum

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2009 Aroma:Toastiness, burnt, coffee, chocolate. 
Appearance: Nearly black, oily. 
Flavor: Iced Coffee. Some chocolate, burnt & toasted malts.
Palate: Creamy, full mouthfeel, smooth. Very dry finish.
Overall Impression:
Little too coffee like for me to return to, but not bad at all.

Bottle, bought @ Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam.
Pours very deep brown with slight red edges. The head is a thing of beauty. Four fingers thick, extremely creamy, wonderful beige-cappucino colour. Truly a stunning beer to behold. Sweet aroma, lots of dark chocolate, roasted malts, some milk, some coffee and Nutella. Lowish carbonation, rather elegant mouthfeel. Though it is not fat, it maintain a good degree of fill. Flaovur is very well-balanced. Lots of chocolate, cold coffee, roasted malts and a milky edge. Tastes like a good bar of dark chocolate with slight chips of coffee nibs. NICE!

12 oz bottle.  Appealing aroma, yet pretty unimposing and not too overly sweet or chocolaty. Nutty, roasted caramels, coffee, chocolate milk, and some brown malts.  Pour consisted of a rather fizzy, bubbling smaller cocoa cream head with little retention, medium-full bodied looking, dark chocolate in color.  In many ways, this beer really does taste like a sweeter and smoother version of Kalamazoo as advertised.  A lot of good roasted nuttiness to it that i like.  Also some coffee and cream mixed with some light cocoa cereal that lingers with the roasted nuts.  Also well balanced like Kalamazoo.  So really, I¬íd say this is really like Kalamazoo¬ís sweeter twin (I would like to try them side by side sometime).  So a good beer for sure, just has a few aspects that to me don¬ít live up to its brother.
Deserving of the name because this one is big, dark, and creamy.  Yummy!  I could drink this stuff all night...  Bells really knows how to make a stout.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Initial rating - 4/13/2009
Mild malty aroma.  Pours a shade lightet than black with a mocha head.  Heavy mouthfeel.  Taste is creamy and malty, hints of chocolate.  I¬ím partial to dry stouts, so this really didn¬ít do anything for me, but it¬ís probably a good beer if you want a creamy stout.  The first time I drank this a few months ago I couldn¬ít bring myself to finish it.  I poured myself another one today to see if a second try is what it needed, and while I think I could drink the rest of the glass, I don¬ít feel compelled to.

Third time tasting it, 12/20/10, I enjoyed it much more.  I¬ím finding it to be a very good beer, just not something I¬íd want to have often. Creamy, rich, chocolatey, nice thick mouthfeel, good carbonation.  Really nice sweet stout.

12oz bottle from a trade. Pours viscous looking, dark brown/black with a thin light brown head. Smells of dark roasted malts also big and chocolatey sweet. Tastes the same with just a hint of chocolate. The roastiness lingers. Full body, good carbonation.

Thick black pour with a creamy brown head.  Aroma is of hops and some coffee.  Initially, this beer doesn¬ít taste much different than Guinness, but after a moment, the taste of coffee and chocolate is present.  This chocolate-like aftertaste is what makes this brew unique.

2009 Bottle - Thanks dmschefke! - Pours a dk brown with a small tan head...aroma is like old corn malt and roast beef...flavour is similarly off, dry and meaty and stale...is this supposed to taste like this..
Bottle from Cracked Kettle. Oily, dark brown body with thin brown head. Sweet and malty nose. Nice taste of chocolate, malts and coffee. Smooth and oily texture. Really nicely done.

Rich chocolate cream aroma. Deep black pour with brown head. Taste is of rich creamy chocolate. Reminds me of brownies for some reason. Dry aftertaste. Very smooth tasting. Leaves a nice roasted malt aftertaste. I really enjoyed this one.

12 oz bottle poured into a normal pint glass.  This beer pours dark black with a then espresso colored head.  It smells of chocolate, some sort of dark fruit, and dark malts.  The taste is very nice.  There is a a nice chocolate bitter coffee taste up front that changes to a sweet creamy finish.  The carbonation is fine and this beer is top notch.  It is a little thin so those that prefer their stouts thick should tread lightly.  This is a great beer.
