12oz bottle from grape & gourmet. pours damn near totally black with a very thin, bubbly light tan head. aroma is very nice and on the sweeter side with scents of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, and some creamy vanilla liqour. flavor is superb and surprisingly complex. flavors of roast coffee, sweet vanilla cream, bitter chocolate, and dark fruits at the forefront, with a long roasted malt finish. palate is somewhat thin for a stout, but very easy drinking, and definitely smooth. overall, another winner from bells.

12oz bottle. Pours almost black. Taste of coffee and cream, with a hint of chocolate.
It¬ís quite tasty but i prefer the expedition stout. Batch: 8732
UPDATED: JUN 30, 2009 bottle.  creamy coffee stout.  chocolate.  medium body.  some hop bitterness.   i would believe that it goes well with desserts

Pours a black with thick mocha head that stays around for a while.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is a pleasant surprise, slight sweetness with hints of vanilla.  Finishes very nicely and sticks around for a while after.  Definitely a very nice stout.
Pretty much just a nice coffee stout with a bit of added sweetness, a goodly amount of dark malt and a citrus complexity.  Maybe worth getting to serve with some special desert around the holidays.

Bottle.  Poured black with a brown head.  Aroma was malty with some chocolate and very fruity.  The flavor is pretty sweet and very complex.  Malt first then some chocolate with some liquorice and dark fruit.    Full bodied, smooth slightly sour finish.
Nice sweet chcolate smell.  Mouthfeel was kinda thin.  Taste was interesting with the sweetness and coffee combo.  It drank very smooth.

Deep/dark  brown pour, mocha almost purple head.  Roasted everything, yet balanced well by a creamy sweetness, with vanilla sugary quality, good with the spent coffe ground notes and light bittering finish.

Pitch black body with a lasting brown head.  Baker¬ís chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt make up the wonderful aroma.  Smooth, full mouthfeel.  Absolutely delicious with the chocolate and roasted malt sweetness up front fading to a great coffee and cream finish.  A beautiful, tasty, and easy drinking beer.  Bravo.
I expected sweeter, but this does wreak of kahlua- a good thing. Dry and coffeeish, not too milky.

12 oz bottle likely from the Binnys Singles Rack (Orland Park, IL) that has been marinating for a good while. Pours a near black hue with floaties, big brownish head that begins to dissipate to a moderate amount and laces good. Aromas are chocolate, vanilla, and light roasted malts off the bat, moving to light coffee and creamy sweetness also. Initial is a good sweet stout base, starting with chocolate creaminess and moving to light coffee, assertive but not dominant roasted malts and barley, some vanilla and caramel and trace smoke. Very nice. Finishes smooth, with a lingering sweetness that is pleasant. Sessionable, but the style is a bit sweet for me overall. Still, a very well done sweet stout that is far from cloying and very enjoyable. Cheers.
Bottle: Poured a deep black with a tan color head. Aroma is sweet chocolate and roasted malts. Taste is sweet with roasted malts, slight coffee bean, and bakers chocolate.

Nice black color. Nice off-white head. Not a deep dark chocolate head, but chocolate enough for me to notice. Very malty aroma, but not very complex. I believe this beer is somewhat overrated. Has a nice roasted malt flavor, but again, there is not much more to this beer. It has a sweet flavor, but the palate is also lacking. I like this stout it is somewhat smooth, but not pungent or sweet enough to grab my attention.

On tap at Datz Deli (Tampa, FL). Pours a murky dark brown to black with a thick and creamy tan two finger head that settles slowly. Aroma is roasted and malty with notes of chocolate, ripe dark fruit, brown sugar, hints of coffee, toffee, caramel. Flavor is sweet and roasted with notes of coffee, toffee, ripe dark fruit, some hints of molasses and raisins. Full body with a slightly bitter coffee finish.
Deep black color with dark tan head... Aroma of roasted malts.... Malty flavor with hints of cream and coffee... Leaves a taste of black coffee on the palate...
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $1.99 Excellent!

12 oz bottle; Pours out dark like your typical stout with a light to medium tan head that laces nicely.  The aroma is a sort of metallic coffee/chocolate.  I agree with fredandboboflo in that the flavor represents semisweet chocolate (not sure about peanut butter though!).  Carbonation is lively at first pour then goes flat.  Good beer - although I¬ím not usually big on sweet stouts.
user_location: originally from Michigan, New York, USA

text: Bottle, batch 8273, i.e. bottled 12/19/07. As a result of the age, there is some mild oxidation in the way of sherry notes, but sweet, milky, roasted malts still prevail in the nose. Flavor has a hearty dose of semisweet chocolate, and huge amounts of peanut butter. Fantastic, creamy mouthfeel without ever approaching heaviness. Really nice beer, even over a year later, impressive at 6.1%.

Bottle.  Pours a deep, dark brown with a light brown head.  Aroma is creamy coffee with a little chocolate.  Flavor is a mix of light coffee and chocolate at first, with a chocolatey finish.  Nicely done.
Bottle.  Dark opaque with a thin chocolate head. Aroma: chocolate, roast, and toffee. Flavor: sweet coffee and a slight smokiness, yet very smooth.
Black pour with a large tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and meat. Strong coffee flavor which subsides to some bitter chocolate and smoke.

Bottle.  Poured to a dark brown with a one fingers tan head that excellently laces the glass.  Nose isn¬ít very strong - what you can pick out is chocolate and roasted coffee, very sweet smelling.  This is a very smooth brew with a lot of cream (as the name dictates,) chocolate, roasted malts and a nice, slightly bitter finish.  For the complexity of this beer, it¬ís a little watery on the palate, but most certainly worth revisiting a few times.
Midnight brown with a small amount of suds. Smelled like tootsie rool. Tastes of milk chocolate, roasted coffee, and hop spice. Felt rich and creamy. Overall a fantastic beer.

This was a pretty good beer but sort of ho hum for Bells. Maybe I¬íve just come to expect a lot from them, especially with their stouts. It didn¬ít pour out pure black but looked completely black when sitting in the glass. Nice off-white head and spots of lacing. The aroma I found a litttle odd, not bad, just different with coffee, licorice, grains, some dark fruit and it just seemed a little strange. Pretty good tasting beer but I didn¬ít think there was a whole lot going on, soft creamy coffee notes up front and it gets a bit roasty in the finish. Also some molasses and chocolate mixed in there. Solid beer for sure and I think Bells might be a victim of their own success with this one.

Black pour with a big, 2 finger, tan head.  Dark roasted malt aroma, with a hint of pine, milk chocolate, and some slight lactose sourness.  Bitter roasted malt and hops flavor with a healthy dose of sweet milk chocolate and a faint sour milk note in the finish.  Very creamy full body with a moderate amount of carbonation.

Black-brown color with a brown lace head.  Sweet malt aroma with caramel and chocolate dominating.  Milky cream taste.  Great palate compared to most sweet stouts.  Long rich aftertaste and doesn¬ít end bitter and sour like most.

Typical jet black color very small brown head that does leave a lace, cant see any carbonation.  Malty but a sweet milky smell like the candy "whoppers". Nice pleasant aroma not too strong and lacking a hop bite. A sweet and creamy taste to this stout rather than the usual burnt gloom and doom. Palate is excellent for this type. A most refreshing taste not oversweet and not the usual bitter pill associated with craft stouts. Great.

very nice deep black color with a mocha colored head.  aroma is a bit sweet with notes of caramel, light chocolate, hazelnut, and a touch of fruit...maybe plum or fig.  flavor is a milky with roasty notes and malty sweetness.  ligh hoppiness balance well with a sweet roasty and dark fruit finish.  mouthfeel is very creamy and milky.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with some head that mostly fades away leaving only a long lasting ring of foam. Tastes very creamy and thick with a little bit of chocolate flavor. Has a very long and complex aftertaste. A good stout but not up to the hype, in my opinion.
Very dark brown in color with a small tan head. Aroma is lightly roasty with caramel and chocolate. Taste is of chocolate, cream, and roasted malts.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 BOTTLE: Dark brown/black pour. Aroma is chocolate, malt, and milk. Taste is creamy, roasty, chocolate, toffee, nice full mouthfeel. Great beer.

An excellent stout. Similar taste to Bells porter, but a little stronger and creamier with a fuller mouthfeel. On appearance it looks heavily carbonated for a stout, but the carbonation is just right on the palate. Slightly sweet with coffee, roastiness, and slight smoke. Medium-full bodied and very well-balanced.

Bottle from California Bottles. has a dairy like scent of milk or whipped cream with a delicious background of roast malts. The stout poured a dark black liquid and created a huge inch of fluffy foam. Incredible flavoring of rich black malt and sweet thick tasting of cream.

12oz. Bottle. Year old bottle with no head and an inky black color.  Lots of cocoa in the nose and a bit of roasted malt.  Flavors include chocolate, caramel, crystal malt, vanilla and a touch of roasty espresso.  Surprisingly the beer is not overly sweet and the hops lend a subtle bitterness to support all the sweet malt flavors.  Mouthfeel is perfect for this style and has a silky/creamy texture.  Finish has a taste of stale hops and bitter chocolate.  Generally not a fan of this style as it tends to be one dimensional, but Bells has managed to come up with yet another impressive stout.

They call it double cream stout for a reason... Pours a deep deep brown, nearly jet black with a thin caramel head... Aroma or roasted malt, dark fruits, caramel, and chocolate.... Taste is very creamy, a bit roasty with a nice interplay between the two... This is a stellar sweet stout deserved of its high ranking, not too thin, not too milky, highly drinkable...

On tap at Magoos.
Really nice stout with a good amount of hops to balance flavor, so a bit more like an Imperial Stout.  Compared to Victory Storm King just a little thinner and sweeter as they say.  Dark Ruby, no Head, licorice, cherries, lingereing fruit sweetness, nice full mouth

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2009 Update 6/15/09.  Batch 8842 (11/28/08).  A slightly fresher bottle to rate.  Aroma is very roasty with burnt toast, chocolate, sweet malt, and raisins.  Flavor is mostly sweet malt with some roast present too.  Kind of dull, not not bad.
7/4/7/4/14 (3.6/5)

Originally reviewed on 1/22/09.  Bottle, batch 8273 (12/19/07).  Pours black with no head.  Aroma of raisin and sweet malt, light chocolate notes.  Flavor is sweet and raisiny initially with a roasty finish.  Unfortunately this is past it¬ís prime, but I didn¬ít realize how old it was when I purchased it.  It¬ís decent overall though.
6/4/7/3/14 (3.4/5)

Black with a dark tan head that leaves just a bit of foam in a ring around the glass.   Creamy, sweet, powdery chocolate aroma.   Mild dark chocolate bitterness after a sweet and mellow front end that has plenty of cream flavor.   Medium-full bodied with low carbonation and an almost silky-slick feel.   A bit overly sweet and creamy, but pretty nice.
botle, chocolate brown pour with only a slight tan ring, aroma of dark fruit, flavors of bitter cocoa, coffee nibs and a light crisp finish

Bottle:  Poured an almost black color with not much head.  The aroma was chocolate roasted malts.  The flavor was good, hints of chocolate, caramel, roasted malts, vanilla, and a creamy texture.  Overall, another quality stout from Bells.

Dark almost black color with very small tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate with roasted coffee.  I love the balance of this beer.  A perfect mixture of hops and malts.  Oily texture that creates an awesome mouth feel.  Bells Brewery rarely disappoints.

2002 Vintage:Pitch black coloured body with a fast-living brownish tan head. Aroma of cream, vanilla pods, perfume and a light maltiness - odd for a smell! Full-bodied; Strong full maltiness packed with vanilla pods and a creamy taste that is reminiscent of creme brulee. Aftertaste is very mild - only showing some subtle sweetness and a bit of the roasted malt. Overall, a nice beer - even after the three years time. Definitely one to try if you could still find it somewhere. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Merchant¬ís in Dearborn, Michigan on 25-December-2005.

12 oz bottle..courtesy of me.  Pours blackish brown with tannish head.  There are chocolate and caramel notes in the aroma.  Coffee as well.  I definitely agree it seems a bit milder than the Kalamazoo.  Very tasty.  There is a sugary sweetness that hits right after the maltiness that hits upfront.  Chocolate is nice on the way out.

Pours nearly black dark brown with a tall reddish brown head that with great retention and lacing. Aroma is of roast, chocolate, toffee, toast and a little burnt coffee, some metallic notes come out as I finish the glass. Flavor starts off char and roast, then caramel, buttermilk, toast, sweet chocolate, burnt sugar, toffee, and a burnt candied nut. Finish is char, bitter, herbal and somewhat old tasting hops, with a nice bittersweet chocolate fade. Body is sweet and somewhat oily, only slightly sticky and more warming than you would expect from 6.1%. A nice stout, but not great.
Bottle.  Smell is creamy, roasty, malts, coffee, and chocolate.  Look is dark brown with red highlights and a beige colored head.  Taste is coffe, chocolate, sweetness, and roasted malts.
On tap at Bettys.  Black pour with a medium tan head.  Creamy coffee aroma.  Hop and coffee flavor up front, followed by cream and sugar.  Awesome.

Pours dark brown with light brown head. Aromas of burnt malt, chocolate and coffee. Sweet roasted malt flavor. There is also lots of chocolate and some mild coffee flavors, Full body with mild carbonation and a slightly bitter finish. Nice creamy mouthfeel. A well done stout.
Pours black with little to no brown head. Taste is chocolate malt and coffee. Roasty with a semi-sweet finish. Great balance, very good drinkable. No alcohol taste. One of the better sixpack stouts.

12 oz bottle from Capones. Pours a very nice thick viscous black body with a large bubbly and thick foamy deep beige head. Aroma is totally superb with tons of chocolate and cream, smells so much like a good pie I was reaching for a knife and spoon. Medium bodied with average carbonation, a nice full mouthfeel overall with only slight hops bitterness on the finishing bite. Flavor has lots of chocolate from some nice malt choices, a good amount of hop citrus rind mixed in, but more malts kick in showing the chocolate notes as well as a slight touch of muffins and soap. This is one well made beer that I will gladly seek out again, especially for that kick ass aroma.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2009 Pours black with a thick pillowy tan head. Not a lot going on in those nose. Some roasted and chocolate malts. Some nuttiness that is fairly mild. A tiny bit of dark fruitiness and some yeast. Not bad, just not amazing. Starts out with a nice bit of creamy malts and sugar. Quickly hit by some very mild hops that lend some bitterness which doesn¬ít effect the flavor much. Ends with some basic malt and grain that leaves little to ponder. Just very malty and pretty smooth. Medium-full body and minimal to average carbonation. I cant say I disliked the beer because it was quite malty and rich but it lacked a solid presence that really made it great rather than just good. Nice sipper and easy to drink but not enough oomph.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2011 Cask at Fries Cafe. Pours black with a nice creamy head and excellent lacing. Chocolate and sweet malts in the nose with excellent roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, fruit, and smoke on the tongue. Medium bodied, smooth, and creamy with lingering balanced roast. A terrific stout.
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2012 Tap at uno¬ís in neshaminy.  Night black pour.  Mocha lacing.   Gorgeous.  Coffee, chocolate, thick malt.  Creamy, smooth, mostly bitter chocolate.  Classic.

Bottle.  Roasty aroma, quite mild.  Black body, smallish brown head.  Flavor is tasty blend of roastiness, some sweetness, chocolate, and a touch of coffee.  Not bad, but not as impressive as other Bells stouts.

On draft at the Dilli Deli in Cincy. Smooth beyond belief of coarse this was cask pulled from a beer engine so it was extra extra creamy chocolate and with a very faint hop presence maybe some oat to smooth out the edges as well. Bells delivers its excellence again and does the stout category justice again highest praise..
Pours a black used oil-like color with a tan head.  Aroma of oats, chocolate,and malt.  Complex and sweet flavor- oats, chocolate, and malts.  Very nice as usual.

Jet black but with a short-in-stature, short-lived head. Has a mildly astringent aroma that defies characterization, probably due to its combination of 10 different malts. A very balanced stout, not too sweet, hardly bitter, that does not have an explicit and defining chocolate or coffee flavor, though both are present. Very drinkable.

Bottle. Pours jet black with a thin medium tan head. Sweet toffee and malt nose. Chocolate covered cherry flavor, with oats and roasted malt. Some nice coffee accents too. Mouth it dry and smooth textured. A nice relaxing after dinner drink

pours dark brown with thin tan head. Nice chocolate and coffee, good roast maltiness.
Flavour is very smooth, creamy sweet malt trailing into a bitter dark roast coffee finish.
Beautiful pour with nice lacing down to the last drop.  Smoky, coffee, chocolate.  Mouthfeel is super d duper.  Smooth.  Very very drinkable.  Great stout.
Almost black with some red.  Nose is coffee, cream, and whiskey.  Chocolate and coffee are major flavor themes.  Feel is wonderfully smooth.  A delightful beer.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2009 A dark brown poor; smells of malt and roasted barley. Taste has characters of coffee, chocolate, and honey with a slight fruity background - either cherry or berries. An even mixture of flavors with a creamy roasted undertone. An excellent brew; goes extremely well with chocolate desserts.

Pours a clear but very dark brown that raises a coffee-brown head that never fully dissipates and leaves spots of brown lace.  Nicely blended roasted, chocolate, and sweet honey aromas.  Flavor begins bittersweet, nuts and berries, segueing through smoky, meaty flavors into an earthy, dark chocolate finish.  Smooth mouthfeel, yet with very present carbonation.  Long, dry, bittersweet aftertaste.

Pours black with dark brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, lots of roasted malt.  Flavor is true to the aroma, with a big creamy character of malts and coffee.  Simple, yes, but very tasty.  Sometimes, damn it, you just want a solid beer.  This is it, with no frills.  Could use some more hops though.  Smooth mouthfeel.
This is a solid brew that I picked up while in DC.  Very full bodied fill for only 6.1 ABV.  Worth a try.

Pours a very dark black with a nice tan head. Heavy roasted malt flavor with notes of black cherries in the back, hints of vanilla and cocoa. Leaves a slight milk chocolate aftertaste. Smooth finish with light carbonation

[Bottle] Pours a deep opaque black with a smallish, soft, tan head. Aroma is sweetish lactose, a touch of vanilla, some roasted malts, and some chocolate. A really soft, but at the same time still full of dimension. The flavor is initially sweet, with the lactose coming forward, which gives way to some roasty and a little chalky cocoa profile. My only knock on this beer is that the finish has a touch of astringency that lingers with the bitterness. Well carbonated but smooth on the finish. I really enjoyed this one.

Pours black with a nice tan head from the bottle.  More smokey than creamy, which I found strange.  Raisin, pepper, and faint cocoa are also detectable.  Much different than what I was anticipating, but still up to the bells standard.
(11.26.08) 12 oz. bottle: Black pour with small light brown head. Roasty aroma of coffee, milk chocolate. Creamy palate, typical of a sweet stout. Flavor is like the nose, milky, roasty, malty.

Pours black in color with a small tan head. Aroma or roasted coffee and chocolate.  Intial malty chocolate flavor and finishes with a burn coffee taste.  
Pretty tasty beer.
Thick near black, very light head. Roasty oily aroma. Roast bitterness. Vanilla bean? Hops come on late. Licorice. Basically similar to any other good American stout.

Bottle. Pours Opaque black, with a thin light brown head. Nose is coffeeish, but smooth. Notes of baking chocolate, some roasty espresso. Light. Flavor is licorice and coffee with a bit of cream, sweet but roasty finish. Mouthfeel is medium-full bodied, but light, with light but crisp carbonation.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Coffee and milk chocolate on the nose.  Maybe some Kahlua  in there, too.  Flavor in¬ít as good as the nose.  Gets too sour later.  But it¬ís pretty damn good.  Later tang on the tongue.

12oz bottles from a variety pack purchased at Shangy‚Äôs in eastern PA. Very dark brown pour with a thick tan head that evaporates at a medium pace. Very roasty, toasty and chocolaty with a coffee backdrop as well. Just the perfect amount of bitter balancing out the main level of sweetness. Creamy goodness in a bottle right here.

12 oz bottle I have been sitting on this for over a year. Unintentionally aging it I still had a great time sitting down with this bottle. Bells usually does not disappoint and this is no exception. Now I know how the blend with Expedition Stout turned out so well - both beers stand alone on their merits. Combine them and you get a gem. Aroma / Appearance - The one finger dense head suffocated the dark brown viscous body underneath. Sticky lacing clung to the sides leaving trails of dirty film. Caramel, chocolate and coffee melded with a smokiness that held it all together. Open and airy it smoothly provides an offering of what is to come. Flavor / Palate - The fluid dark chocolate taste of the first sip gives way to caramel, black coffee, and malt. A little thinner than Expedition this is still stoutlike. The smoky finish highlights a sippable winter warmer. This would be perfect with some fine chocolate. I may just have to get some more in the future once I thin out the cellar.
From a bottle poured black with a small light brown head.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a lingering finsh.
pours like rootbeer, and has a very similar flavor.  nothing real special about this beer, but very drinkable and smooth.

Bottle thanks to Kosko20. Bottle markeed 8150. Pours a deep brown with a deep head that fades on top of it. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and soot. Tastee is a bit husky with coffee grounds and a bit of lactose. Very creamy mouthfeel with light carbonation.

Pours a deep deep brown with a dark tan head that slowly disapates into a this layer. Smells of malt and coffee with a hint of chocolate. This is a drinkable stout dispite the stong sweet coffee taste from a great brewer. 

12 oz. bottle from world market

Reviewed on: 11-02-2008

12oz Bottle - Trade - Daknole
Aroma ¬ñ Huge malt aroma, with a sweet lingering dried fruit aroma.  
Appearance ¬ñ  Dark Brown in color, Clear with a nice head. 
Flavor ¬ñ Smooth easy malt flavor with a nice fruity flavor and very deep dark malts. Chocolate flavoring was very sweet.  
Palate ¬ñ Nice Mouthfeel, Good texture with a dry finish. 
Overall ¬ñ  This is a wonderful beer.  Smooth and great flavor. Creamy is a big word for this beer.

330 mL bottle. Pours more formidable than the Kalamazoo Stout- used motor oil black with a menacingly dark tan head. Lacing is not too great. Aroma is red licorice, roasted malt, burnt sugar. Flavor is powerful with espresso, burnt sugar, cocoa powder, dark chocolate.  Moderately creamy on the palate, almost watery. Aftertaste is short and neutral with some bursts of unsweetened dark chocolate. Reminds me a lot of Guinness Foreign Extra but loads more cocoa.

On tap at the Gnome - Pours a deep black with a small head. The nose is rich toasted malt , with chocolate, and coffee.  Comes across the palate with a bit sweet before more bitter toasted malt , with hints of chocolate and coffee. The mouth feel is too tacky to be very drinkable. Nice lingering toastyness. Pretty tasty,but not your everyday easy drinking beer.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2009 Ive been waiting for this I got in coming in a trade but when i saw 6 pk hmm pour was black thick and rich with thick creamy brown head aromas of chocolates and coffee and roasted malts taste was sweet and creamy,heavy like a syrup of chocolate,cofee and malts what a great brew by bells i like this one better than kalamazoo

Wow! Pours a dark dark thick motor oil black colour with a medium sized brown head. Aroma is so wonderful- smokey, chocolate, hitns of coffee, and dark roasted malts. Taste is creamy, full and chewy on the palate. Leather, smoke, cigars, chocolate, and coffee flavors are abundant. An excellent, well balanced and incredibly tastey beer.

Logan‚Äôs Stout Tasting: Chocolate mousse nose with a touch of vanilla.  Dark brown beer, lacy but thin head.  Clean, creamy chocolate flavors with some hoppy bitterness behind.  Nice and creamy but nothing really out of the ordinary.

Bottle.  Pours a nice, rich black body with a brownish head that is medium size.  Strong aroma of chocolate with other hints of candy and vanilla.  As would be expected, very creamy texture with a very nice aftertaste.  Highly recommended as a desert itself or a great beer for drinking!

Deep brown pour, mocha head.  Wow full flavor.  Roasted everything, yet balanced well by sublime creamy sweetness, with vanilla sugary quality, dancing well with the spent coffe ground notes and light espresso bittering finish.  Nice

This might be the best beer I have ever had.  Pours dark brown with a nice brown head.  The aroma might be the only area the beer is lacking in with hints of coffee and cocoa.  The flavor is a nice combination of everything delicious including coffee and chocolate all melded together by a nice smokiness.  Phenomenal beer.  Nice because Bell‚Äôs lists this beer‚Äôs availability as Nov. 1st through March but I got it mid-October at La Cave du Vin which offers it to go at state minimum prices which is an awesome discovery.

12oz bottle. Pours black, almost opaque with dark brown highlights. The head is thin and brown in color, leaving light rings of lace on the glass. The aroma is mostly chocolate with some honey, sweetened espresso, and dark fruit. The flavor starts roasty but not acrid or burnt. It is like dark chocolate with a boatload of sugar in it - lots of residual malt sweetness. At mid-palate, there is some fruity and chocolatey malt and yeast character, but the sweetness is still pervasive. Some balancing bitterness shows up in the end - clean and slightly fruity. The finish is full with a bunch of chocolate and sweetened coffee and some ester and hop character providing nice, complex undertones. The mouthfeel is very full and slick - almost oily. It is a bit spritzy after it is poured, but swirling in the mouth releases gas and reveals the very full body (almost reminds me of chocolate mousse). Overall, an enjoyable sweet stout, but it is missing something - not sure what, but there is some quality to it that fails to overwhelm...

Pours black, brownish head.
Aroma, roasted, some piney hops, malty.
Taste, sweet and creamy, light hops and chocolate. Malty, with some nice notes of roastiness.
Beer could pass for more than 6.1% and has a nice warming mouthfeel. Aftertaste has some light coffee notes. Gets better with external temperature.
12 oz bottle. malt, coffee, dark black pour, minimal head. probably drank a bit too cold.  lingering taste.  tasted a lot bigger than a 6% beer.

Bottle. Pours a deep black with a small light brown head. Rich toasted malt aroma, with chocolate, coffee, and the hint of something metallic. Taste starts a bit sweet before more bitter toasted malt kicks in, with hints of chocolate and coffee. The mouthfeel is too tacky to be very drinkable. Nice lingering toastyness. Pretty tasty, but flawed.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with no head. Aroma is on light side with malt, vanilla and chocolate. Flavor is light with vanilla, chocolate, malt. Mouthfeel was a little thin. Not a whole lot to it.
Bottle. Thin mouthfeel, a bit watery. Not very complex, but nice tastes overall. Tastes of roasted malt with some vanilla. Good but not great.

dark pour - looks like the kalamazoo and expedition stout - full head - aroma was not very strong - palate was a bit thin - taste is Malt and Milk and butter?- When oh when will I stop buying the MOCHA - Cream - Vanilla stouts - they all just don‚Äôt work for me.. I did like the FFF Mocha Stout though... Probably a well made beer but too weak for me - not complex enough- too smooth for me.  I cerntainly enjoyed this but will not be jumping back to this...

Pours a very dark viscous near black with a small beige froth on top.   Sweet creamy aroma of butter, dark coco-powder and oatmeal.  Flavor of dark roast, dark chocolate, oatmeal, molasses  and butter.   Buttery coffee finish.  Medium/heavy with large soda bubble carbonation.   Good, but not very creamy.

Got a 6 pack of this for $6.99, how lucky am I? Other than needing a fuller head and a bigger mouth feel, a fantastic beer. An aroma with mocha and chocolate and a taste that is sweet and creamy. Excellent, excellent beer.

A very good sweet stout.  Light to medium body.  Great aroma. Nice and easy on the palate.  A sweet stout should be less complex and sweeter than a darker more complex stout and bells really nailed that here.

Full of Malts, caramel, some roasted coffee and a little bit chocolate. Creamy but not that syrup crap many Stout makers are passing off.  Absolutely delicous.  Just sampled a fresh batch from Oct. 08.  It think it‚Äôs even better this year...

Much drier than most sweet stouts I‚Äôve had - still it‚Äôs an amazing, smoky concoction that has notes of chocolate, smoke, sesame and a very light coffee touch. Creamy and sweet on the finish - yet dry in the mouthfeel.

Bottle @ Maproom. Pours very dark blackish, with a great head and great lacing. Smells of coffee, prunes, dark chocolate, cognac, and licorice. Tastes very roasty and creamy malty. Finishes very smooth, with a creamy, roasty flavor. Very bold and a very nice beer, just not as good as an imperial but probably the best sweet stout I‚Äôve had.

Pours dark brown with a quickly dissapating tan head. Aroma is of toasty malts, caramel, dairy creamer, and some weak coffee. Taste is malts and hints of chocolate complimented by coffee and a lingering creamy sweetness. Very creamy mouthfeel, but a tad too watery. It‚Äôs good, without being overly unique.
Bottle. Pours thick brown with tan head. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, creamy and thick.  Finishes malty. Very hearty beer for winter drinking.

12 oz. bottle - batch 8150; thanks to kryptic (BA) for the trade; milky brown with thin tan head; smooth, creamy texture; milk chocolate, vanilla, cookies; very nice and an easy drinker; perhaps a little unfair to drink next to the 7000, but a stellar beer on its own

Bottled.  Super, easy drinking stout.  Pour a slick, dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma is coffee that has cream and sugar added.  Smooth flavour of milk chocolate, french coffee and vanilla.  Just a hint of bitterness in the finish.  Maybe a little thin on the body and mouthfeel but still a great stout.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2008 On tap at Jerry¬ís. Black with big, creamy cappuccino head / Sour, toasty, tobacco nose / Medium to full body, acidic, maybe a tad watery, with good finish / Remarkable flavor profile of tobacco, smoke, bittersweet chocolate, and vanilla / Superb flavor offsets a weak body.

From bottle.  Part of May beer tasting event.  
Pours deep chocolate brown with substantial brown head. 
Aromas of chocolate and coffee. 
Very smooth from beginning to end.  Nice effort.
Shows roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee flavors.  Very little carbonation, no head, with an extremely smooth mouthfeel.  An excellent all around stout.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown/black, small brown head that didn‚Äôt stick around long. Aroma is sweet chocolate, malt and maybe a touch of coffee. Flavor was again chocolate, malt and coffee. Finish was abrupt, no real lingering of flavor on the tongue.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2009 Beautiful deep chocolate pour with a medium dark head that diminishes to a halo of large bubbles. The nose is wonderfully smooth and sweet, with chocolate, coffee, and what seems to be graham crackers. The flavor is almost equally enjoyable, with a bit more of the coffee present, along with the chocolate and roasted malt. Smooth on the palate.

RateBeer Rating, Style and Glass: 97, Sweet stout, Pint
ABV, Volume & Calories: 6.1% in 12 fl oz. estimated at 150 C
Purchased at: Bound Beverages, Bensalem, PA for $3.33

Aroma: great, cocoa, chocolate, coffee. 10 out of 10.

Visuals: high design, black, oily, persistent tan head, thick lace. 5 out of 5.

Taste: heavy malt, medium hops, medium strength, high craft. 9 out of 10.

Palate: high quality, dark texture, bitter finish. 5 out of 5.

Overall: a sweet treat, I¬íd have it again, very good, medium value, high craft. 18 out of 20.

12oz bottle. Courtesy of NYbeer, thanks Steven. Poured a really dark brown, with a light tan head. Very nice aroma, dark malts and some nice hoppiness. Nice roasty bitterness, coffee in the aftertaste, very enjoyable.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle courtesy of colemgm8 pours black with little quick diminishing tan head. Aroma is chocolate and chocolate malt. First taste is sweet light coffee and nuts, then a great chocolate flavor takes over and finishes really nice. The mouthfeel is creamy with little carbonation which really complements this beer.
Bottle. Pours near black with a brown head. Roasted aroma with espresso and vanilla. Very smooth in the mouth. Cool, subtle flavor has chocolate, roasted malts, and is even a bit nutty. Good.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2008 Pours Oily black  No head to speek of,minimul lacing. Nose is very rich with straight forward coffee & chocolate with a bit of roast. Flavor is lightly sweet and malty with the light hops coming through in the end next to a bit of smoke. Not super complex at all, but very straight forward. Drinkable

Poured from a 12oz bottle (Batch 8150) and served in an English pint glass. This stout poured a solid black with a thin head of dark tan foam that faded away into a single layer of bubbles. Just a touch of lacing was left around the glass. The aroma of the beer was made up of rich milk chocolate notes, fresh coffee, and some burnt malts. The flavor consisted of light burnt malts and a heavy dose of creamy dark chocolate. The mouthfeel was creamy, smooth, and medium-bodied with a nice level of carbonation. An awsome stout that is tasty and quite sessionable as well. One of my favorites!

Bells is no stranger to the stout scene. Their Kalamazoo, Java, and Expedition stouts are each glorious examples of the various stout styles, and their Double Cream Stout is a succulently smooth entry into the cream stout category.

She pours a thick-brown black and a soft cappuccino head forms and slowly lingers down to a velvety ring around my glass. Sweet milk chocolate hits me in the nose, lightly buoyed by hints of half&half and some prunes. Considering how thick she poured, I take a couple quaffs expecting it to be very viscous and full-bodied but am instead pleasantly surprised to find Special Double Cream to be well-balanced and more medium-bodied. Smooth and creamy, she glides across my tastebuds. Smooth cream, not too overly sweet leaves a pleasant lingering dry bitterness hinting at rich chocolates and fresh espresso. Very little if any prune taste in the palate. A very pleasant finish which lingers and makes me crave another quaff. I happily oblige. Smooth, creamy, reminiscent of a cool chocolate milk coffee drink, though far better. I can‚Äôt get over the finish - sweet bitter chocolate espresso. I think I enjoy the finish of the Special Double Cream Stout as much as I enjoy the overall palate and flavor profile.

I am thoroughly impressed with this beer. Delicate, well-balanced palate resplendent with smooth chocolate and espresso coffee aromas and flavors. An amazing dry finish which lingers like a chocolate truffle on my lips. Beautiful! The only way Bells Special Double Cream Stout could be any better were if I had a side plate of milk chocolate truffles and dark chocolate covered strawberries.

Pours black with a tan head.  Nose was roasted malt, coco powder, some coffee. Taste has a lot of complexity with the malts. The flavor is excellent, though, with some coffee and milk flavors, and a light sweetness. Cream and chocolate in the finish. Mouthfeel is very thick and nice. Bells is so awesome.

I had a glass of this in the Three Floyds Brewpub in Munster, Indiana (it was a guest draft beer).  This is the only Double Creme Stout I could find here, so this must be it,  Very dark with a small light brown head. Nose of chocolate and coffee.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  Flavor is of roasted malts and chocolate. Amazingly easy to drink. Simply incredible stuff
Nice aroma of coffee and cocoa.  Somewhat bitter of an aftertaste with hint of cream.

12oz bottle via trade with mmm///beer.  Pours the darkest possible brown without being black.  Nose was medium in potency with fresh coffee, cocoa dust, and toasted malt.  Finish was very, very creamy.....a great one from Bells.

Bottle.  Black with small tan head, not much lacing and appears to be a little thin.  Smells like a strong cappucino, roasted coffee, chocolate, and creamer.  Soft sweetness throughout.  Very easy to drink just somewhat of a thin watery texture though.  Otherwise good.
I don‚Äôt think these guys make a bad beer. Another solid stout. Smells like a chocolate shake. Easy drinker but not an everyday drinker. Would be great on draught to sip on during the winter.

Bottle. Heavy malt smells of cookie, toasted, dark chocolate and strong coffee, moderate resin for hops and leather and earth for the yeast, with a vanilla not in the background. Head is large, creamy, light brown, with good lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is black with a red tint. Flavor is moderately sweet and lightly acidic to start and finishes lightly sweet, acidic and bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy, has a carbonation that is soft, almost flat. An excellent Sweet Stout, aptly named "Double Cream".

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2008 12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown almost black color with a thin tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate and roasted coffee beans.  Accordingly, these scents are very prominent in the flavor as is a tinge of maltiness.  Smooth on the palate with a slightly bitter finish.  Medium to heavily bodied and just plain delicious.  Another great brew from Bells.

(Bottle) Pours near black with a small light brown head. The aroma is perfectly and medium roasted with creamy tones of chocolate cake/brownies and mild but dry coffee. Undertones of roasted nuts, vanilla, butter, dark berries, hints of orange chocolate and just a whisper of hops. The flavour is of creamy dark chocolate with a dry roasted espresso finish. Undertones of nuts, vanilla, dark berries/dark grapes, mild sal ammoniac and a touch of hops. The mouthfeel is creamy, soft and velvety with a dry, light to medium bitter and light acidic ending. The aftertaste is light to medium sweet with a honey sweetness that lingers. Medium bodied. Great.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2009 Dark opaque black with fizzy tan head. Aroma of asphalt, light-roast coffee, cocoa bean, fresh nuts. Nice soft mouthfeel but does become cloying. Slight lactic taste but good roasted malt too. Off dry. I want to like it more...Draught at Cock & Bull. Opaque black with thick tan head and nice lacing. A hint of cherries in the aroma on top of a mainly chocolate background. Clean and steely aroma. Super creamy mouthfeel. Finishes slightly thin but otherwise full of dark chocolate. Goes down really well.

12oz bottle.  dark pour with a thinish light brown head.  smells like chocolate milk.  taste of vanilla, graham cracker, coffee, roasted malt.  sharp creamy mouthfeel.  nice bitter finish.  great stuff.

Thanks to mcbackus for this beer.  Pours black with a moderate tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, chocolate milk, flavored coffee, caramel, toffee and toast.  Milky and dark chocolate taste with oats, licorice, caramel, dessert-like coffee.  finishes with buttered toast and sweetened espresso.  Slightly milky all around.  Medium bodied, silky oily texture, yet the body is only a little creamy feeling.  Very smooth beer though and the flavors are all actually a bit mellow, but it‚Äôs still interesting and unique.

I was very impressed with this beer.  Dark black in color with a one finger brown head.  Aroma was of roasted malt and bitter chocolate.  Excellent carbonation.  Taste was similar to the smell.  Very creamy finish.  This is a great beer.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2009 Bonus bottle from daknole!  I¬íve seen this one around but now I¬ím kind of disappointed that I never tried it before.  So thanks to daknole for finally giving me the chance.  This is a superbly drinkable stout.  A good session for sure.  Dark black in color with a small brown head.  Very sweet flavor with chocolate and roasted malt.  There is something really unique about this beer that I can¬ít really put my finger on.  Has a hint of nice sweet tangy, almost sour (black cherries?), flavor that leads into an extremely smooth finish.  Sweet flavors stay around for awhile.  Excellent carbonation that compliments this beer perfectly. Not overpowering, nothing too extreme.  Could be considered boring by some.  But I think it is amazingly well crafted.  Focuses more on balance than just being big and brash. I will revisit this one again soon.

Sample at the Most Honorable SuperHappyFun Stout Tasting:  Very dark pour, fluffy tan head.  Sweet and creamy, packed full of chocolate malts and roasted coffee.  Sweet, moderately warm finish that makes for a very delicious beer that is very drinkable.
user_location: I F&ckin¬í hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: (Sampled 7-6-08 from 12 oz. bottle poured into shaker)  Poured midnight black, non transparent, creamy off tan head formed and stayed to give me some company.  Aroma of dark brown chocolate, darkly roasted malts, and heavy cream.  Hits the mouth with a high-wide body, malt is moderatly heavy on the tongue, the dark chocolate comes in the middle and transistions itself to a mild cream on the finish with lingering sweet notes.  Very mild when compared to the K-zoo stout, but still very enjoyable.

Another knockout from Bells! 12oz bottle. Pours dark chocolate brown with a dark white head. The aroma is slightly sweet. The tastes is exactly what I expected it to be, double creamy with amazing malt back. It‚Äôs beers like this that are quickly making stout my new favorite style.

12oz Bottle: Pours virtually black w/ a small brown head. Aroma is of sweet malts & grain. Sweet malts fade into a nice roasted coffee flavor towards the end. Aftertaste is all roasted (yet sweet) malt/mocha flavors. Very smooth & creamy mouthfeel. Yummy!

12 oz bottle from John¬ís Grocery.
Aroma: Creamy, chocolate, lots of roasted malt and coffee.
Appearance: Dark, thick, and creamy. Very small, dark, brown head. Pretty lacy. Not a lot of carbonation.
Flavor: Malty, spicy, chocolate, mocha, roasty. Sweet like chocolate milk.
Palate: Very smooth and sweet. Light and malty in the beginning and roasty lingering aftertaste. Not a lot of carbonation.
Overall: Very drinkable, very very good. Sweet and lingering. Very well hidden alcohol. Definitely sweeter and smoother than the Kalamazoo Stout.

This beer pours black with little head to speak of.  The aromas are chocolate with some hints of coffee...almost a burnt syrup aroma.  The flavor is very smooth with big hits of chocolate.  There are some definite coffee and caramel flavors.  The coffee flavor is the one that seems to linger the longest.  The body is medium-heavy with medium carbonation.  This is a good sweet stout!

bottle, market square liquor tallahassee. an amazing dark brown or black body with a thick creamy khaki head. aroma is fulll of chocolate, coffee roast, espresso and caramel. sweet flavor of espresso and chocolate. lasting finish of coffee.

THOUGHTS: This was my free birthday beer at the Grey Lodge. It was my first Bells and it was great. Sweet and chocolatey, just like I like my beers. Went down fairly easy for a heavy beer in June.
TECHNICAL: On tap at the Grey Lodge. Poured a dark brown that was black in the glass with red highlights and an average-sized, light brown head that mostly diminished. The aroma was mostly chocolate, cherry and maybe some vanilla. The initial flavor was moderately sweet, lightly acidic and bitter; while the finish was lightly sweet, moderately acidic and bitter; and sour. The medium to full body was syrupy then a little dry with tingly carbonation and a lightly acidic finish.

Bottle: Inky, black with not much head.  It pours thick like motor oil.  It has a sweet chocolate malt aroma with smooth, rich chocolate flavors accented by a bit of charcoal.  The feel is really thick and creamy.  Yummy to the max!
It definately has a good name. The flavor however is all but short lived. IT comes in the end and then its over with.

Off taps at Capital Ale House. Dark almost black with small tan fine head.
Chocolate and roast malt aroma. Rich creamy body. Moderately bitter and slightly sour with coffee chocolate and roast coming through in the finish
Pours a very silky black, with a very nice head.  Very sweet aroma, almost coffee?  Taste is sweet and a mildly smokey.  A great beer for its style

Pours a nice black color with a thin to normal tan head. Aroma is very sweet, chocolate, and some java notes. Flavor is also very sweet, is much like the description, a sweeter, less bitter/dry kalamazoo stout.
Pours a dark iodine color with thin mocha head. Sweet roasted chocolatey coffee notes with thick, syrupy and very smooth mouth feel. Good to great stout.

Pours a very dark brown with a small, light brown head. Smells like a lighter Kalamazoo. Aroma is lightly sweet chocolate, espresso, and caramel. Taste is good, very creamy, the start is light chocolate, and turns a little bitter sweet as it finishes with some coffee. I guess I was expecting a little more.

Not smoother than Kalamazoo but sure is sweeter.  Need to drink during winter time or with chocolate like the description says.  Dark brown/black pour, Small dark tan head.  Great flavor, a little on the thick/heavy side.

12 oz bottle aged from 2006....Intense brown to black body with a brown sugar head...has a milky rich aroma along with sweet malts and cocoa....sweet malts in the mouth along with a toasted malt presence....roasted coffee/cocoa flavors...body is luscious...creamy to silky...just a damn good sweet stout....quite complex, yet simple and enjoyable

Bottle. 12 fl. oz. Black beer with brown head. Aroma of creamy fudge.  Light carbonation, medium to full bodied, and a slick texture.  Sweet chocolatey flavor with some roasted coffee bean that was not as apparent in the aroma. A nice after-dinner brew.

Bottle acquired via trade from moejuck...Joe ROCKS!!!  Aroma is sweet vanilla and cocoa.  Color is more mahogany than jet black and the 1/4 inch head rises slowly after the pour.  Definitely fits well into the "sweet stout" category with its flavors of   milk chocolate, dry roasted coffee, and brown sugar.  Velvety smooth.
A lovely creamy sipping stout.  Not too harsh, just nicely mellowed.  A fantastic balance of burnt malt flavor and hoppy undertones.  Sweet and smoky with a very dark color and thin head.

Pours black with tan head.  Good lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, bourbon, licorice, vanilla, burnt malts, some coffee.  Flavor is rich and chocolatey with some burnt malt and licorice in the back.  Slight coffee notes.  Sweet lactose and vanilla are definitely present.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.

12oz bottle. Poured into an imperial pint. Nose of creamy milk chocolate and a touch of coffee and anise. Dark brown in color with a almost non existant head. Soft carbonation and a much deeper bolder flavor than the nose suggests. The vanilla is there with hints of anise but the flavor is big with coffee and dark bitter chocolate up front the creaminess and sweetness comes in a little on the finish, tempering what is otherwise a pretty bold and dry stout. Quite tasty but not their best.

Bottle numbered 8150. Dark brown/black color with a tan smear for head. Aroma of dark toasted malt, and something like vanilla. Near medium body with mild, smooth carbonation. Flavor is dark toasted, near burnt, malt with coffee and a touch of vanilla. Then it seems more like anise, and sucking on dark chocolate. The finish is nearly dry, and bitter like baker¬ís chocolate. Now the body seems fuller. This is strangely variable stuff. Tastes really good.

Bottle batch 8314. Dark brown with a frothy tan head. Smells of sour tobacco juice and burnt malts. Smooth medium body. Nice blackened malt flavors with a lightly sweet milk chocolate taste to finish. The flavor was much better than the aroma here.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 12 oz bottle from SoLan. Pours an opaque black color with a medium tan head that lasts a short while. The aroma is rich with mocha coffee and dark chocolate. The flavor shows more of the same with added slightly burnt malts, licorice and a touch of vanilla. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. The Finish is medium in duration with lingering biter chocolate. Overall: This is an extremely drinkable stout. Recommended.

Pours a dark black with a tiny, thin tan head.    Aroma has dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, and sweet malt.  In the mouth it is thick and tastes of lots of dark chocolate and a barely noticeable hop bite at the finish.  Not a bad stout...

12 oz bottle.  Pours opaque brown-black with a pretty big dark tan head.  Aroma is sweet malty, caramel, chocolate.  Taste is dark chocolate, roasted coffee, and a bit of caramel.  Palate just about right to make it very drinkable; this is quite good stuff.

batch 7186  aged in my basement.  Pours dark deep brown with a little light at the edges.  Aromas of chocolate and roasted malts.  Flavor is sweet and chocolatey with some bitter roasted coffee notes.  Thick mouthfeel.

Ok I love this beer.  I could drink it all day long. Pours nice and black with a beige head.  Aroma is chocolate, caramel, malty, cereal.  Flavor is smooth, rich and balanced.  tastes of coffee, vanilla, malt.  What a brew.

black pour with a small dark tan head.......wonderful aroma of coffee ,chocolate and vanilla? Very thick and sweet but not too sweet just right. taste id the same as the aroma chocolate, coffe and soooooo wonderful one of my favorites!!!!
Great thick flavorfull beer.  Excellent with a thick spicy steak or even as a stand alone dessert.

12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.  Black pour with brown boarders and a nice kaki head.  Simply stout aroma is coffee, molasses, chocolate, and roasted malts.  The flavor was primarily creamy chocolate with hints of vanilla.  It was not too thin on the palate like most non-imperial stouts; medium to heavy bodied and very drinkable,  Overall, delicious and well balanced stout.
dark brown color, tan head.  smells like chocolate and coffee and malt . tastes the same.  the palate is very weak.  it is very easy drinking

Pours a rich, opaque body with a quickly dissipating brown head.  Aroma of roasted coffee, some smoke, and molasses.  Flavor is rich and full with plenty of coffee and chocolate character.  Little hoppiness and more smokiness as well.  Sweet molasses finish with mild hops.  Nice stout.  Rating #1000!

Bottle. Pours very dark black with a nice beige head. After finally finding out this was lactose free (thanks to a vegan website (awesome how vegans unknowingly help out the lactose intolerant community)) I was pretty stoked to crack open this beer. Aroma is full of sweet chocolate and coffee. Flavor is really sweet chocolate, cream, coffee, and slightly roasty in the finish. Very nice overall, I keep thinking that this is a great beer to recommend to newcomers to the craft beer community.

Dark brown , oily bodied stout with a heavily roasted aroma.   Sweetness is present in aroma and flavor.  Not sure what  the ¬ídouble¬í designation pertains to, however, this stout would be an excellent addition to any fireside chat.

Pours black-brown, spent oil. Cookie brown colored head, dissipates in 2 minutes. Smells like chocolate cookies, slight dog food. Taste is silky smooth chocolate. Well balanced chocolate flavor. Good.

Purchased at Capone¬ís in PA.  I didn¬ít think it was as good as Rogue¬ís Chocolate or LeftHand¬ís Milk Stout, but still a good offering from Bells.  Dark pour, rich tan head and sweet brown sugary aroma.  Coffee and chocolate dominate, as expected.  As the folks at Bells indicate, smoother than Kalamazoo.
Bottle.  Pours a dark brown nectar with a dark head.  Aroma is sweet molasses, coffee,k chocolate, lactose and etoh.  Flavor is sweet and not as creamy or roasty as some of the other bells stouts.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 has all the same qualities of the left hand milk stout, smooth, very dark beer with a slight cream taste to it while giving you that stout feel to the beer. Very good and about the same as left hands, only difference for me is this is a little smoother
Pours black with a bubbly brown head.  Strong hops, roast malt and a little anise in the nose.  Taste is all roast malt but it is lighter than most examples.  A very approachable stout.
Pours black with barely any tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor starts with a smooth sweetness and ends with a roasted chocolate bitterness. Good beer.

bottle.  tiny tan (fully dissapating0 head into black body.  aromas of moderate coffee, chocolate and hops.  flavor is moderately sweet with light bitter at end.  long finish duration.  enjoyable easy drinking stout.

Pours thick black, with a very limited tan head. Nice chocolaty mocha aroma, but not too strong of an aroma.  Flavor is great, excellent blend of milk chocolate and roasted coffee. Very smooth body, a little too much carbonation and a little too light, but an otherwise solid sweet stout.

12 oz bottle, poured black with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of coffee, sweet malt, and dark chocolate.  Not as strong smelling as many stouts, smells good but a little underwhelming.  Taste is not hoppy like Expedition, it¬ís more smooth and creamy, with dark chocolate and coffee.  Mouthfeel is creamy, slightly fizzy, and smooth.  Pretty good stout, but not as great as I expected.  Solid offering.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2008 Bottle thanks to Hellbilly.  Black with good tan head.  Aroma of Roasted coffee, mollasses and powdered chocolate.  Sweet taste of mild powdered chocoalte and some roastiness.   Soft and smooth mouthfeel.  Medium body.  Pleasant and mild.

I was really expecting a lot more from this rated at 97%.  It was smooth but lacking in flavor.  I thought this was the weakest Bells I¬íve tried.  How this can be rated right below Rogue chocolate stout for sweet stout I don¬ít know.  Aroma is roasted coffee with hints of bittersweet chocolate.  Mouthfeel watery and flavor leaves you wanting more.  I thought this was an alright beer but not solid and definitely not top three percent in the world.

This was second of three Bell¬ís stouts I¬íve just tried.  This has a very powerfull aroma of dark roasted malts with notes of coffee.  I couldn¬ít help but taste a bit of overly burnt bitterness that wasn¬ít only from the hops.  This stout is average in my opinion.

Slight milk chocolate, but it¬ís dominated by roasted coffee. A nice, tan head to black beer, with moderate lacing. The tastes follow the nose with strong roasty malth character and a slight sour component. Nice for the roast lovers, but a little too one-sided for me

Pours a pitch black with a lovely thick tan head with decent retention and a fair bit of lacing. Aroma is very interesting - dusty, earthy roots (maybe mushroom?) and chocolate malt. Tastes quite nice, lots of chocolate and lightly kilned coffee, swimming in thick, rich milk. Tastes like a cold mocha-latte. Touch of hops in the finish, fusel notes.  Delicately carbonated (small bubbles) and very thick and creamy, although it leaves very little in the finish. I really like this beer, probably the closest to a milk stout that I¬íve ever had. Not exactly balanced, but plenty interesting, and well-executed.

bottle courtesy of nick76.  pours an opaque oily black with a small tan head.  aroma is of  roasted coffee, bitter molasses, and chocolate.  palate is super creamy.  flavor is earthy with milk chocolate, coffee, and vanilla.

From Puddintane via trade.  Thanks again!  Pours a super dark brown with some lighter highlights.  The head was maybe one-finger tall, brown and didn¬ít hang around long.  Spotty bits of lacing.  The aroma was nice.  Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, molasses/marshmallow sweetness to it.  Some light earthy, tobacco like quality to it as well.  The flavor was roasted malt, chocolate and some thin coffee.  Easy to drink with a good finish.
Probably my favorite sweet stout... Very smooth and creamy and tastes great.. Very drinkable brew that I always try to have a few of...

Tasty brew, thanks kryptic! Poured a deep brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is very malty/roasty.  Tastes like creamy chocolate and coffee, with medium body.  Nice slightly bitter finish that ends quickly.  Very nice brew, would drink again.

Pours a relatively thick, deep brown, black in the glass. Medium dark tan head that settles quickly. Aroma is sweet and malty, with coffee and chocolate notes. Palate is only medium thick, with a fair amount of carbonation. Sweet at first but not cloying, with a crisp finish. A lot of roasted coffee and molasses taste on the end. Pretty good, nicely smooth.
was really creamy a little bitterness,very sweet taste to it though...medium sweetness, lightly bitter,

Hmm.  Thought that ¬íSpecial¬í would mean that something less than 800 raters had reviewed this brew.  Aroma is lightly smoked, toasted cashew stout.  Bad vascular label.  Can¬ít view the computer screen through a wine glass filled with the beer.  Smooth, deft, not very bitter, some green nuts, coffee and roast.  A formidable brew, even if it¬ís widely available. Efferevescent finish with a coffee aftertaste.  Medium-light impression, though it¬ís actually denser than that.    Really well done.  Market Square Liquors, TLH.

Thanks to Mike at Coles for this one! Pours a   opaque with a deep brown small, quick head. Great lacing. Roasted espresso aroma. Really smooth, creamy milk chocolate flavor. Not too sweet. Little bit of a thin finish, but a really awesome stout.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2008 Smooooth.  I can see the lineage up to the Expedition.  At heart, it has that same marshmallow creaminess that I love in it¬ís big brother, but sweeter and more prominent in this because of the lower alcohol and less intense flavors.  Deep dark pour, with a nice rising head.  Sweet coffee, milk chocolate, and malt on the nose.  Same on the palate, with creaminess really becoming prominent.  Only critique is that it feels a little thin.  Great overall, though.  Seems like the very definition of a cream stout.
Pours deep black with dark brown lacy head. Aromas of roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is mostly roasted malt but finishes with traces of coffee and caramel. Nice brew overall, but lacking something.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: On tap @ Mad Mex: Pours a dark brown to black with a tan head. Aroma, chocolate, some coffee, lactose, some roasted notes. Flavor, chocolate, roasted notes, lactose, sweet and rich throughout. Full creamy body, with a sweet finish.
The head on this one is unmatched. Creamy and full bodied. Has a taste of coffee, great coffee. This is the heart and gem of Bells, drink, share, celibate with this delicious stout.
Pours out black with a nice brownish head. Aroma is of roasted malt and some chocolate. Taste is very complex and smooth. Roasted malt, molasses and some nice creamy sweetness in there. Solid.

BOTTLE: 6150.  Dak pour with excellent beige head and lacing.  Aroma is strong roasted coffee.  Flavor is somewhat mild but delectable.  Livens up the mouth with a short finish.  Very drinkable but not very complex or robust.

(USA) Deep brown color with a sm- tan head. There is a slight molasses / chocolate aroma with a smooth creamy toffee taste. (Yummy)  Well balanced and very drinkable. This one will  go down nice and easy. Please go get some !!!!
On tap pours a pitch black.  Tan head lasts a while and laces the glass as you drink it.  Smells like a sweet roasted coffee.  Tastes like a sweet roasted coffee, too.  Good brew.

Nice fine carbonation creates a pillowy head that adheres to the glass. Smells of dark chocolate, roasty coffee/chickory, faint molasses and hops. Tastes moderately roasty, chocolatey, has a very smooth mouthfeel, nice full malt body and sweetness, dextrinous. Very drinkable beer, delicious and would probably still be pint after pint after pint-

Bottle from dkachur, thanks Dan! Deep dark brown color. Malt, cacao, cream and chichory in the aroma. Sweet and creamy milk chocolate and grapes in the flavor. Hint of licorice. Fairly thin, but also tasty and aromatic. Liked it very much.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2009 bottle stamped 8150 on the label poured a dark jet black color with a thick one finger head of tan with great retention. aroma has roasted coffee, dark malt, some over ripe fruit,  dark chocolate, and sweet cream. mouth feel is a medium with a heavy dose of carbonation for the style frothing the flavors across. flavor has burnt roasted coffee, toffee, malted chocolate, and a sweetness that is done at the right level. light touch of bitterness leads to a finish with sweetness and loads of flavor and character. this stout is very good for the style as some thin out and get watered down but this brings on the flavors nicely.

Bottle. Many thanks to Secret Santa for this one. Pours a black color with a longlasting off-white head. Slightly burnt roasted malty aroma with hints of coffee and chocolate. Smoothroasted malty creamy chocolate flavor with some hints of coffee. Has a smooth roasted malty chocolate finish. THanks alot Santa!

bottle.  black pour with very thin tan head.  malted milk, chocolate, coffee, mild alcohol in aroma.  smooth. medium body.  earthy hops, rmild nuts, smooth chocolate in finish.  mild coffee as well. creamy mouth.  well done.  flavors are not intense but well established.

Bottle.  Pours jet black, no light comes through if held up to a light.  Medium thick frothy brown head that disapates in a few minutes.  Taste of nutty chocolate.  Velvety mouth feel.  A slight warming sensation due to the relatively higher ABV.  A nice hoppy finish.  First beer from Bells, but won¬ít be my last.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2008 Bottle.

Pours dark and rich - almost oily - with a modest tan head. Pumpernickel bread drives the aroma, some roasty coffee and chocolate. Nestle quick flavors, full and rich but a bit too chocolate syrup for my taste, rather on the sweet side. Smooth, full-bodied mouthfeel is very nice and marvelously drinkable. It works pretty well, and would be one I¬íd be happy to put down any time, but it‚Äôs just not nearly the masterpiece that the Kalamazoo stout is.

From the bottle, pours a thick black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is mainly of chocolate.  The flavor has some nice malt, heavy chocolate flavor, and a little sweetness.  Not as creamy as I thought it would be given the name, but still very good.  I wish I would have bought more than just the 6 pack.

Pour is dark with aroma of creamy chocolate and light vanilla.  Taste is again really creamy with a strong taste of malt, chocolate, and a cream soda sweetness.  Real nice and drinkable.  Worth a purchase for sure.

Excellent Stout.

Not too sweet like some other stouts.  Excellent Black pour, dark creamy head.  Wonderful aroma and taste.

Leaves a great complex and  smooth taste lingering.

Wonderful, somewhat cheaper choice over the pricier Imperial Stouts, delivers great complex flavors like the Imperial Stouts.

Bottle, batch 8150.  Pours a motor oil black with half finger tan head that settles to a soapy layer.  Nose is roasty malts and chocolate.  Palate is a lot like it smells, with some coffee added for good measure.  Medium mouth feel ¬ñ not as creamy as I thought it would be given the name.  I prefer K-Zoo over it, but it¬ís still a solid Bells Stout.

bottle. pours a very dark brown with garnet highlights, a one finger tan head forms on top and fades down to a thin foam on top. smells of coffee beans, cocoa, and nuts. full rich roasted flavor with some sweetness at the end. smooth creamy palate. finishes with a roasted bitterness. quite a delicious beer, great by itself or with dessert.

This stout was fantastic on a snowy winter night. With notes of chocolate, light coffee cream, and just a shade of bitterness at the end to let you know that it is alcoholic, it does warm you inside. The creamy mouth feel was appropriate here, and if poured in a  two-step manner you get a beautiful tan head on the black brew. Don¬ít make the mistake I did though and drink four at a sitting... it is quite heavy!

12oz.  Another standout stout from Bell¬ís.  I must admit I am a sucker for sweet stouts and this nails it on the head for me.  Almost black body with a tan head.  Nose is mostly roasteds and some sweeter chocolate.  Flavor follows similarly with some latte in the mix.  Alcohol slips on past.

Bottle, poured black, no head. No lacing. Aroma consisted of coffee and little bit of sweet cream. Flavor coffee, roasted malt, chocolate and no sweetness detected. To be honest I think this was a little flat. I cant remember who sent this to me bryan or josh, but cheers to you both.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Secret Santa.  Pours a very dark brown, nearly black, with a thin-to-moderate tan head that setlles into a thin, dense, creamy topping that lasts until the end of the glass.  Chocolate is the most dominant component in the aroma along with some lightly roasted malt and some light tobacco.  The flavor is more roasted malt and tobacco with barely a hint of chocolate.  Lightly bitter at the finish. Nice creamy mouthfeel.
light brown head with a very dark pour. aroma is of chocolatey roasty malt goodness. very mellow espresso like aftertaste. good stout from a good brewer. could definitely drink a few.
12oz bottle. Malty aroma with hints of chocolate.  Dark black with virtually no head.  Creamy texture with semi-sweet flavor, chocolate apparent.  Pretty solid beer, could pound down a few!
Soft and easy on the tongue, reminiscent of Spotted Cow. Not as hearty as other stouts and not something to drink if you¬íre looking to tie a buzz on in a single drink.

Appearance: Pours an opaque black body with a tall, though brief beige head.

Smell: Roasty aroma with notes of smokey bittersweet chocolate, licorice, charred firewood, and espresso. Distant fruitiness. Very faint lactic touch in there, too.

Taste: Roasted malts bring in flavors of Columbian coffee and dark chocolate with a soft sweetness. A complimentary sip of prune juice. Mild lactic sourness. Dash of bitters, one and a half dashes of ash, two dashes of cinnamon. Light roastiness in the finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Bell¬ís has really got a handle on the stouts, I¬íll give¬ím that. For me, it comes in third after the Expedition and Kalamazoo stouts.

It has a little bit of a coffee taste that is common to stouts. It has a good frothy head to it that leaves fairly quickly compared to other beers. The froth a a mildly bitter flavor to it that is quiet enjoyable.

Pours a very dark brown with a nice beige quarter inch head.  Smell is roasted black malts and just a hint of coffee.  Huge coffee flavor in the taste.  Wasn¬ít expecting that at all.  Really dominant. A little cloying in the mouthfeel to be truthful.  Creamy.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with 1-inch loose light brown head that quickly dissipates to almost no lacing. Sweet aroma of coffee and chocolate. Dark chocolate and espresso dominate a mild sweetness that lingers, then finishes in a sweeter aftertaste. Caramel and roasted malt notes appear. Mouthfeel has an unexpected liveliness not promised in the flat initial pour. Similar to an imperial stout, but without the alcohol kick. Nice to sip all by itself. (Note: some solids remained in bottle, but didn¬ít pour into glass.)

Bottle. [Courtesy of wetherel]. Clear dark black color with a large, creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, light brown head. Aroma is heavy malty, roasted, caramel, dark and milk chocolate. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long duration and a dry finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily - creamy, carbonation is soft. ;o)) (220108)

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2009 A great stout from one of the great American stout makers. Very dark, with a great tan fluffy head. Aroma of chocolate, licorice, and roasty malt. Taste is much of the same, predominantly dry with light sweetness. Mouth feel is huge and creamy.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Bottle. Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights. A small ring of creamy tan head slowly fades away. Distinct and prominent wet lacing stays behind. Aroma is strong, and really draws you in. Roasted ground coffee, ginger, chocolate, some distant apricot. Very interesting. Flavors of warm, roasted malts hit the tongue first. Chewy toffee, caramel...nice, viscous molasses intertwined with a river of chocolate. Big, roasted coffee aftertaste. Quite enjoyable. Medium-bodied, oily texture. A nice sinuous finish. Very drinkable, too.
12 oz bottle. Black with a light tan head. Creamy, roasty, chocolately aromas. Roasted chocolate flavors which are very, very smooth. Very drinkable beer.

On tap @ RDF¬ís in DC. This was the first time in a long that I haven¬ít been stuffy, so I feel like I can fairly rate a beer. So with that out of the way... poured black with a tightly bubbled head, about a finger high and tan. Faded pretty fast. The aroma was knockout, coffee, a little whiff of sweet-cream, faintly spiced. Very smooth on the palate. Malty, with roasted chocolate hints, not super sweet, but very enjoyable. Hops were there to mildly balance the toasted maltiness. Very nice.
black pour with a 1 finger khaki head.  malts, malts, and more malts on the nose.  it also has a very creamy scent.  quite easy on the palate and very creamy.

black pour with tan head. Aromas of roasty coffe, minor chocolate, and sweet tobacco. hoppy onset receding into a deep bitter chocolate. Not as creamy as expected, but thats ok by me. Ends woody and deep with a perfect balance of sweet and bitter. Dark fruits play a supporting role though it¬ís somewhat behind the scenes.
Very smooth. Pours black with a brown head. Very creamy taste. Best served after dinner and in the winter. It¬ís a ¬íwarmer¬í tasting brew.
from vintagecellars.  Black with a brown head.  Aroma of chocolate and tobacco.  Milk chocolate taste with a roasty finish and mild bitterness.
Bottle @ Coles Buffalo NY. Decent but wanted to like it more. Black pour with raosted coffee & cream aroma. Smooth creamy body, sweet flavors. Will have to have another tonight

Black with thin brown head. Vinous, sweet, roasty aroma with coffee leather and smoke. Huge body, smooth and rich. Pleasant roasted and chocolate malt flavors. No hop flavor to speak of and low bitterness. This beer pretty well nails the style.
smooth and toasty with a bit of nice cream flavor. The rest of the beer makes a great presence, I feel like this could a vastly improvement . yum yum

Aroma is about as good as the dog kennel of a humane society. Looks decent... tastes like roasted burnt chocolate with a hint of feet. Smooth on the palate.... but bitter finish. I don¬ít like stouts. ¬íNuff said.

The aroma is great with chocolate, cream, coffee, and toasted malt. The appearance is dark brown with a tan head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is typical for the style. Overall it¬ís a good stout.

Dark, no light getting through at all. Nice dark tan head that reduces to a good film of bubbles. Lacing is small but respectable. Smell is sweet malts with chocolate and a definate coffee background. Taste is really interesting dark chocolate overtones with a somewhat coffee presence that makes it really good.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2011 Man, i must be way out of wack on this one, but i didn¬ít care for it. (still drank the entire sixer).  Too sweet for me and i like a finer, longer lasting head on my stouts. The taste is a nice complex one, but the sweetness comes on too strong.  Still, a bad Bells is better the 75% of the beers out there.  I wouldn¬ít kick it out of my fridge, i ya know what i mean.,
**UPDATE**  Had another this afternoon waiting for the "rapture" My tastes must have changed because i didn¬ít find this overy sweet at all!  Very nice mouthfeel.  I think I¬íll have another.

Thanks to MuenchenerKindl

Bottle poured into a tulip glass produced a nice tan head that turns to a nice ring of lace around the glass
It has a wonderful dark black brown body 

Aromas of chocolate, molasses, coffee and tons of malt

Flavors of sweet malts, cream and chocolate with a light coffee bitter finish

Great creamy full mouthfeel 

A very drinkable stout I like it better than the Expedition stout and I am going to savor every last drop of this one

Thanks to kryptic for this brew. Batch 7808. Pours a dark black with a thick mocha head that evenually turns thin and bubbly. Milky chocolate nose with roasted malts, coffee and cream. Nice creamy mouthfeel that has flavors of smooth chocolate, lightly roasted coffee and a nutty cream. Sweetness is well balanced and enjoyable to drink. Thanks kryptic.

Used a corsendonk, (love the corsen glass!) Very dark-black pour.  Nice tall foam of white-brown head, really nice lacing.  Aroma was like root beer black licorice but very minimal.  Very creamy on the pallet.  Tastes of mild coco with definite mixed variety of malt flavors.  Mildly sweet and a  cream finish.

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark reddish-black with a thin mocha-colored head.  Aroma is sweet and spicy, with smells of caramel, molasses, chocolate, syrupy hops, and spices.  Taste is creamy and full, with a strong but not overpowering taste of caramel and roasted malt giving way to a long finish of chocolate and coffee.  A marvelously balanced and creamy stout.

From bottle : Pours very dark black, with a finger of very light brown head, that dies fairly quick, and leaves a film on the surface.  Leaves a thin layer of lacing that sticks around the glass.  Nose is very roasty, with chocolate and coffee notes coming and going.  Taste is very sweet, chocolate, and towards the end goes with a coffee finish, like a coffee with maybe a little too much half and half.  Chocolate milk aftertaste, which is delightful.  Pretty thick feel, and smooth as anything going down.  Bells really knows how to make stouts.

Pours a motor-oil black with faint beige head and some lacing.  Nose is fruity chocolate, with a rich milk chocolate lactose base and roasted chocolate sweetness.  Rich and full  on the palate, goes down very smooth, with a solid malted shake body and gently hopped finish.  Quite nice.  Also, extra points go to lovely bottle design.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2008 12 oz. bottle..Poured very dark brown w/ a tan head. Not much lacing, but the pour was not very aggresive. Aroma was of coffee, sweet cream, and some cocoa. Taste was sweet,  creamy coffee with a touch of dark chocolate. The mouthfeel was very creamy and the finish was smooooooth. I really enjoyed this wonderful stout!

Pours a dark brown color with a large frothy tan head. Nose of cocoa nibs, cream, coffee, roasted malts and light fruits.
Initial taste with light tingling mouthfeel, deep roasted malts and creamy cocoa. Mid palate of coffee icecream, sweet malts,
dark fruits. Finishing with roasted malts, cocoa and minor bitter hops. Palate duration is great and slightly warming. Good Head Retention
and some lacing of glass. Medium to full body. Robust and flavorful.

Dark brown, thick, sweet malty goodness from the great Bells brewery in Michigan.  Nice typical hints of roasted malt and chocolate, coffee undertones. A dessert beer, super tasty but remenber DENSE.  A great stout!

Pours dark brown nearly opaque with large light brown head. Rich sweet malty aroma with a hint of coffee. Dark chocolate taste with a minimal bitter finish. Surprisingly light to medium body very smooth. One of the better stouts I¬íve had.
Good stout.  Better than the Kalamazoo but not the Java or Expedition.  Smooth and malty.  Definite roasted finish

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2012 Feb 2012- On tap at Pinocchio¬ís.  After 5 years, got back to this. It was smooth, it was roasty and chocolatey.  Bumped up a bit from the original rating.

 Jan 2007 - Sometimes I don?t know if it?s the beer, or me. There was nothing wrong with this beer, dark brown pour with red highlights, decent head and lacing. Strong roasted aroma with chocolate. Rich flavor of chocolate, roast. This beer just didn?t thrill me. Ehhh...must be me!

Bottle - no batch number.  Pours black.  Big tan head.  Very nice lacing.  Chocolate malty aroma.  Tastes pf vanilla and chocolate as it warms.  Creamy.  Kind of makes your tonge slippery.  A desert beer, but not so sweet that you don¬ít want another.  Very happy with both this and the Kalamazoo stout.  Will have to try again before Oberon season rolls around.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Mcbackus. Pours black with a brown head, very minimal lace. Nose is chocolatey and mild coffee. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Taste is of sweet malts, minor chocolate flavor and mild coffee. By mild I mean coffee with extra cream and extra sugar. This was wonderful.  I¬íll have to put out an ISO for more next winter.

Probably the best stout I have ever had... Silky, smooth, creamy, with a lovely cocoa-colored head (not too long lasting), an aroma of sweet nuts, vanilla, caramel, coffee, and malt, and an almost-opaque color. Drinking is the same, with a lot of vanilla, good hearty coffee, some sweetness, but little to no bitterness. Definitely a treat, to be had with dark chocolate or espresso cheesecake, savored in small sips once it has warmed a tad. Just lovely.

Shared w/ Juart.  His great idea to try right after B.O.R.I.S.  Pours black with a thick beige head.  Has some nice lacing.  If you can find light that will permeate it, there is a hint of red.  Aroma of spicy coffee.  A little pineapply fruitiness as well.  A mild roasted flavor.  Some creamy taste and body.
