Poured black into the English Pint glass with a half inch light tan head.  Chocolate, vanilla, caramel, coffee and malt scents; Nice filling mouthfeel with a sweet chocolate finish.  A very smooth, creamy sweet stout.  I really enjoyed this beer.
This offering was a bit of a let down compared to other sweet stouts like Left Hand¬ís Milk Stout and Too Cream Stout.
Tap @ TJ¬ís Paoli. This was somewhat disappointing. Tasted like it was old in the keg. A bit thin mouthfeel, with unremarkable smell and flavor. will have to try again sometime.

This creamy stout from Kalamazoo was very smooth.  The velvety mouthfeel of this brew is wonderful.  The taste is nothing to write home about, but it is still a decent beer.  I couldn¬ít taste much of the 6.1% in this smooth brew.  I would try it again, but it is not at the top of my list.

If all of the gods of all of the religions made a stout, this might be it.  I rate this the best of all of the Bells beers I¬íve had, or of all the beer I¬íve rated probably...  Vanilla aroma, pours reddish/black with tan head around the edges...  not as opaque as some of the Bells beers, or other stouts.  Flavors of coffee and vanilla.  I guess I could see how this is a seasonal beer (probably would not rate as high in the summer)... but by the fire, or as a dessert beer, this might be hard to beat.  The Kalamazoo is very good, the expedition overrated in some aspects, this is underrated by a long shot.

12 oz. bottle courtesy/split with Naka.  Pours black with a touch of red.  Head is mall and fizzy with very little lacing.  Sweet, roasty nose, with a touch of lactic sour.  Tastes of roast with some caramel and raisin, a big dose of creamy, sour twang.  Sweet and sour, bitter ending with a sweet after, enveloping some lingering bitter.

Pours opaque with a very dark tan head. Malty nose. Nice roasted bean flavor profile with an obvious sweet tone to it. Thick liquid feel. Nice level of carbonation. Overall, I¬íll say this is a pretty good brew. Hearty with a slight rich edge to it, it¬ís a good enough stout I wouldn¬ít mind trying on-tap.

bottle from Mcbackus, thanks!
After a hard pour, there is a nice brown head sitting atop a very black beer. Aroma is lactic, and mily, with some notes of burnt chocolate, and coffee. 
Flavour is quite lactic, and roasty. A good stout, but the lactic funk gets to be a little much, not my favorite style, I guess.

Draft, Baja Bean, Staunton VA. Black with brown head. Aromas of bourbon, burnt toast/ash, chocolate, and roasted malt. Flavor is bourbony chocolate, with some lactic twang, full and creamy throughout, with a nice chocolate aftertaste. Well done, just not my favorite thing.

batch 8150 - very faint aroma, a dry plywood scent. Very woody taste. Burned wood, roasted creamed coffee, dry woody malts. Not sweet, smooth at fiirst, and a little harsh going down. I had very high expectations for this, so maybe thats why i¬ím a little disappointed. I don¬ít taste much of any cream. A little bitter in the finish also, which i don¬ít care for in stouts.

12oz bottle, batch# 7704.  Pitch black with burnt brown medium head.  Sweet roasted malt aroma.  Very much milk chocolate flavor with some cinnamon, rich dark malt, some espresso/turkish coffee in the finish, very nice.  Creamy full body with a good amount of carbonation.  Another amazing stout from Bells.

12oz Bottle Pours out a nice black topped with a great tan head. A nice aroma of roast malt and light coffee. Tast of light dark chocolate bitterness. A little touch of smoke to go with the coffee roast. Very good.
A cheaper cousin to the expedition stout.  It has a slightly watered down mouthfeel for a special double stout.  Very dark with strong coffee, toffee, and chocolate flavors.
Black pour with a thin tan head. Subtle malty nose. Flavor of malt and chocolate ... like the cherry stout, though, I expected a bit more sweetness. Kind of disappointing.
Scent of chocolate, coffee and carmel, but does have a mild aroma.  has a smoked chocolate taste that goes down very smooth.  A very nice stout.  I would purchase this one again.

Almost nothing for the nose. I find this to be a sweet stout with a lot of character. Very dark but not too heavy. head is a camel color with pretty lacing. Stout fans should drink this beer. Don¬ít forget to serve around 50-55 degrees F. One 12 ounce is plenty for one person.

Pours a nice thin black color with a tan head that laced up nice.Lots of roastedness, chocolate and milk notes on the nose.Flavor is of coffee and cream with some nuttiness to it.It has a;so some sweetness to it with the finish being coffee but not overly bitter.

This was dark brown in color with a tan head.  There were scents of lactose, milk chocolate and a roasted/nutty aroma at the end.  In the mouth this was smooth and creamy but lacking the punch that their other stouts can have.  Well-balanced and quite smooth this would be a nice summer stout.
bottle.  nice lower alcohol contend beer considering it¬ís a Bells stout.  good amount of malts and smoothness

This one really left me asking why, in a DOUBLE cream stout, I could not detect the "cream" at all. Compare to something like Left Hand¬ís ¬íMilk Stout¬í and there is no comparison on which is creamier. This one had a really nice aroma, choclate, roasted malt, cream. Pours a nice black, with a small but good looking head, and a little lacing. Alcohol is a little too up front, despite only being 6.1%. Thick, but not creamy. Some nice flavors going on here (coffe and hops along with the choclate and malt), but just a bit boring. Maybe my expectations were too high.
a very harmonious whole - not too thick, not too sweet but very smooth, lots of action but nothing obnoxiously dominant.  wish I¬íd bought a 6 and not a single
UPDATED: DEC 5, 2010 Incredible creamy stout flavor. Perfect amount of roasted grain flavor for me in a creamy covering. Shockingly better than I thought.
Overall quite a nice brew. Sweet, but not over the top. Thick, creamy taste and feel with a pleasant, roasted finish. I look forward to drinking the rest of the 6-pack.

Pours a pitch black with a thin mocha head and foamy lacing.  Aroma is smoky, charred wood, and light chocolate.  Taste is sweet, lighltly bitter hops, some chocolate and coffee.  Has some presence to it but it didn¬ít floor me or anything.

Bottle purchased at Discount, Milwaukee, into a shaker.  Fine-bubbled head produces tightly held together lacing that crumbles into an oily sheet.  Dry roastiness in the smell with a buttery malt character, but overall, not a very strong aroma.  Vegetable and Nutella flavors, nuttiness is prominent and lingers in the finish.  Pretty full bodied for the alcohol level, nice and smooth mouthfeel.  Roastiness in the finish is nice when focused on, but I don¬ít know how it goes with the somewhat fatty nuttiness and vegetable qualities of the flavor; seems kind of disjointed.  Not a huge fan of the lactic sweetness mixed with the somewhat bitter and dry aftertaste that reminds of the other Bells stouts.  Still, well-crafted.

A nice stout, similar flavors to the kalamazoo and expedition but a little lighter bodied smoother and sweeter, not nearly as bold and complex as expedition but enjoyed it as much, or more, as the kalamazoo.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 In short: Superb stout with a wonderful fudge taste.  Well balanced and drinkable in very large quantities
How: Bottle 12oz from elmatador00, thanks a lot my friend for proposing this to one to me.
The look: Black body with a large tan head
In long: What a wonderful surprise this beer was.  Nose is somewhat smoky with roastiness, ashes and old black coffee.  Taste was just great.  Instead of the expected black chocolate I got this definite sensation of grandma¬ís fudge.  That fudge was melting in my mouth.  That fudge is covering earthy flavours, tree branches and dry grass.  Just the right amount of dry grassy hops to dry it out without taking away from the malt profile (the main attraction here).  Amazingly drinkable, I can¬ít imagine it grossing me out even in the long run.  In the overcrowded world of stouts it¬ís refreshing and even surprising to come across one that stands out and manages to do something different.  That¬ís like a rap song coming up with a new rhyme with the word fuck.  No, even more original than that, a rap song without the word fuck.

Great sweet aroma with a little of what I thought was hop bitterness coming through.  The taste is sweet, more carbonation than I was expecting, then a tad watery (lose points on palate), then some burnt malt bitterness on the finish.  I like this beer, but with the way it looks and how well it laces, I thought it would be a favorite.  It is a good beer, just not the best.  That said, I wouldn¬ít hesitate to have it again, it was tasty.
Mmmm, creamy goodness. Slight roasted malt aroma. Smooth and creamy texture.  A little sweet with a nice malt character. Some coffee, some milk chocolate. Subtle and good is this one. Thanks jtw.
UPDATED: MAY 7, 2008 12 oz. bottle.   Dark brown-black with very little head.  Malty chocolaty aroma.  Very smooth and creamy.  Sweet to start and slightly bitter to finish.  Nice coffee flavor.

Bottle courtesy of Styles. Wish I had not just had Kalamazoo, because this seems somewhat muted in comparison, although still very nice. 

The pour is impressive, slightly more opaque and darker than the Kalamazoo with a nice bit of lace that clings all the way down the glass. 

Smokey aroma, with a hint of chocolate, and a bit of sour cream of all things. 

Flavor is heavy on the malt, with a big lactic backbone giving it just a bit of sourness that I typically would think of more in a dry stout rather than a sweet stout.
Dark color, aroma of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is creamy, velvety chocolate and coffee.  Smooth and easy to drink.  Bells is money.
nothing special about the appearance, but great taste...creamy, chocolatey, pleasant after taste

Bottle at Bell¬ís Eccentric Cafe.  Not overly impressed.  If I didn¬ít know better, I would never have guessed this is a sweet stout.  Tasted very mainstream.  Nothing that made me want another.  Switched to the Expedition stout-- much better.

12 oz bottle. Pours a thick nearly black color with 2 cm brown head that is mostly diminishing.  Aroma is dominated by chocolate, some hints of sweet malt.  Flavors of chocolate, cream, and smoky malt.  Medium body, significant lacing, no real alcohol detected, and lasting aftertaste.  Very tasty and drinkable, almost a pop feel.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2012 Initial Rating 1/11/08  - Pours black with moderate dark tan head.  Aroma is chocolatey, malty and has some roasted nut accents.  Flavor is pretty damn good:  dark chocolate and malt abound, and there is some bitter roasty accents to offset the sweetness...dare I say a hint of tobacco in there as well?  Good mouthfeel...not thick like a RIS, but oily and complete.  Good brew by Bell¬ís!

*****

Update - 11/4/12 - I keep saying I¬íll not only revisit, but re-rate/adjust beers, so giving that an effort with this one since its been almost 5 years.  Aroma is truly delectable milk chocolate - just enticing...flavor is very milky and full of coffee and chocolate - more milky chocolate than I previously thought.  No significant reason to change my previous scoring system, though I could easily tick it up one on the aroma and down one overall - very solid beer!

This poured a deep black color with a thin tan head that left some nice lacing in the glass. it has a nice aroma of dark chocolate, dark malts, and some caramel. There is also a touch of roastedness and cream in there too. The flavor is a blend of dark chocolate and cream with some roasted malts in the background. It has a nice creamy mouthfeel that finishes smooth with a touch of roastiness on the backend. A very nice and easy drinking sweet stout. Bell¬ís is definitely one of the best with their stouts.

Aroma of sweet malt chocolate.  Some roasted notes as well.  Pours dark brown with a creamy head.  Taste is sweet and somewhat bitter.  Mouthfeel on this is great, very smooth and sticky.  Overall, a nice stout with some great characteristics.

I was surprised to see this was so highly rated. Pours a dark black brown color with a brown head that turns into a white creamy head. Smells like smoke and roasted malt. Tastes bitter some what sweet and like chocolate and roasted malt. Nothing special really...

Bottle. Pitch black with almost no head. Smells like a darker version of chocolate milk...whatever that means. Nuts, coffee, some sourness, and a touch of black liquorice. Nice tight bubbles make for a great, clean mouthfeel that finishes moderately sticky. It lingers a little bit in the mouth, but other than that, I¬íd say this one would be a fantastic session beer for cold weather.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2009 [912-20071205] 355mL (w/ PhillyBeer2112). Sweet alcoholic roasted malt aroma. Dark brown black body with a medium-lasting foamy light red-brown head. Smoky barbecued beef steak flavour also has a bit of roasted coffee malt. Full body. Good stuff. (7/4/8/3/14) 3.6

[2314B-20090719] 355mL bottle. Sweet molasses roast aroma is a bit dry and leafy. Dark brown black body with a quick foamy brown head. Lots of coffee grounds and roast in the flavour with a long roast finish. Fully body is a little watery. Drinkable, good stout. (8/3/8/4/16) 3.9
(w/ DuctTape, jerc)

Pitch black with a light dark brown head.  Taste is superbly well balanced.  Not too much roast or chocolate.  Goes down surprisingly smooth for a stout with little/no aftertaste.  Maybe my favorite all-round stout based purely on the ease by which one can put this one down.

dark brown appearance with slight head and little carbonation.  flavor is very impressive with a subtle complexity that is based upon roasted and chocolate malt with a nice smooth creaminess.  the beer ends with a nice balance but no discernable hop component.  very nice

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2008 Just got off the roof after removing some ice dams.  I thought I deserved one.  It turns out that the beer is just the thing for refreshing yourself after removing ice dams.  It has a little sweeter taste than the stouts that I normally like, but the smoothness really makes it drinkable.  Pleanty of roasty malt flavor too.
A solid traditional stout.  Definately sweet but very drinkable.  A nice winter warmer.  Just under the limits to be considered very drinkable.

Pours extremely dark with a brownish white head that quickly fades yet sticks to the side of the glass.  Smells a bit burnt and also like oxygen has gotten to it quickly.  It is sweeter than I am used to but what sticks out is a big burnt, smoky taste that actually works well with the sweetness and makes for another solid beer for Bells.

Tasted 12/29/07.  12oz bottle.  Batch #8150.  Unfiltered and sedimented.  Pitch hue.  Finger width of beige head.  Rich cocoa and chocolate aromas.  Ever so slight soy hint.  Subtle graham cracker grain in the nose.  Full bodied with a rolling palate.  Smooth vanilla note followed by chocolate, then a bitter acidity.  Creamy yet sharp.  Good bitter hop finish.  Creamy smoothness dominates the malt profile, but the coffee acidity is noticeable into the finish.  A dark fruit note is fleeting and faint.  Totally solid beer!  Bells does it again!
Very smooth and creamy, but balanced with a little bitterness.  Almost a perfect balance of maltiness, sweetness and bitterness.  Thick, sweet flavor that fills the mouth and coats the throat.
This is a dessert beer in itself. Lot¬ís of chocalate. Very good like all of Bells stouts.

12-31-07 bottle. 
Tan creamy head over a medium black color.  Nice lacing to boot.  Smells of roasted nuts and some bread hints as well.  Smell is subtle, I like a little more oomph.  Nice, creamy mouthfeel.  Taste has some creamy milk hints in there.  Sweet - but not overly done.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  As it warms, the smell has some smoked jerky notes in there. Would like a bit more smell, flavor and some more bitterness.  But, overall a good brew.
12 oz bottle acquired via trade and secret santa. Awesome dark pour with no head. Flavors consistent within this style. Very good!
I really enjoyed this stout.  Bottle, poured black with a thin tan head, no bubbles at all.  Taste was quite sweet, thick and rich.   An enjoyable beer, quite nice in pairs!

Jet black with a moderately thick dark tan head.  Aroma evokes powdered cocoa and dark chocolate, and toasted coconut.  Thick, smooth, and well-carbonated palate.  Very chocolately on the taste with just enough hop backing to keep it tingling.  Reminiscent of Kalamazoo, but it lacks the complexity.  More straightforward chocolate.  Still great.
Black with some head.  Very little aroma.  Light. Some creaminess but is bitter. Too much aftertaste.

Aroma is creamy and almost sweat with hints of molasses and coffee as well as a sour note.  Appearance is very thick reddish black with zero transparency.  Flavor is full and rich with strong coffee.  All of it is evened out by a very smooth creamy flavor (and texture).  Finish is slightly sweat and coffee with no bitterness.  Overall I would buy this beer again and again.  It seems to have become one of my favorite stouts (though I have only had it twice).

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2008 Thanks to emacgee for the bottle and perhaps somebody else, I¬ím forgetting...

Pours black with a foamy tan head.  Very subtle cream and roasty smell on the nose.  Nice but too subtle.  Some smoke in the nose and taste as it warms only.  Fairly creamy body with light notes of coffee with cream or milk, and a roasty maltiness.  Pretty smooth overall and easy drinking.  Bittersweet creamy roast pretty much sums it up with some Kalamazoo-esque smokiness coming through as it warms.  Nice beer.

Poured from a 12oz bottle (Batch 8223) and served in an English pint glass.  This stout poured a solid black with a thin head of dark tan foam that faded away into a single layer of bubbles.  Just a touch of lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of rich milk chocolate notes, fresh coffee, and some burnt malts.  The flavor consisted of light burnt malts and a heavy dose of creamy dark chocolate.  The mouthfeel was creamy, smooth, and medium-bodied with a nice level of carbonation.  An awsome stout that is tasty and quite sessionable as well.  One of my favorites!

Sampled via 12-oz bottle at Cellar¬ís Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours an opaque dark brown brew with a thin tan head that has some nice retention and lacing. Aroma of roasted dark malt with plenty of chocolate character. Taste is smooth, creamy, full bodied, with light carbonation and flavors of roasted dark malt, dark chocolate with a touch of cream. Finish is semi-sweet with a smooth/creamy chocolate malt aftertaste. This was a pleasant surprise for a sweet stout.
Nice sweet chocolate aroma.  Chocolate and coffee flavor with a nice mouthfeel.  Sweet chocolate and roasted finish.  This is a pretty good sweet stout.

Pours dark with tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and java.  Taste that follows is not far of from the smell.  There is a nice malty thickness to this one.  Not on par with the Kalamazoo. (not as balanced), but great none the less.

Great job yet again Bell¬ís!  This stout is delicious.  Pours like a classic stout with a nice head.  Very dark and rich.  Flavors are barely stout-bitter because of the infusion of creams in the mix.  It¬ís chocolaty, almost like a malty milkshake but with the bite of a well brewed stout.  Definitely a great addition to any dessert.

Larry Bell must love stout. Oily and black when it pours. Lots of roasted malts in the aroma and a hint of coffee. A tad sweet but not something sugary for the kids. The coffee and chocolate flavors make their presence felt with a hint of smokiness and a decent dose of vanilla. Not as thick and rich as the Java and not as classically awesome as the standard Kalamazoo. This is still a beer I would never turn down, not even in July!

This was batch 7808 so that makes it about 8 months old.

A: Dark black with ruby notes and a dark mocha head. I served it in a Sam Adams glass.

S: Dark roasted malt and chocolate dominate the aroma. There is a bit of sweetness, probably lactose, that is typical of this style.

T: This is a pretty sweet beer but with roasted malt in the background. The sweetness is definitely lactose and right in line with the style.

M: Medium to heavy bodied and just how i like it.

D: A pretty good Cream Stout all around. Damn, I wish Bell¬ís was closer...
Pretty black pour with light chocolate head.  Medium mouth feel of chocolate, vanilla,and dark malt.

Pours black with a light brown hue with a chocolate milk head that dies to a thick ring. Laces nicely. Smells of roasted malt with notes of vanilla and coffee. Tasty with dark roasted malt. The coffee shows nicely and vanilla is slightly more than an afterthought. Smooth as silk in the mouth and not as bulky as an impy stout leading it to be very drinkable. A tasty brew.

This brew sports a totally opaque, deep, dark mahogany brown to black body.  A loose, foamy, dark khaki colored head leaves behind dense patches of sheet-like lacing.  The aroma is very malty, and fairly complex.  Coffee, dark chocolate, scorched caramel, and roasted barley are all present in the malt base.  Heavy ream, molasses, anise, and some earthy hops add depth to the nose.  Woodsy, earthy aromas emerge as this warms to room temperature.  The flavor is very roasty, yet sweet and sugary at the same time.  Coffee and baker¬ís chocolate provide bitterness, adding a little balance to sugary notes of scorched caramel, cream, sugar, and marshmallows.  The medium-full body comes courtesy of the heavy sugar content, and it ends up slightly sticky and cloying.  Finishes moderately long and roasty.  Sweet Stout¬ís are not my favorite, but this one is right near the top of the genre.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2008 bottle.  pours a dark black with little head... very smooth and quite delicious.  full of chocolate, dark fruits and sweet malts.  this stout goes down so easily; has a velvet character... I could drink the whole six pack in one evening without any trouble.  nice medium body... flows over the palate - highly recommended.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2008 Bottle. Pours black with a creamy brown head. The aromas are mostly a burnt malt and chocolate. The taste is subdued; a sweet malt, some burnt and smoky aspects, some fruit and coffee, and a metallic undertone. An awesome cream stout. Really easygoing and smooth. Great.

From bottle. Poured dark brown, but not completely opaque. Chocolate, malt aroma. Medium sweetness. Finish was somewhat creamy / somewhat sticky. It was OK, but I¬íd choose a lot more stouts over this one.

Poured black with a hint of red when placed up to the light and a small tan head.  Aroma was of coffee, chocolate malt, and some hops.  Flavor followed like the aroma:  coffee, chocolate, and hops.  Quite smooth with a sweet finish.

On cask at Groveland Tap. So smooth and creamy, as you might expect. A ton of coco and chocolate malt greet your tastebuds, and start partying! Slightly sweet and very easy drinking. Did i mention creamy smooth?!
Pitch black with a very small tan head. Cream, malt, coffee and chocolate in the nose. Awesome mouthfeel. Like drinking velvet. Lots of tasty chocolate and malt in flavor. I¬ím pretty impressed.

Pours a beautiful black with a seductively small head.  The nose is all coffee, chocolate and toasty malts.  This follows on the palate.  Finishes crisp with just a slight lingering sweetness.  An incredible winter beer.
Black with a tan head. Very smooth and creamy feel. Chocolate, coffee and roasted malts in the aroma and flavor. Nice clean finish. Real good.

Poured a thick black, brown head.  Aroma of ground coffee, chocolate, roasted malts.  Flavor is sweet malts, coffee, and chocolate.  It is a nice beer that isn¬ít overly bitter like many stouts out there.
Pours thick and is black, with a light brown head.  Flavor is coffee, chocolate, & roasted malt that lingers.
Pours black with a thick off white head. Aroma is ground coffee beans and malt. Taste is thick, smooth malty, coffee. Finishes nice and clean. Very good.

12 oz bottle courtesy of limesmut.  Pours a dark brown/black with a beautiful light brown head.  The head even sparkles!  Beautiful lacing.  The aroma is roast coffee and some malt.  Flavor is wonderful burnt, roast coffee yet sweet with a medium, creamy mouthfeel that has a dry, yet sweet and bitter aftertaste.  Loved this stout!

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 Dark black with a thin brown head.  Aroma of malty chocolate, roasted coffee and hops.  Very smooth, easy drinking stout.  Nice balance of creamy maltiness with a nice touch of bitter hoppiness.
Dark black with a sturdy layer of creamy tan head.  Chocolate, coffee, and licorice aromas.  Creamy mouthfeel with flavors matching the aroma, coffee bitterness, and chocolate sweet.

Very dark in the glass and impossible to see through.  Aromas of cocoa, coffee and fruity hops.  Light enough beer that you can taste the hops up front, but the real bitterness comes through on the finish, when you get the full effect of coffee and chocolate and roasted malts.  Unique beer with a nice smooth character.

Bottle.  Pours oily black with a thin brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee.  Taste is a little bizarre to me, starts off with a Smartees candy type flavor, but then the big roasted malt and coffee comes in at the end.    Medium to heavy body, finish is bitter coffee.

Thick tan head.  Coffee comes through in the aroma.  Smooth, silky and creamy mouthfeel.  Slight roasted malt with coffee and chocolate also present.  Definitely one of the better sweet stouts I¬íve had.
bottle. black with small crema head.  Coffee, chocolate, vanilla. SOme bitterness, complex malt palate.  A nice brew.

Pours black with light head, lacing consistent throughout. Smells of roast coffee, cream, chocolate. Smooth, velvet-like texture but not quite on the level of a good RIS mouthfeel. Good beer, would buy again. Bargain at $1.80/bottle.
Batch 8215. Pour is black with a faint head. Aroma is cocoa, coffee, malts Flavor is chocolates, coffee, light roast. Body was pretty thin.

Milk chocolate aroma, with a somewhat leafy hop aroma. Dry roasted flavor with a big hit of an acrid astringent graininess that dries on the tongue. Lingering bitter chocolate. Dark brown with a hint of garnet. Smallish head.

Tallahassee, Fl. - Liquor Loft - 12 oz bottle. Asphalt black pour with a tight dark khaki head. Aroma is a bit less substantive than expected with brief hints of chocolate and potting soil. Flavor has some bittersweet chocolate notes, some day old coffee grinds, and a bit of roasted marshmallows. Some lacticity makes the mouthfeel nice and creamy. Overall, a solid entry from Bells.

12 oz. bottle. Pours out almost black with a very nice thick tan head.  Smells of dark chocolate, caramel and vanilla.  Has a nice substantial mouth feel of sweet milky coffee malts with a nice slight finish of bitter.  A very good cream stout.

12oz bottle. pours jet black with a quickly vanishing mocha colored head. roasted malts, and chocolate fudge brownie comprise the nose. medium to full bodied, soft and slightly creamy mouthfeel. chocolate leads to a cherry center and finishes with a fine raosty toasty flavor.

Pours a black color, with a small, tan head.  Lots of coffee in the aroma, along with a kick of milk chocolate.   Smooth body that¬ís full of roasted coffee notes, oatmeal, and sweet chocolate.  Not sticky sweet, which is surprising, considering the name.  Bitter coffee bean finish.  A great stout.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2007 12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Black with lasting brown head.  Roasted coffee chocolate and fresh baked chocolate chip cookie aroma.  Chocolate roasted flavors with mild fruitiness and medium bitter lingering finish.  Full flavored yet drinkable.  Excellent.

Bottle thanks to NachlamSie. This brew pours dark with hints of ruby on the edges. The aroma is of cocoa, coffee, molasses, oatmeal, and brown sugar. As it hits the tongue, coffee is dominant with cocoa close behind. I can also taste some milky qualities as well. The finish has a nice coffee-like bitterness.

Bottle. Pours black with a small but lasting tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of fresh roasted coffee, roasted malt, and dark chocolate. Taste is dark chocolate, coffee, and I think a bit of oats or wheat. Full creamy mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness. Very smooth and very good.

One word.  WOW!  This beer is fantastic.  Pours out a thick black color with a long lasting thick tan head.  I let this thing sit for 10 mins while i was working and it never lost the head.  Aroma is sweet and very malty.  Flavor is had lots od semi sweet chocolate, coffee, and a nice small hop finish to it.  this beer just bettered as the temp went up.

12 oz bottle: Pours a clear very dark brown almost black with a solid tan head. The nose is driven by roast, chocolate and dark caramel. I get a lot of coffee, come dark chocolate and slight hop bitterness on the finish. The palate is medium light and disappears fairly quickly.  It¬ís good but it doesn¬ít begin to measure up to the other Bell¬ís beers I¬íve had.

I hadn¬ít had this in a while, and I was surprised at how roasty and deep the flavor was.  Lots of coffee with a bit of chocolate.  Body was smooth and creamy.  Not too thin and watery.  Quite solid.  Full of rich flavor.  Delicious.

A very memorable stout from Bell¬ís, these guys have this style nailed down to near perfection. Abundant aroma of coffee with cream, milk chocolate, and loads of burnt roasted malts. Thick, dark, opaque pour leaving a dwindling heavy brown head and splotchy lacing. Very rich mouth feel, full bodied with a creamy smoothness that finishes nice and easy. Flavor is very nutty with lots of roasted malt. Burnt and lightly smoked with a pleasing bitterness. Chocolates, vanilla, and strong coffee round out this fine stout. Not quite as impressive as Kalamazoo, but still great.

The aroma was strong dark chocolate with an espresso roast accent and a sweet caramel undercurrent. The aroma carried mild fruity esters and a dark roasted grain acidity. The beer poured into the glass black with a ruby highlight and a tannish well lasting head which laced the glass. The flavor was slightly acidic when first poured and quite cold and became smoother and rounder as the beer warmed. The flavor contained mild esters and a strong presence of milk chocolate and dark chocolate backed up by some caramel and a light bit of espresso coffee. The finish was nicely dry with lasting light impression of chocolate into the aftertaste. The body was medium-full and with a moderate level of carbonation the beer was very creamy on the palate. A very nice stout. 12 ounce bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 14, 2008 Pours a dark brown, with a brown head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is roasted malt, roasted coffee with slight dark fruit. Mouth fell is very thick, creamy and smooth,,,,incredible. Loads of malt of the front tongue, followed by roasted malt, biscuit, roasted coffee, and a slight hint of dark chocolate. Overall a great sweet stout, one of my personal favorites for winter.
Bottle: Not bad.  Pours black with a small head.  Malty and sweet flavor and aroma.  Not bad, but not great.

Appearance: Quite black w/ a nice creamy 2 finger brown head that mostly disappeared after awhile. Pretty good lacing.  Aroma: Subdued but good. Faint hops smell, but mostly malts. Definitely smells like I would expect a cream stout to. Very light fruity aroma. A moderate sweet malt smell is present as well. 
Taste: Some sweetness that is balanced out by burnt malt bitterness. Mouthfeel is bit too carbonated, yet full bodied. A fair amount of coffee in the taste & a bit of chocolate as well. A strong burnt malt bitterness lingers on the tongue. nice finish. The beer leaves a thick coating in the mouth. Slightly dry finish.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a good sized creamy brown head.  The aroma is sweet chocolate with notes of  roasted coffee.  The flavor is a solid mix of roasted malt and creamy sweet chocolate.  Full bodied, sliky smooth finish.  Coffee in the finish.  This is a solid winter offering by Bells.
I don¬ít know what they do to make it ¬íspecial¬í or even what constitutes a ¬ídouble cream¬í but this rich sweet brown concoction is an exceptionally smooth creamy delight.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2008 Very sweet. Tastes just like the Kalamazoo but much sweeter, and with a bit less body and mouth presence than Kalamazoo. A small gain in flavor for a small loss in mouthfeel to Kalamazoo. Overall, very enjoyable.

Bottle.  Poured an opaque brown with minimal cola colored head, no lacing.  Rich oatmeal amd roasted malt orama.  The malt profile has a subtle sweetness and a strong dry bitterness that lingers.  Good and easy to drink.  Full and creamy mouth feel.

A sweeter, more subdued version of Kalamazoo Stout. Not much in the way of hop bitterness, and the malt profile is also less aggressive in comparison to the Kalamazoo. Still, this is an enjoyable stout and easy to drink.

Bottle from batch 8150. Pours jet black with two fingers of dense, creamy, frothy, tan head. This is what I want a stout to look like. As the head slowly recedes, it leaves sticky, creamy lace in its wake. The nose is a pleasant and relatively subtle blend of dark roasted malts (10 different kinds according to the bottle), chocolate and faint coffee. The mouthfeel is medium to full-bodied and, true-to-its-name, quite creamy. It has a pleasant lingering roasted finish that remains creamy without going dry or bitter like many stouts. The flavor follows the nose with a nice blend of dark roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and cream. The only complaint that I could possibly come up with, regarding this beer, is that it isn¬ít available year-round. Before I began exploring craft beer, however, I really didn¬ít care much for the colder months of the year. This beer is just another addition to the list of brews that have given me a reason to look forward to winter each year.

Courtesy of Quake1028. Pours a deep dark darkness with mocha head and decent lacing. The aroma is light with roastiness and faint charred malts. The varied malt bill comes through in the flavor that starts roasty to burnt and slowly becomes sweeter with sweet caramelized malts mixed with chocolate and vanilla. The vanilla gives it a faint cream soda sensation that I¬ím not a big fan of in a beer. It ends with burnt malts and chocolate malts.

12oz bottle, courtesy of someone cool. Moejuck maybe. Black body with a really nice looking dark mocha colored head. Looks like a root beer float head. Nice retention, unfortunately only spotty lacing. Aroma is chocolate cake, vanilla extract, caramel, molasses, dark roasted malts and light coffee. Fore is all of the mentioned elements from the aroma, plus a nice bitterness that isn¬ít really present in the aroma. Medium bodied, luscious palate. Finish is sweet, then bitter, full of chocolate and creamer, with some coffee as well. Pretty lengthy and leaves  you wanting. Great beer. Aroma is a bit light, my only real complaint,.

Bottle: pours dark black with a big, thick, frothy head, aroma of chocolate and coffee, taste is coffee and dark chocolate with a slight bitter finish and a thin mouthfeel.  This is a nice stout.  I wish it would have a bit of a thicker feel to it but other than that no major complaints.

Pours a mahogany brown color that¬ís mostly opaque with a cola-colored head.  The aroma is roasty with notes of floral hops, chocolate, and roasted malts.  The flavor is relatively one dimensional.  It¬ís mildly sweet with the traditional roastiness of the style being the most dominant flavor element.  The motuthfeel is nice and, as advertsied, creamy.  Overall not that exciting, but totally not offensive.

batch 8150 bottle from miketd...thanks. pours a very dark brown with a creamy cocoa head. aroma is cream...both soured and lacto sweetness, chocolate and heavily roasted malts. flavor is full of dark roasted malt ashiness, wood chocolate and milk flavoring (the kind added to stuff to make it taste more like real milk). there¬ís coffee on the finish with some lingering bitterness. medium/low body. definite "milk spit" in the back of my throat.

Batch 8150 bottle.  Black pour with tan foamy head, nice lace.  Smells of coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt.  Also, very slight sour milk aromas.  Creamy sweetness followed by bitter coffee/dark chocolate flavors.  A bit thin on the palate.  Slightly sweet, warming finish.  Easy drinking.  Good cool weather brew.

great aroma, pours thick black suggesting a thick bodied beer, but the taste and mouthfeel were thinner and less creamy than I expected. Roasted flavors are there, but so are sweet estery notes contributed by the hops I think. Either way, very enjoyable and drinkable. I really enjoy this style.
Bottle. Very dark brown body, small tan head receding rapidly, big roasty nose with coffee notes. Roasty, coffee, bittersweet chocolate, less richness than the nose suggests, very drinkable.

(bottle) One of the first stouts I really liked when I started drinking beer, just got around to rating it, and it didn¬ít disappoint.  Pours dark brown with a cream colored head.  Aroma has some sweet notes of milk chocolate along with some roasted and burnt malt, and somewhat of a sour fruit note and coffee.  Taste is nice sweet milk chocolate with a finish of slight charred malt and coffee with slight sourness.  Thick mouthfeel that was very smoothly carbonated, a quality brew.

[Bottle] Pours dark brown with a small dark tan head.  Aroma is very sweet with malt, a little fruitiness and some brown sugar.  Taste is a little bitter, with a lot of burnt malt and only a hint of the sweetness in the finish that the aroma had.  A very subdued sourness is in there that reminds me of one bottle of cherry stout that I had.  Fairly thick, quite smooth.  This one had potential, but I just couldn¬ít get past the burnt taste.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 Had this for the first time in 5 or so years last weekend.  Once again, the hop character Bells adds makes this different than any other "sweet stout".  Not really sweat at all.  Great balance, to me a perfect middle ground between an RIS and a milk stout.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Roasted flavors dominate the aroma and the taste, complemented by chocolate.  It is medium to full bodied.  The carbonation is excellent - the bubbles are just right on the tongue.  Slight bitterness, very smooth.  A great stout.
Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. Has hints of lactose, chocolate, burnt malts, and bitter fruit. Finishes thin and creamy with a bitter bite.

bottle. pours like a thick oil.  no head.  aroma is chocolate with some roasted notes and a light alcohol.  mod bitter hop in taste.  bittersweet on exhale.  great carbonation - fine prickly bubbles. starts out moderately thick and thins as you drink.  ended up tasting like a dopplebock toward the end.  definitely a solid beer.  i had ¬íthe poet¬í a couple nights prior, and this one felt slightly lackluster in comparison.  definitely worth tasting though.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2009 12 oz. Bottle:  Pours black with brown around the edges of the glass, initially a tan brown head that slimps to a thin covering or 
ring that leaves generous foamy tan lacing on the glass, aroma of sweet chocolate, roasted malt and coffee, 
faint nut and some earthy fragrances, taste of dark roasted malt, sweet, 
chocolate and bitter coffee, faint bitterness, medium to full mouth feel that is creamy with a faint oily touch that does not linger, 
finish is pretty dry with residual coffee ground bitterness, very smooth and easy to drink.

dark pour and not as thick as i thought it would be. nice creamy head that disappears after a couple of minutes. taste of coffee and chocolates. light malty flavor as well. my personal opinion is that the taste was well balanced and worthy of a few more tries. liked this one.

Lovely opaque dark brown/black pour with about a 1/2 inch of soft creamy tan head that eventually dissipates to thin coverage and leaves streaky, spotty lacing.  On the pour, the aroma is understated; roasted malt with a hint of sweet cream. Flavor balances toward dry and roasty with hints of expresso and bakers chocolate.  Palate is full-bodied, smooth and somewhat chalky with moderate, soft carbonation.  Delicious.

Pours a dark, rich, brown with a quickly disipating head.  Smells rich, and big with toasted malts.  Taste is slightly sweet, incredibly crisp, and with a nice toasted malt finish.  It should be noted that this beer followed the hitachino nest espresso stout, and it held its own.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2009 Bottle thanks to miketd.  Poured a deep brown/black color with a nice tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts and coffee.  Begins super smooth and leads into flavor that matches the aroma.  Hints of cocoa in the finish.  Very creamy and easy to drink.  I wish I had a few more to enjoy on Christmas by the fire, because for some reason that is what this reminds me of.  Big thanks to Mike for hooking me up with thus beer.
pours black with nice frothy tan head. aroma of roasted coffee, cocoa, with a hint of sweetness. mouthful is a smooth malty goodness of coffee and cocoa with a bitter sweet finish.

Black brown pour with a small dark tan head...chocolate and light smoky aroma...intense roasted flavor, some coffee and burnt toast...rich and satisfying ...nutty and roasty...tons of sticky lacing....bitter and malty...dry finish...Bells has me by the balls..great distraction from the abundant and awesome selection of IPAs available

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2009 Bottle. Opaque black with a medium-large and lasting head. Aroma of coffee, cocoa and slight grassy herb with a metallic tinge. Flavor is slightly sweetened coffee, hints of charry wood, earthy cocoa, and milk chocolate with a slight sour, metallic twang that is not unpleasant. Palate is medium-heavy, smooth and sticky, with just enough dryness to make a highly quaffable dessert beer that begs a second or third helping.

Bottle. Aroma of coffee, sour milk and dirt is not too appetizing. Pours black with tan head, small and with a little lacing. Cream is right! Mouthfeel is almost like milk. Still a little sour tasting, but a good effort. THis is 4 of 4 of my Bell¬ís stout-fest. I¬íd rank them 1) Expedition 2) Java 3) Double Cream 4) Cherry

Black with tan head.  Malty aroma with slight chocolate.  Very smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  Flavor is malty, chocolate/coffee and mild.  Dry finish. This beer got better upon the second and third tastings.

Poured black (of course), appears thick & creamy.  Aroma of malts, brown sugar, coffee and vanilla with a bit of chocolates.  Flavor is full bodied, chocolate malts, roasted vanilla bean and brown raw sugars.  Well refrined stout beer......sessionable beer with friends on a cold night with a bonfire...another great Bell Brewery beer!
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: bottle. Pours pitch black with brown head. Aroma is sweet with sight hints of fruit. Body is mediuma nd taste has coffee and alcohol.
Pours black. Small head. Deep chocolate scent and flavor. I don¬ít taste, see, or feel the cream - definitely not double. Bitter chocolate finish. May have to re-rate.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: Pours out a mystic black color with a fingernail of light brown head. Teeming cascades of tan lacing. Aromas include chocolate malts, bubblegum, heavy cream, and sweet red fruits. Flavors are abundant with malts and espresso bean that join with sugar, cream, and other condiments you¬íd include in a good cup o¬í coffee. Pleasant bittersweet chocolate sweetness upfront with well-balanced malt qualities toward the rear of the palate. Light/medium carbonation and medium/full body. I particularly liked the smooth texture and velvety feel of this beer on my lips. Very drinkable and enjoyable. I¬íd pick this up all the time if it was readily available down here. I¬ím impressed with the Bell¬ís stouts I¬íve tried so far.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2011 12oz bottle from Once Upon a Vine, Richmond. Superb, like a big ol¬í truffle. Rich and thick, with a bit of roast in there, combining with thick creamy milk stout goodness. The finish is ever so slightly dry, making for a really interesting and subtle combination of elements, as if three different and equally satisfying stouts had been genetically spliced into this beauty. YUM.

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark black/brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma is typical stout-smell... chocolate and coffee with neither overwhelming the other.  Incredibly smooth mouthfeel and flavor, chocolate, coffee, vegetable soup (Bells stouts tend to remind me of vegetable soup for some reason...?) Well balanced, full-bodied.  This is a good beer, but there¬ís really nothing especially unique about it.  If I had to teach someone what a stout tastes like, I would choose this to sample first.

12oz bottle, batch 8150.  Pours dark brown/black with a solid, foamy light brown head.  Aroma is sweet malts, slightly smoky, subtle chocolate.  Aroma is fairly subdued.  Taste rich, strong chocolate.  Very flavorful for a normal stout.  Medium bodied with a slick, silky texture and mouthfeel.  I¬ím going to have to do a side by side with Kalamazoo to see which one I like better.  Solid though not exceptional.

12oz bottle.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate and cream.  Average sized tan head left some lace and mostly diminished.  Black/red hue.  Flavor is sweet with a little bitterness on the finish.  Palate is watery soft.  Shit, I guess this is just another beer I don¬ít get.  Weird sweetness and almost expired milk aroma/flavor just turns me off.  Cream stouts are not my thing.

Black beer with dark amber-beige head. Chocolate, and dried wine or brandy barrels; sweet, near-fruity. Dark-brown sugar aroma. Sweet, coffee & cacaopowder; roasted finish, breadcrust. Retronasal like unsweetened cocoacream. Quite velvety MF, despite lively carbonation. Medium bodied, slick. Sweet, but warming stout, nice.  Once more thanks to DaveDave

Bottle from EithCubes - Thanks!  Pours a dark brown with a smaller tan head.  Sheets of lacing.  Aroma of coffee and roasted malt, sweet cocoa and light vanilla.  Tastes creamy like a mocha with coffee and chocolate in harmony.  A little hint of roastiness and bittersweet cocoa.  Nice and balanced.  None of the flavors are competing in this brew.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2008 2006 batch.  pours dark with thick tan head and plenty of spotty lacing.  Nutty aroma with a hint of coffee.  Clean and velvety up front with a hint of cream. finish¬ís with a bittersweet chocolate flavor

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2007 Nice mild cream-whiskey aroma with a faint tint of chocolate. Pitch black in colour with a hint of a brown head. Thick milky mouth feel with a definite coffee-chocolate flavour, minimum carbonation with a distinctly sour-chocolate finish. Very enjoyable (sorry, I don¬ít remember who good willed this to me at Aarons tasting, please let me know!) Delicious.- update, Cheers Jason!!!
Very good beer. Not as thick as i thought it was going to be, but still nice and warming. Nice and smooth,
Not quite what I thought a double cream stout would/should be, yet still very nice.  Good thick taste on the tongue.  Almost a milky texture to it as well.  Good stuff.
Pours black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts and little bit of chocolate.  Good Chocolate taste with some vanilla and malt.  Great Bell¬ís beers.

Bottle:  Pours a dark brown/black with minimal cream head.  Fairly thin in appearance.  Big chocolate, dark roasted malt and black licorice aroma.  Some nutty notes come through as it warms.  Medium-light mouth feel, perfectly carbonated and still quite smooth.  Very sweet dark chocolate taste kicks it off leading in to nut-infused malt bomb finish.  Very good stuff from a great brewery.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2010 
Name: Double Cream Stout
Date: June 04, 1998
Source: Ale Atlanta
Appearance: black, thin tan head
Aroma: roasted malt aroma, hint of sourness
Flavor: mild malt flavor, hint of bitterness, not too much going on

Name: Double Cream Stout
Date: July 06, 2000
Mode: Bottle
Source: Ale Atlanta
Score: i to ii+
Aroma: slightly sweet roasted malt aroma
Flavor: light malt flavor

Name: Double Cream Stout
Date: July 18, 2005
Mode: bottle
Score: ii to ii+
Appearance: black, thin tan head
Aroma: big roasted malt aroma with a touch of sweetness
Body: creamy velvet body
Flavor: nice rich roasted malt flavor, low bitterness, a bit of chocolate, a bit of vanilla
Overall: a great cream stout

Name: Double Cream Stout
Date: January 10, 2010
Mode: draft
Source: taco mac kennesaw
Aroma: sweet chocolate aroma, light roasted
Flavor: rich roasted flavor, caramel sweetness, dark chocolate bitterness
Overall: good solid basic stout

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 3/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: ** /4

Not much on the nose at all for me. A dark black pour with a light tan head. A semi sweet milk chocolate flavor that is extra smooth.  A pretty special maltiness like it has an extra helping or something. A moderate finishing bitter that make it a very smooth smooth beer. Carbonation is good but a bit thin for the flavor. I just expected it to be a bit richer on the palate. A good beer i just don¬ít understand why I didn¬ít pick up anything on the nose.
very dark colour,  has a bit of a roast toffee aroma,  fairly smooth body, seems to have a hint of chocolate in it.

Bottle.  Deep dark brown color with a tight beige head.  Aroma of bitter chocolate, coffee, and something briny(olives?).  Great flavor - chocolate, malt, light hops, smooth and creamy finish, really drinkable.  Nice beer.

Bottle.  Bells is absolutely money in the stout department - they nail it every time.
Delicous creamy, malty stout.  All kinds of malty goodness jump out of the glass.  Dark chocolate, molasses and a bit nutty.  Very creamy and smooth.  My full rec.
bottle. it has a black color with a large head. it is very roasty in the aroma. the texture is quite smooth and creamy. it is also quite chokolaty and slightly smokey.

Pours like iodine w/ a medium sized, creamy froth. Head retention is good and reduces slowly to a full canopy and a fluffy ring. Aroma is weak w/  mildly roasted, creamy malts. Full nectar w/ creamy residual effers. Mildy roasted w/ a balanced sweet and creamy malt backbone. Not real complex but very drinkable. Theres a slight souring that takes place mid-palate. The finish is long w/ a mild souring.

I had a glass of this at Ashley¬ís of Ann Arbor, and it must have been aged because I had it yesterday.  Expedition is too intense for me but Double Cream is just about perfect as stouts go--bittersweet chocolate with coffee and alcohol.
Pored a very dark brown with a mocha head.  Aroma was of chocolate, molasses, coffee, and spice.  Flavor was chocolate, molasses, slightly bitter dark chocolate finish.  A good beer.

Bottle from Hoppymeal: Pours black with highlights and a quickly dissapating 1 finger off white head. Aroma of malts, chocolate and cream. Flavor is slightly sweet and very creamy milky with a slightly roasty and chocolaty finish. Very creamy very smooth. It lives up to its name but i was dissappointed by it not being rich and roasty enough for my tastes. Still very good for style.

Batch 7704 bottle courtesy of john_adam2002.  I tried hard but pours with little to no head.  Some small-bubble lacing, that slowly falls from the edge of the glass.  Opaque, dark reddish brown color true to stouts.  Very mild aroma of sweet roasted malts.  Taste is mild, and improves as it warms up in my glass.  Medium body.  Very light hop bitterness.  The roasted grains are nicely subdued.  The tiniest amount of tannin sourness on the sides of my tongue for the finish.  It sin¬ít that sweet, sort of on the mild side.

Bottle, batch 7808.  Poured a very dark brown, mostly opaque.  Aroma is roasty with strong dark chocolate and hints of toasted nuts.  The flavor is mostly sweet with strong roasted malty taste, very smooth and subtlely complex.  Finishes with a slight hop bite.  Coffee/mocha flavors linger on the palate.  Medium to heavy body with creamy mouthfeel that finishes nicely.

Batch 7801. Beer is very dark warm brown, nearly opaque. Head is small, light brown, frothy, mostly diminishing.

The nose is plush roasted and sweet. Malty with heavy notes of creamy milk chocolate, coffee, roasted grain, light notes of molasses, toasted nuts; Hoppy with a light herbal, light resin/pine; Yeasty with a light note of cobweb; Light note of underripe plantain, intermittent flicker of chicory.

The flavor is moderately/heavily sweet, light/moderately acidic, lightly bitter with a long, lightly/moderately bitter, lightly acidic, moderately sweet finish.

The body is full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is lively.

A lot of personality for the ABV. Beautiful.

Bottle (batch 7801). Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing. Body is black (non-opaque). Aroma is moderately malty (chocolate, chocolate milk, caramel, nuts), with notes of vanilla, hint of smoke. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. A liquid candy bar.  That pretty much sums this up...chocolate and vanilla galore.  Not quite as decadent as one might expect from the name, but if you want that you¬íd already be opening an Expedition instead. Best sweet stout ever?  Not sure I¬íd go that far, but it¬ís great.
Dark roasted malt nose with a faint coffee character.  Dark brown body with creamy white head.  Sweet chocolate body with a smooth finish.
12oz bottle courtesy of mreusch- Dark black body with a small tan ring for a head. Aroma of chocolate and dark malt. Taste of sweetness, chocolate milk, with a dry finish. Great tasting sweet stout.
this ones good. definitely smoother and sweeter than the Kalamazoo, its good with ice cream or cookies. i let it warm up a little bit before i drink it to let the flavor hit a bit faster.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2007 draft.  Nice not overly sweet stout.  Very malty and chocolate with not a lot of hoppiness.  Gently complex but easy drinkin¬í stout.  rr... still good with subtle complexity also including some hops and coffee flavors that I missed the first go round.  I¬ím gonna raise it up.

Bottle. Pours dark, dark brown... almost black. Nice nose: roasted malt, coffee, vanilla sweetness. Creamy with a hint of carbonation on the palate. Flavor-wise, we get notes of roasted sweet malt, coffee and smoke. Quite drinkable.
the bottle had a little age on it, but still good!  Coffee, chocolate and hints of vanilla aroma.  Pours black!  Creamy, chocolate, vanilla, hints of coffee, lacto sugars.  batch 7250.

12 oz bottle, batch 7776 12/20/06.  Pours a dark brown with a thin brown head that goes to a thin film that leaves some lacing.

The aroma is grains, sweet lactic chocolate, roasted malts and coffee.  It improves as it warms but is still kind of subdued - more roast and coffee, less grains.

The flavor is sweet and sugary rich chocolate, a little tart and slightly sour fruitiness, some smoke and nuttiness and raisins with a roasted coffee finish.  The mouthfeel is full and creamy with a good amount of carbonation.

Overall, a very fine sweet stout.  The roasted coffee balances well with the sweet notes.

Dark black color with a thin ring of dark brown bubbles on the surface.  Dark roasted malt aroma with hints of cocoa, coffee, and a bit of a nutty smokiness.  Very rich. full flavors of dark roasted malt, lots of coffee, cocoa, a slight sweetness, a sort of lactic acid element, and a hint of roasted nuts and smoke.  Smooth, silky palate and full-bodied mouthfeel.  Really great stuff, very easy to drink.  This would be a nice dessert beer.

It¬ís pitch black and the head is nougat colored, huge and creamy. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate a hint of licorice and berries. The mouthfeel is semi-oily. The flavour has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, licorice, roasted bitterness, hints of coffee and a light sweetness. It¬ís smooth and delightful! Thanks you so much Linus_stick/Alan for this one, I cannot wait to taste the rest of the Bell¬ís!! 2320

Bottle.  Creamy dark chocolate malt aroma.  Black-brown color with small head.  Creamy dark chocolate malt flavor.  Lighter mouthfeel than with some stouts.  Extremely easy drinking - another great Bell¬ís beer.

12oz. Bottle
$10.99 6-Pack
Liquor Stop
Bottled 12/20/2006

Double Cream Stout poured glossy black with very minor black coffee colored edges when held to the light. A two finger drown head was produced on the pour. After some waiting and this typing it fell to a half-finger creaminess. Looks good.

Smell is strong of bitter coffee grounds. Swirls of cream are mixed in with the black coffee. Heavily roasted malts combine with the coffee notes to for a robust smelling stout. 

The flavor is actually quite a bit different than I imagined from the smell. Big roasty flavors that show up in the front and again in the finish. A milky creamines comes through in the middle along with mild coffee ground bitterness that gets stronger until it meets with the roasted malts.

I really enjoy the mouthfeel on this beer. It¬ís medium bodied but creamy like a heavier bodied beer. Somehow on the finish there¬ís even a little frothiness. Very nice.

Drinkability is good for a bigger stout. I can drink a couple of these in the winter time but I have to be in the right mood. I have to be in the right mood for a lot of stouts though. When I enjoy them I really enjoy them. This one is very nice.

A good solid stout overall. I thought there would be more milk chocolatiness but I was clearly wrong about that. Very nice beer to have handy on a cold night like tonight.

1/15/07

Bottle from Capone¬ís, sampled with the Mad Indian. Pours dark with a light tan head. Aroma of roasted chocolate malts and coffee. The flavor is smooth, sweet, chocolate, roast, and coffee. Good brew.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2007 bottle....nice and clean black pour w/ a small beige colored head....aroma:  sweet malts and not too strong on the roast.....taste:  didn¬ít too much for me in this area. sweet but didn¬ít get too much more in the flavor....above average but there are a lot better stouts out there.

Bottle from Capones, Sampled with stegosaurus. Nice black pour with a thin off white head. Roast aroma with a hint of chocolate. Good balance in the flavor with such tastes as roast, coffee, chocolate and alcohol. A very good brew.

For a beer with 10 different types of malt in it this was a disappointingly one-dimensional beer. Faint aroma of coffee and liquorice, and with a taste of cold coffee and mollases. Really malt sweet upfront, but a thin, watery body - nothing like the fat, chewy character of its big brother the Expedition Stout. A poor relation in my book.
Firs t beer ever rated! Has a coffe/nutty aroma. Initial bitter taste but becomes sweet and smooth.  Good Stuff!
Excellent brew. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and malts. The aroma was surprising sweet. Started off bitter with a roasted coffee taste which faded into a sweeter malt. Seemed very complex.

Faint, but pleasant but pleasant nutty, sweet, malty aroma with anise and cherry.  Tin, very dense tan head over extremely dark brown but not black body.  Tastes starts mild with coffee and chocolate like a typical cream stout, but then grows sweeter as it fills your mouth.  Finally the bitternes takes over and you find roasted barley.  Overall very mellow, yet plenty of taste.  The palate is amazingly smooth and really rolls around your mouth despite the moderate carbonation.
Poured black with a tan head.  Sweet aroma.  Had a great sweet malty flavor with very little carbonation.

(Bottle) Pours black with a small head. Chocolate and sweet malt in the aroma. Flavor is much of the same. Still pretty balanced, however. Mouthfeel was thin, especially compared to other Bell¬ís products I have had. It was pretty good, but not as good as I expected.

I tried an older bottle, and newer bottle side by side at the woodshop tasting, I liked both, but the older bottle was like dessert in a bottle, mellow, with lots of chocolate, sweetness, some roasted malt,very nice brew, Thanks to cquiroga for sharing!

From the Bro out in Ohio.  Poured pitch black, small tan head...rather watery.  Didn¬ít enjoy all that much - somewhat of a sour/metallic hint in the aftertaste.  And the mouthfeel was a bit too thin . . . just average.
very rich in flavor, with sweet undertones of chocolate, yet somewhat thin in the palate. low carbonation...

Batch 6707, picked up by the pops almost a year ago during a trip in Minnesota. Black with hardly any head or lacing. It tricked me, all of the carbonation I saw in the pour seems to have faded.  Nose is chcolate space ice cream, vanilla, but no straweberry. sorry neopolitan. or whatever that shit is called. Kinda nutty as well. The nose, that is. Tastes kind of oxidized, like the last beer I just drank, with mild flavors of chocolate, vanilla, and sweet cream.  Very mild though.  More sour a bitter and just off. I hope this bottle was just past its prime because I can see traces of this being a nice sipper.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013 12 oz bottle pours a dark brown with a tall tan head.  Malty aromas chocolate a little coffee.  Flavor is similar with a great balance between sweetness and bitter roast.  Very creamy and smooth.  Another very drinkable and tasty beer from Bell¬ís. 4/26/07
Always enjoyed in my Andechs 1/2 liter stein.  I"ve been drinking so much of this beer this winter.  It¬ís just the perfect amount of roast and black patent malt.  It¬ís slightly sweet but that heavy roast really balances it out.  This goes down easy.  8/4/8/4/16 3/29/13
Pours dark dark brown with a decent sized tan head, good lacing. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roastiness. Very nice balance of sweet and bitter. Good stuff.
Pours near black with little brown head.  Sweet creamy stout with mild coffee flavor.  Enjoyed it.

This beer poured black body but not as black as other stout, more of a dark brown, and had a lighter head than your typical stout.  The nose was coffee, vanilla with a hint of alcohol, overall not a bad stout, will have again, not as heavy as other stouts.

Poured a very dark brown with a very quickly decipitating head...Smelled like roasted nuts. Taste was roasted nuts, malt, sweet cream, with a very nicely bitter coffee finish. I really liked this. Very drinkable, and all flavors blended nicely together.

Had this on tap, crunchy¬ís in east lansing.  Pours dark with little head.  Smells sweet and roasty.  Taste is much the same, little coffee, and fairly creamy as well.  Nice stout, not their best offering though.

A nice, chocolate head on this stout that calms down after the pour.  Tried it at Crunchy¬ís in E. Lansing, MI on draft.  Strong, sweet stout with a little bit of a coffe and chocolate flavor.  Very good, but I like the Kalamazoo stout better.  This might give me a headache if I had a few due to the sweetness.

Bottle.  Batch 7684 (packaged on 10-16-06) I cellered this one for about 6 monthes.  Pours Black with a average frothy light brown head.  The lacing is very good, it leaves a film from the top of the glass to the bottom, with a head that stays around for the whole beer.  When looking at the bottom of the bottle once it is poured, this one is bottle conditioned, but looking through the glass I couldnt tell because it pours so black.  The aroma in the hops isn¬ít much, but the malt aroma is awsome!!!   There is a really nice roasted coffee aroma along with a slight hint of chocolate.  There is also a hint of brown sugar.  With the first taste it is very sweet with light bitterness.  Then the finish is also quite sweet with a little bitterness to back it up.  The duration of the finish is pretty long, (the bitterness is that of a medium roast coffee.)  The body is extreamly full with a silky smooth creamy texture and very soft carbonation.  Overall this is a awsome beer.  I will have to taste it fresh to see if there is a differance, I also have one bottle left of this batch that I will keep in the celler for a while longer.

NorCal tasting Apr 07 - This is the 2nd beer from Bells that I really didn¬ít care too much for. Pours out a jet black liquid with a nice off-white two-finger creamy head. Aroma that hit me first was a smokey character. After that, some chocolate, coffee and finally wound up smelling like a meat marinade of some kind. Flavor was lactic, dark chocolate, some coffee in there. It had an odd sourness to it that I found off-putting. Perhaps a bad bottle? Afterall I did receive it in a trade so I don¬ít know how long it was made or where it was sitting. Bells makes too many other good beers for me to think any less of them.
Nice roasty coffee nose.  The flavour surprises me by having many lactose notes going on, and a malty cola sweetness.  very thick in the mouth and coating.

Drank a pair of bottles with my ex-boss tonight.  Poured a 1-finger head, very dark.  Smooth enough to almost be mistaken for an oatmeal stout, with a nice roast malt edge.  Mouthfeel is wonderful, rich but not excesively sweet.  A little lacing left on the glass.
Poured pretty black with a small tan head. Aroma of roast chocolate and lactose sweetness.Flavor was pretty sweet, chocolate and pretty smooth overall. Solid beer.
Pours ebony with slight mahogany.  Fluffy pancake head leaves spider lacing and volcanos as it slowly recedes.  Dark chocolate aromas.  Full milk chocolate with a slightly sour hop finish.
12oz bottle-pours a thin brown head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-cocoa, milky.  Taste is dark malt-cocoa, milky, secondary hops bitterness.

pours jet black with a nice brown head, smooth, creamy stout with tastes of chocolate and coffee.  very smooth and drinkable, nice finish.  prefer this style to the imperial stouts, much more drinkable in my opinion.
Black, brown edges, small light brown top. Nose of roasted malt, cocoa, and oats. Same flavor, bittersweet, not very complex, but very good. Medium body, balanced carbonation. Solid.

Dark brown in color with very dark-medium brown head that left a lot of nice lacing. Aroma was decent, typical roasty/coffee scents. Flavor was also about the same. Creamy, as the name states, filled with chocolate and coffee.

Bottle.  Pours a deep, dark brown, with a thick dark head that fills 80% of the glass and slowly fades into the bottom.  The aroma is mostly chocolate malt and hops.  I can also smell coffee in the aroma as well.  Fairly light body, with a sweetness that is perhaps a bit too sweet.
user_location: People¬ís Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Deep opaque dark brown with almost no head. Aroma is sweet and roasty, but not very strong. Taste is thin and bitter, with a sour coffee finish. Mouthfeel is rather thin and uncreamy, and the whole thing is rather disappointing. $4/12oz

via trade with wheninhell  - like all of the bells stouts, this pours jet black. aroma is of milk chocolate and roasted malt. flavor is something like a mocha coffee with cream. this has a nice full body with a sweet lingering finish. pretty good, but not up to the level of the other bells stouts ive had.

Bottle.   Pours black with a decent sized tan colored head.   Aroma is mocha, chocolate, roasted malts.   Flavor is chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, sweet cream.   Palate is full bodied, mildly carbonated, sweet finish.   Very good stuff, though not as good as K-zoo stout.

Bottle from JCapriotti, rating #1500.  Thanks, dude!  Pours a beautiful dark brown with haunting black highlights.  Slight head of dusk white, with lacing to frighten even the most pure of heart.  A sinister aroma of coffee-infused chocolate permeates the silence;  can you hear the creaking of the staircase?  Layers of velvety chocolate and coffee caress the tongue like the soft hands of a clock at midnight; the bell tolls for thee, my friend.  Notes of roasted nut and caramel seem to pierce the darkness.  The palate is tickled by spikes of nutty coffee and chocolate.  A smooth beer for a dark, stormy night.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Dark with brown head.  Nose of chocolate hints of spice.  Flavor is of roasted coffee and chocolate.  Body is medium.  Texture is great, has a great mouth feel with the finish of sweet and smooth.

Bottle (Batch 7733). Poured black with a tan head that lasted and left lacing. The aroma was of chocolate, mocha, and roast. The flavor found mocha, roast, and a hoppy background with just a slight hint of alcohol. Medium to full body with a sweet yet roasty coffee aftertaste.
Lots of smooth chocolate in the aroma.Pours black with a medium tan head.Roasted malt and slight chocolate stand out in the flavor.Thin to medium mouthfeel with a roasted malt finish.

One of my favorites.  Almost black with a tiny tan head.  Light aroma of chocolate and caramel.  Tastes of chocolate and roasted nuts.  Very little alcohol taste despite being 7.5%.  Its not as creamy as I epected but still very excellent.  Washes hot wing sauce away like nothing else.

Poured very dark brown with nice dark tan foam. Really nice lacing. Aroma is predominantly chocolate with some roastiness. Taste is very chocolately with mild nuts and coffee. Very little roasted flavor. Not too sweet. Very little alcohol comes through. Nice balance. Mouthfeel is not quite as thick as I expected. Very drinkable as a dessert drink or nightcap.

12oz bottle.  Aroma:  Lots of sweet roasted malt with some coffee and chocolate overtones, caramel, cream, slight vanilla and hazelnut.  Appearance:  Dark black in color with no highlights.  Light tan head was full and frothy with good retention.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  A little sweeter here than in the nose.  Coffee, caramel, chocolate, strong creaminess, slight anise and vanilla, and some light cherries.  Medium-low bitterness.  Fairly clean finish.  Palate:  Medium-full bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall:  Another solid beer from Bells.  Not my favorite in the style, but pretty good.

A bit of a chance with this one. I have never had such a dark and complex beer as I never thought I would like them. Some friends and I decided to have a beer tasting and discussion and this was one of my choices. I can say that I am glad I took a chance on this one. Opened a chilled bottle and poured into a large glass. The beer was dark and had a nice lighter color head. Once I let the foam settle, I took a sniff and was surprised that it didn¬ít smell really burnt or roasted. Took a sip and was surprised at the smoothness. It didn¬ít have a bitter taste or aftertaste to it. The flavor had hints of chocolate and coffee to it. A very enjoyable brew.
Big beer baby, big beer! can wrASSLE wi thisun. velvety delicioius, kindof feel like I¬ím bein lead down the primrose path and ah laks it. dang. Oh well.

Bottle. Dark pour with nice size head. Aroma is of roasted malt, caramel, slight chocolate and vanilla. Flavor is sweet with caramel and melt blenidn with the subtle chocolate tones and a small amount of vanilla left on the tongue. Well carbonated and full flavored. Good stout but what else do you expect from Bell¬ís.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2016 On tap at Taphouse on Queensway in Hampton.  This is solidly black with a thin tan head.  The aroma is whiskey-laced and smoky; the beer has a big stick-to-your-ribs consistency.  As I drink I get more bourbon character, dark cherry fruit.  Don¬ít get the "cream" with this one, but this is an excellent stout.  I had a couple.  (#2743, 3/10/2007) <<Rerated from bottle, 1/2/2008 ... similar impressions.  Excellent flavorful stout.

poured a small sample from a bottle. this has always been one of the bells beers i¬íve never gotten into. black color with nice tan head. flavor is very creamy, low roastiness, chocolate, and sorta sweet. drinkable, fine, but boring.

Pours dark brown/black with lacy chocolate head. smells of sweet malts and dark fruits. Flavor is sweet and creamy with a strong chocolate and roasty aftertaste. Very drinkable..a  nice stout but I was expecting something more
UPDATED: MAY 5, 2007 Bottle.  Aroma of roasted coffee and vanilla.  The flavor is similar to the smells, but creamy and not overpowering.  Slightly bitter finish.  Decent beer.

Bottle - black pour with brown highlights and a brown cola head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, caramel and chocolate.  Flavor is roasted malts/coffee, chocolate with a sweet favor that gives way to a slight hop dry finish.  Single bottle sample.

Pours a very thick black with a hazy light tan head.  Very inviting looking.  Very nice coffee and dark malts, light chocolate in the smell.  A little roastiness as well.  Very creamy in the taste, some light chocolate and caramel but pretty subtle.  Some roasted malts in the finish are evry nice.  Another gret stout from Bell¬ís.  They never disappoint.
12 oz bottle acquired via trade.  Black in color with a brown head.  Aroma: is coffee, sweet malts.  Taste is coffee, sweet malts, quite a smooth stout.  nicely done.

Black, dark brown head. Coffee-ish, roasty aroma, very, uh, is there a word that means "loud", but for smells? It smells loud. The aroma screams at you. Smooth and rich. Big coffee flavors,  and a burnt toast note too. Hints of dark chocolate and vanilla throughout. Really tasty.
Draft Pint, wonderful mouth feel,  malty and sweet,  coffee without the bitterness, dry at the end,. I¬ím in agreement with most if the other posts.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2007 (bottle) Pours like motor oil with a brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt and hints of mocha.  Lots of carbonation, clashing with malts, strong cofee presence; unpleasant chalking taste.  Slight bitter after taste thats relatively clean.  Overated!  Try their porter.
________________________________
I take back what I said! Turns out that the reason it tasted chalky is because I drank it out of mulike stein.  Much better in an eglish pint.  Very good sout.  How could I actually consider that this brewery could make a bad stout! My apologies.  My original review was a 2.9 overall.

Pours clear and nearly black with a nice big brown creamy head which diminishes quickly. Smells like choclate chip cookies and dark coffee. Also maybe a bit of banana and toffee. Medium bodied with minimal carbonation...fairly creamy textured. Heavy smokey flavor...more coffee. Okay, but only OK...

Dark color.  Smell of chocolate, caramel, smoke, hops, roasted malt and some wood/oak.  Taste of malt, bitter chocolate, hops, malt, hint of smoke and caramel at the end.  This was one of my favorite stouts when I first began drinking beer two years ago and still is a very enjoyable stout.
12 oz. beer at flat rock saloon.  Pours black with thick khaki head.  Sweet, slightly roasty nose.  Malty and sweet, nicely balanced.  Very smooth and drinkable.  Excellent stout.

Poured a nice brown/black with a thin layer of bubbly tan head. At first the aroma seemed somewhat muted, but that was probably because it was too cold. As it warmed up, the beer revealed it¬ís lovely sweet coffee and milky aroma, with chocolate creeping in there at times. Unfortunately, the taste didn¬ít quite follow through. I had to really swirl it around for a while before I could get a real definitive taste. Beforehand, it didn¬ít really have much of a taste, maybe a faint milkiness at best. After doing so, there was a bit of coffee and malty sweetness. I let it warm up some more, but it didn¬ít do much good. What it did do however, was accentuate the finish, which also ended up being very good. It was way more pronounced, yielding a delicious sweet coffee flavor without too much bitterness.  Based on the aroma I had high hopes for this one, but the taste just didn¬ít deliver.  On the bright side, the finish was almost certainly the best aspect of this beer, suitable for all tastes (unless you¬íre really averse to coffee). I just hope I got a subpar batch.
Tasty sweet stout.  Pours pitch black with a mocha head.  Buttercream frosting and oak aroma.  Smooth malty flavor of chocolate and smoke with a hop edge.  Nice in the mouth.
UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 Best cream stout I¬íve found. One of best stouts I¬íve tried. Well balanced and amazingly smooth. No funkyness to the lactic aspect. Great moutfeel and finish/aftertaste.
Pours black with a mocha head.  Smells of chocolate and coffee.  It has a nice roasted coffee flavor that goes down smooth and rolls around like velvet in your mouth.

Bottle. Pours a dark black color with a nice tan head on top. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, and hops. Flavor is pretty light and watery with hints of chocolate and roasted malts coming in. The beer finishes dry with a espresso/coffee taste lingering. I wish the beer had a more robust taste throughout instead of just a hint right at the first sip. The beer definitely tastes as if it can have a potential but unfortunately falls a little short.

Bottle from shigadeyo, Thanks, Craig! Noble hops in the nose. Medium-light body with medium carbonation. A sort of un-stoutlike wateriness to the body. Not a lot of flavor - seems like a vacant interpretation of the milk stout style. Dry finish.

12-oz., courtesy the kind hospitality of BitBucket. Pours deep black with a thin off-white head. Tiny bit of sour funk on the nose. Almost wild yeast-like. Hollow body--roasty, but the emptiness makes the flavors too subdued. The attack and the finish just wither there. Not much happening. Really a disappointment.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2007 Black with tan head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma was of chocolate, malt, hops, and oak.  Flavor was similar except with some syrup sweetness.  Tingly with carbonation and alcohol taste in the mouth, which distracted from the flavors.  Finish was crisp and bitter.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2008 poured a rich black color with a light brown head that didn¬ít last very long. Aroma nice blend of roasted malts and chocolate. Flavor is delicious balance of smooth chocolate and perhaps creamed coffee. Also got some oat flavors mixed with the malt. Wasn¬ít as creamy as I expected, but tasty and easy to drink. Another nice one from Bells.

Bottle, pored a deep, deep mahogany (sp?) with a thin dark tan head.  Aromas of roasted malts and hoppy bitterness.. Smooth flavor, pretty standard for sweet stouts.  Good flavor, but nothing all that exciting.  Another nice beer from Bell¬ís.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Nice beer, as I continue to try Bells products, I must say I am impressed.  Dark color of course, and minimal head.  Flavor is chocolate, malt, coffee, and smokiness.  More smoke than I expected though, which threw me a bit.  Otherwise really nice beer...creaminess at the very end.
12 oz bottle. Pours black in color with brown head. Not much aroma, malt, chocolate and coffee aroma and taste.
A dark, smooth, thick beer with a smoky, malty quality. Dark tan head that holds well. Complex, deep, dark flavor.
