Oily, waxy feeling on the palate, with substantial staying power.  Head finally subsided about half way through, becoming a floating cap of fluff that shifted with each sip.  This is one complex stout.

Pours a deep black with a dark brown head.  Aroma is chocolatey, rich and malty.  Taste is delicioius, very full bodied, soft, very creamy maltiness, slightly roasty.  Sweeter than expected finish with balanced bitterness.  Loaded with flavours.

I was saving this bottle for a sunny winter day and it was more than worth the wait!  Dark brown pour with a medium creamy brown head and lacing that clung to the glass like sheets of velour.  Rich aroma of roasted malt, toffee, cohocolate, coffee & vanilla.  Beautifully balanced flavors of dark chocolate, more roasted malt, smooth coffee and just a hint of alcohol.  Finish was long, sweet and had a touch of vanilla.  Bell¬ís brews are next to impossible to find in south jersey and I found this gem at the Foodery in Philly.  I know where I¬ím going tomorrow.......

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2005 Thanks to Mr. Facto for this beer.

Ah, it¬ís been so long since I¬íve had a Bell¬ís Stout... I¬íve been looking forward to this.  As I open the bottle, I am instantly hit with the powerful aroma of cream and chocolate, with just the smallest hint of coffee.  I¬íve never smelled a stout quite like this.  It poured black with a creamy tan head.  (Should I expect anything less from Kalamazoo?)  As I bring the stout to my lips, something interesting happens.  Unlike Kalamazoo Stout or Expedition, which blanket the mouth, Double Cream slips like water on a ducks back across my tongue and down my throat.  Wow, this is the smoothest stout I¬íve ever had.  It¬ís so smooth that I have to actually swish it in my mouth to get the full flavor, which is coffee with half and half and a touch of sugary chocolate.  This literally could supstitute a cafe breve (that¬ís a cappuccino with steamed half and half instead of milk).  The aftertaste is mostly coffee.  In the world of the stouts, my alliance has always been most firmly with the camp of the sweet.  And this is the creamiest sweet stout I¬íve had the pleasure of trying.  If I have one complaint with this beer, it¬ís that I wish the body were as full as its aforementioned counterparts, Kalamzoo and Expedition.  If this beer had that body, it would truly be the holy grail of sweet stouts.  But being so damn close still makes this a beer worth seeking out.  I¬ím now very thankful that Facto sent me two, for I have one to save for another occasion.
UPDATED: MAR 1, 2005 Tastes like a vanilla ice cream and beer float. delicious, my moms boyfriend stole my last two, so i almost whomped him in the nads

What a treat!.  Pours a darkk brown/black opaque body with thin light brown head.  Aroma is strong in roasted malts, and slight coffee, and chocolate.  Tatses is sweet malts, and roasted nuts.  Great taste.  You can Hardly notice the alchol, it is so smooth and creamy, like butter on the throat.  Very slight bitterness left with mild coffee.  Awsome beer!!!

Huge thanks goes out to BUNKYPOP for this one!!! What an incredible beer.
Pours a dark brown, almost black body. Head is thin, mocha coloured. Aromas are intense roasted and sweet malts, nuts, coffee and chocolate. Reminds me of almost a mudslide because there¬ís a slight boozy aroma here too, though very plesant. Taste is sweet, huge malt, roasted nuts, dark chocolate and some espresso. Mild bitterness as well. Finish is incredible creamy. Smooth mouthfeel....mild alcohol and coffee finish. What a great example of the style! Thanks again Steve!
Very dark to no surprise but, there wasn¬ít as much head as I expected.  This was really smooth almost a oil taste to it.  This was better than I expected since I really don¬ít like the style.
Smooth and pleasant roastiness in the aroma. Almost completely black body, with no head. Sweetish flavor, roastiness and plums. Decent one.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2006 RERATE: I¬ím digging this more than last time. Pours black as death with a large light brown head. Aroma of mocha, roastiness, smoke, hops and a tinge of sourness. The flavor starts off with massive notes of mocha/chocolate, sweet caramel, roastiness then gives way to a little lactic sourness and a bit of saltiness - pretty interesting. Moderately sweet. Roasty coffee, chocolate ice cream aftertaste. Very creamy, lush and silky with lively small-beaded carbonation which makes the flavor gently ripple over your tongue. Lacing hangs on the glass in sheets, decent head retention. Great stuff. Bells gets my vote for King of Stout.

Tap at Blue Nile, Minneapolis.  Gorgeous looking stout.  Couldn¬ít discern much aroma.  I agree with Wawood that it feels nothing like 7.5% alcohol, as the lightly creamy body brings forth light milk chocolate and decaf folgers--not any alcohol flavor to be found.  Rather light in flavor for the rich name, but a tasty treat nonetheless.

This beer looked good out of the bottle, dark black pour with three finger brown head.  Creamy chocolate feel in the mouth, left me wanting something more.  Misses on the finish, wish it was more a of "heavy-hitter."

Draught at Blue Nile. There¬ís no way this is 7.5%. If that is the case, it still needs more alcohol. Dry chocolate and coffee aroma. Opaque body, excellent lace. Chocolate is the predominant flavor. Nice lace. Creamy. Significantly overrated.
Pours dark black with thin khaki head.  Aroma is sweet, chocolate, malty, toffee, good! Flavor is the same, but with a tangy quality. I like it.

english pint, room temp. / the body is blacker than midnight, hence no highlight. the head is huge, sparkly, tight, rocky, and... awesome. a lot of resiny lace is left, also. and whaddayaknow, this is a rich, smooth, sweet stout. an excellent brew with flavors primarily analogous to slightly burnt chocolate chip cookies, a bit of coffee and spice, and a pinch of fruitiness.

Cheers to MrFacto for generously providing a bottle for our tasting.  Black with a thin head that appears light tan in color.  Deep aroma highlighting decadent malts (chocolate, coffee, roast) along with a touch of cream for coffee and gingerbread.  Rich and chewy malt flavor with notes of chocolate, coffee and brownies.  Another very special Bell¬ís stout.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2006 Pours a deep black, yeast sediment very heavy, as is the case with all Bells.  Head is apprpriate, lacing is excellent.  Aroma is toffee, tobacco, and mild hops.  Flavor is sweet, toffee gives way to chocolate, which in turn gives way to coffee, then mild and grassy, and a long, dry, bitter finish.  Excellent stuff, but that was expected.  Amazing when paired with milk chocolate.

Bottle courtesy of Styles: Deep, dark brown, completely opaque, medium brown head that slowly fades to a ring with nice lacing.  Aroma is bread, coffee, roasted malt, burned malt, butter.  Palate is very creamy, thick, full.    Flavor is bitter roasted malt, butter, creamy chocolate, pine & citrus hops, plum, carob, marshmellow, dark caramel, bitter chocolate, mildest alcohol, fruit.  Amazing palate, sweet dry finish.

bottle. Pitch black, mocha head and lace. aroma consists of a lot of coffee, bread,  and creamy chocolate. creamy mouthfeel. flavour is bursting forth with coffee goodness. very rich.  some bitter chocolate in the finish. it¬ís a good stout, but it didn¬ít really blow me away.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2005 Pours black with a small tan head.  Aroma of butter and uncooked cookie dough. The taste is also butter with hints of chocolate. I dont know about this beer. It tastes like I should be dipping my lobster in it and not drinking it. Very sweet taste and aftertaste.

Dark black hue.. dark tan head light cola aroma.. pear and apple blended into the complexity of the aroma and flavour.. Mustiness the 10 malts compeat with eachother to form a complex flavour... Light smooth oily palate.. very good ......light carbonation....

Bottled. Darkest billowy brown head I¬íve seen in a while. Solid black body. Smell of deep roasted cocoa, chicory and carob. Taste is initially creamy, like toasted marchmallows. I also get impressions of polished walnut, sassafrass, loam with nightcrawlers (oh, that¬ís a good thing). Very warming alcohol leaves me a bit heady. Marred only by slightly burnt offerings further down.
Average aroma. Beautiful mahogany head. Nice flavor with nutty and toasted notes. Smacks of caramel and coffee.  Carbonation is light, alcohol makes an appearance. Excellent!

Tasted at the Great Madison St. Stout Off, from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass.  Loved the fresh cream aroma off this and this one is smooth and sweet and flat out one of the best tasting beers Ive ever had.  Light brown bubbling head on a pitch black body. This one is close to perfect for me.

I¬íve had better batches of this beer, but this is the one I¬ím rating so, here goes.  Seems a bit oxidized and overly harsh.  Not nearly as smooth as you¬íd think it should be.  I prefer expy or Kalamazoo to this one.  Maybe its sat on the shelf for a while..not sure.
BOTTLE. MODERATE MALTY, LIGHT BREAD AND LICORICE AROMA. MEDIUM FROTHY, LIGHT BROWN HEAD THAT HELD TO FINISH. MODERATE SWEET FLAVOR. FINISH WAS FULL, CREAMY WITH LIGHT ASTRIGENT.

First, I have not been a fan of Stout¬ís in general. But this is the CREAM of the crop. A perfect balance of sweet & bitter (bitter is better) Hint of chocolate, mocha ...nice after taste  Chicago in the winter Yah

Bottle, from Duane, Thanx! Pours a rich dark brown with thick creamy, huge, tan head.  I have let this warm a bit, as the head resides, it leaves nice lacing. The aroma is sweet, chocolate, roasted dessert like.  The first taste is full of chocolate and a good bit of bitter, like Belgian dark chocolate.  There is a bite from the carbonation, but this pleasant kick helps blend the bitter and sweet. It is almost like a chocolate mousse cake. I loved this.
Pours near opaque with a bit of carbonation.  Nice mouthfeel.  Great thick head and a great roastiness to boot.  Can¬ít wait to try the regular stout as well.
bottle.  pours a rich, reddish brown with a nice head.  a pretty good stout but I thought the Kalamazoo stout was a little bit better.

Bottle. brentfeesh sent this one in a trade.  Kudos again Brent!  Pours as black as my old girlfriend¬ís heart.  Minimal head that dissipates to a thin layer of dark amber bubbles.  Nose is awesome... just like walking into a real coffee shop (not Starbucks) that has 100 year old wooden walls and the old aromas have buried themselves in their surroundings and yet they still mesh with the new aromas from the freshly brewed coffees and teas of today and create a great atmosphere.... That¬ís the nose of this beer.   Sweet and malty and cocoa and vanilla, and .... I¬ím missing something, but the aroma rocks.  Body is creamy and smooth with slight and fizzy carbonation. The taste is sweet with a slight twang that rides down the throat with the heavy espresso flavor... not perfect, but not bad.  Not sure what that twang is, and it doesn¬ít ruin the brew, but it does keep from being top-notch in my book.  Not bad stuff, but doesn¬ít finish as well as dry or imperial stouts. Still a nice beer.
A pitch black beer with a dark brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of coffee and chocolate. The flavor is sweet with notes of alcohol and coffee, but some sour carpet notes in the aftertaste.
Creamy, creamy, creamy...No wait, that would be Bells Triple Cream Stout.  Absolutely one of my favorites with a mocha aftertaste that goes on and on and on...

Bottled: Red/brown coloured. Off white medium sized dense head. Roast, berries, coffee and hops in the aroma. Flavour is roasted and sweet. Loads of coffee and chocolate notes. Ends with a balanced bitterness on the palate. Good one. Thanks Santa BBB63.

Bottle, dark brown with red tones, minimal head with medium lacing, smells of malt, chocolate, and some earthy tones, taste is sweet at first, mild hint of fruity bitterness at beginning, chocolate takes over and ends with mild earthy notes.  i like it.

Bottle: Poured a deep brown-black with a creamy tan head that held up well. Aroma of chocolate, black malt, coffee and sweet cream. Flavor is incredibly smooth and sweet, a hearty dark chocolate malt and cream, almost like a malted milkshake. Some light fruitiness noted, along with a hint of bitter hops. Creamy mouthfeel, would be better on tap. Finished was bitter and satisfying, slightly warming alcohol hints. A delicious sweet stout, almost as good as Kalamazoo Stout, but still a worthy contender.

Jet black in colour with a small off white head. The aroma is dominated by sweet chocolate (think chocolate chips), with more subtle notes of espresso, roasted malt, and a fruit element that I can¬ít quite identify (perhaps plum?). Upon drinking, the chocolate becomes a little less sweet, and takes on more of a powedered cocoa flavor. There¬ís also a bit of a yeasty note with a bit of leafy hop bitterness at the end. The sweetness is a little less than I expected, but well within stylistic guidelines. I had hoped for a bit more body too, but again, it¬ís not as if it¬ís thin. I tend to want sweet stouts to completely bowl me over with sweetness and thick mouthfeel... I found this one to be a bit on the tame side, but still a quality beer.

Black color but lessening into a brown color though still opaque and a dark tan head.  Big cream aroma, dark yeast fruit (though well-integrated and not overdone) and coffee.  This is one of my favorite stouts.  A solid body, a nice dollop of hops and acidity at mid palate, and sweetness coming back into a solid stout finish.  Complexity of flavor includes malted milk, fruit cake, crystallized sugar, espresso dryness, and a warm, alcohol background.

Nice dark color, subdued aroma, mostly malty. I smell a subtle sourness that concerns me, but in the taste it translates to a subtle fruitiness. Rich and creamy like a milkshake. Fruity with a bitter, dry finish. Quite quaffable.

Pours very dark brown, with good brown head. Rich, sweet, creamy,malty aroma. Smooth creaminess, sweet and malty. Some chocolate and vanilla, and light roasted flavor, with a nice balanced bitterness. Excellent beer.

Densely opaque, black body, thick chocolate mousse head formation. Roasted chocolate and berry aroma. Strong chocolate and vanilla  flavor, fairly roasted, good bitter finish. Pretty well balanced with sweet strawberry  touches. Good complex mix of flavors.

Jet black; thick; monstrous, super-dark brown, almost reddish head.  Aroma has some dark fruit but mostly is chocolate with vanilla and caramel; actually smells creamy.  Flavor very good, with chocolate and vanilla; not much roastiness, which is fine by me.  Nice and thick; bit sticky.  Excellent brew.

Gorgeous deep brown with about 3/4 of an inch of tan head that faded down to a thin layer that rested on top for the whole bottle.  Actually smelled like cream, not milk, but a cross between a beer and a container of cool whip.  Very smooth taste, a blend of malts, chocolate, coffee, and the obvious cream.  No bitterness on the tail end, but the feel is a little on the heavy side as it hits your stomach.  A serious improvement over their Java Stout.

A super brew, pour was dark with a nice laced white head.  Aroma full of chocolate, malts, and very mild spices.  Taste was similar and overall very drinkable.  And of course nice and creamy.  Another great outing from bells.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2004 Pours an opaque black with a tad bit of reddish brown if held up to the light.  Nice amount of foamy tan head.  Aroma is very complex mixture of sweet malts, roasty coffee, and sweet caramel.  A little too sweet I would say.  Taste is very smooth, sweet and almost milky, and some roasted coffee flavor.  Very well balanced.  Overall, this is a very good beer.

On another note, my buddies who are BMC fans said they felt like they were drinking alcholic syrup.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2005 Nice.  Pours a dark, dark, dark brown color with a short-lived brown head, soon readuced to a halo & some lacing across the glass.  It¬ís got a lightly roasted aroma with coffe scents and chocolate coming through.  Smooth and creamy in the mouth, this tastes of roasted malt, caramel, toffee, coffee, and chocolate with some mild spicing underneath.  There¬ís a touch of the hops and some nice roasted malts in its long, satisfying finish.  Nice job, Bell people.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

This had a difficult aroma to place for me.  Smelled creamy with wood and grains.  Looked great!  Very opaque, dark brown/black with a lite off white/borwn head.  The taste started to remind me of charcole bu quickly moved into a lite sweet candy/molassas taste.  It moved back again to a lite hop finish with roasted malts.  Underneath you could tast some spice like anise or clove.  It was complex but not my favorite.  Creamy body though, oily and substantial mouth feel.

Pours black with big off-white fluffy head. Butter/caramel aroma reminds me of a yankee candle. Flavor is everywhere Sweet malt,caramel,butter and chocolate. Very smooth body and mouthfeel. Very well done.

Wow.  Bells hit a home run again; they¬íre so good at making stouts and porters......this one¬ís so creamy, I expected it to be cloudy white with whipped cream in it.  great roasted flavors, subdued bitterness, ends with a  mild hop flourish and lingering roasted maltiness. Excellent.

Thanks to MrFacto for this delicious brew!
Deep black with a ruby tint that appears when strongly lit from behind.
Thick creamy tan head.
Malty chocolate aroma that repeats in the flavor with a coffee finish.  Easily earns it¬ís place among the other Bell¬ís Stouts and Porters.

Nice classic cream stout.  As Colonel Potter said, "Not enough o¬ís in smooth to describe this one"  The roastiness is there, but subdued and lots of flavor here.  One of the few stouts that I could use as a session beer.

Opaque black body with a large mocha head. The aroma is a huge sweet malty assault. Tons of chocolate. The flavor is equally as massive. Chococlate, sweet malts, a decent hop presence. Medium to full body, fairly soft palate. Very nice beer from the king of stout brewers!
Nose is super maple brown sugar/cream.  Milky flavor - perhaps a bit too ¬ícreamy¬í  Maple & malt.  Nice buttery finish.
UPDATED: FEB 22, 2005 Mocha like aroma, distinct but not heavy, stong but mellow cream coffe taste, like a fine malted starbucks concoction, smooth rich aftertaste. Definitely on my A list

Dark as night with mocha colored head. Sour cherry mocha icecream nose with lactic undertones. Heavey weight with light sweetness in the mid palate and a dry coffee finish. CREAMY, wow that¬ís an understatement with mocha coffee notes and bitter chocolate. Very rich but not cloying or heavy. Awesome beer!

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2004 Bottle pours a luscious black with an Aveda Spa air brush tan head and some psychedelic lace.  The aroma is of bitter chocolate and malt.  The flavor is malt, sweet, bitter chocolate, and very smooth and creamy.  They were right on with the name.  This is one creamy stout.  Overall, if I wanted to gain tons of weight, I would drink this.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2007 Poured black as can be with just a trace of a khaki/ orange head. Aroma is coffee and chocolate. There is also some peanut butter. The taste is not near as sweet as I would have expected. A full mouthfeel with some notes of dark chocolate and some malts. Also, some roasted character that is very strong. There is a hint of roasted almonds in the finish. It is creamy and smooth. Another very solid stout from Bell¬ís.
UPDATED: JUN 12, 2008 Black pour, almost no head.  Roasted cocoa and coffee aroma.  Flavor mimics aroma.  Not bad.

Beautiful dark beer with a rich light brown head.Nose is like drinking a rich delicious cup of hot chocolate,not that cheap Swiss Miss crap either.Has a wonderful taste of roasted malts and a chocolate dessert.

Nice dark brown color,small tan head that faded slowly leaving very little behind.Nice malty caramel and toffee aroma with a decent sweet side coming through and maybe a bit of coffee as well.Nice bitter chocolate taste some toffee and the coffee flavor manages to come on the scene late in the pallate.There is a slight alcohol presence but it is fairly mild and doesn¬ít make to much of itself known.Over all a very nice brew and well worth having a few more around.Thanks go to Robertsreality for sending this fine brew my way.

Hoo hah more Bell¬ís stouts compliments of The Factonator. This one poured pitch black with a rather large tan head. The nose is milk chocolate, coffee, and some licorice notes. The flavor is slightly sweet and fairly bitter with some chocolate, coffee, and toffee. This one manages to be a very smooth yet complex stout that hides the fact its a 7.5% ABV very well. Wish I had another one. GRRRREAT!

Pours as black as coffee and makes a nice tan head.  Aromatics are dense of rich roasted coffee beans and chocolate.  Flavor is quite large, with more roasted malt character, coffee and chocolate in the blender making me a mocha surprise.  Mouthfeel is thick and sticky on the palate.  This is a nice drinkable stout... its really similar to a homebrew porter that I made, so I am stoked!!!

Yummy, this is really, really good...I think we can safely call Bell¬ís the king of stouts.  Pours a dark milky brown color with a small tan head.  Aroma is chocolate toffee and, to steal Sick_Boy¬ís line, tootsie roll.  Flavor is really nice, more bitterness than I expected but still nice and sweet.  Like drinking chocolate candy.  Rich complex mouthfeel...alcohol hangs on just enough.

Bottle. Pours very dark, nearly opaque, even when held to the light.  Nice thick, frothy coffee colored head that takes it¬ís time going down. A roasty malt and chocolate smell.  My wife says ¬íchocolate covered coffee beans¬í.  Nice full mouthfeel, goes down smooth.  Tastes of chocolate and bittersweet tones.  Good stuff, very smooth.

another great beer by Bells!  a full bodied dark pour, complemented by a full bodied creamy palate....wonderful roasted, sweet flavor; chocolately and carmaley taste, with definite hints of vanilla; i need more!

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2005 i have had multiple bottles of this beer, varying from funky to very good.  luckily only 1 or two were every "funky," perhaps infected or improperly stored; the others are roasty and sweet and syrupy.  liked a souped-up version of kalamazoo stout, with extra unfermentables and less hops.
original:  dark orange/tan head. nice aroma of coffee, chocolate, milk/cream...smells a bit sweeter than regular bells stout.  just like the description--smooth and sweet, with plenty of roasted barley and starchy oatmeal presence.   syrupy finish with a lightly roasty aftertaste--excellent beer but i think i prefer the regular kalamazoo stout.

Pours a deep balck/brown with a small off-white head.... Aromas of milk chocolate and as burcusabrews said, a tootsie roll.   Damn.... I think that is the most appetizing aroma I have ever had from a beer... (homer voice) mmm..... tootsie roll.... chocolate....mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with flavors  of chocolate. toffee and caramel... I think that is what a toostsie toll tastes like.  Very smooth and tasty.  One of the better stouts I¬íve had in recent months.
Dark tootsie roll brown with no head.  Aroma of tootsie roll and light roasted coffee.  Very nice soft choclate flavor with a slight burnt toast flaovr.  Very nice.

Bottle Pours a dark black with a large fluffy dark tan head that stays.  Aroma is hazlenuts, carmel and dark malts.  Feel is smooth "creamy" and slick.  Flavors are very dark malt, molassas and charcoal.  Very nice and easy going down.  Thanks to MrFacto for the trade

Bottle: Poured a dark black with little to no head to speak of. Aroma is one of chocolate sweetness. On the palate the beer is extremely encompassing as the beer delivers hints of flavors not found at the nose. Cherry and even some vanilla maybe were nice surprises. A nice beer that impressed me.

08.16.04  bottle courtesy jsquire.  This is one of the darkest black beers I¬íve ever seen.  On the pour, the beer looks thick and syrupy.  Head is small but laces right away.  Aromas of chocolate cake batter, hints of buttercream, only slight roastiness.  Palate is huge and coating, even my teeth feel oily after a sip.  I feel like the flavor does not totally live up to the outrageous aromas, but it is still quite tasty.  Rich and roasty, hints of nuts, lots of chocolate.  Dark cherry notes are a nice surprise.  Doesn¬ít finish with much luster and makes me wonder what¬ís missing.  Thank you for this treat, Jeff.

Large brown/white head, excellent retention, plenty of droopy, stringy, sticky lace. Black as coal with a ruby red tint. Grainy, roasty nose with some licorice notes. Full body, creamy, lasting. Plenty of roast and chocolate, fruity undertones, cherry and a faint smokiness also. Fairly dry finish. Quaffable stuff. Thanks MrFacto!
Cream, roasted malt, and a bit of pineapple sweetness in the nose, Coffe, lactose, chocolate, and raisons in the mouth.  Dry finish with green raisons and tannins.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2004  Pours a very dark brown with a nice small sand colored head. Taste and aroma is a very smooth choclate coffee flavor. Key phrase: VERY smooth. Very easy to drink and the alcohol is barely noticable. Awesome stout!
UPDATED: AUG 20, 2004 I like the cream addition to this stout as it makes it very smooth.  Also very roasty and sticky, nice mocha head.
Dark Brown Coloring.  Small Head.  Sweet.  Not overpowering like Crack Dealer Susie...

opaque black with a medium tan head.  Almost smells like one of those chai things you can buy at Dunkin Donuts.  Has a definate earthy aroma in my opinion.  Nothing discernable to start, the middle starts to flavor chocolate.  Finish is slightly hoppy with choco-hints.  A decent offering.

Well, I basically tasted this side by side with the Kalamazoo and I noticed that this one was a little thicker and roastier.  Everything else is pretty much the same.  I did not appreciate more sweetness in this one though per the description on here

Huge brown head with staying power.  Opaque to extremely dark brown beer.  Nice sweetish aroma of dark chocolate (not roasted barley).  Malty as all hell but balanced by roasted malt and hops bitterness.  Yes some coffee flavors too.  I like it better than the Kalamazoo.

Thick brown creamy head. Very dark brown body. Aroma has a rich chocolate coffee feel... but its light. Big flavor. Very smooth. A rich chocolate taste with some sweet licorice, raspberry, and bitter tobacco. Nice bitter coffee finish that hangs around a while.

Opaque ebony body with a medium brown foamy head.  Aroma of chocolate and sweet roasted mocha.  Creamy and medium-bodied.  When I bought this, I thought that it would be too malty, as they use ten different kinds of malt, but it¬ís actually very well balanced.  Not as good as the Java Stout, but definitely delicious nonetheless.

Light nose - roasted coffee. Dark dark brown-black color and a foamy tan head that disappates. Smooth sweet syrupy malt initially with some licorice notes, becomes bitter - like black coffee that lingers on your teeth after the swallow. Fairly simple profile, but a good balance and enjoyable overall.

Nice sweet chocolate and cantelope aroma with some roasted malts.  Very thick black color with a clingy, foam head.  Sweet cantelope flavors through-out with some chocolate in the beginning and a dark roasted coffee finish.  Excellant stout.
Opaque colored, spare light brown head. Inense coffee nose, licorice also. Very heavy roasted, almost burnt malt flavor, licorice and tabacco too. Nice.

Pours a dark brown/black with thin, evaporating head.  Aroma is sweet, but nothing too noticeable.  Flavor has lots of sweet cream to it, along with some malt and a little chocolate.  Oddly enough, some bitterness as well.  Good, but not great.
Dark with no head. Aroma is of dark chocolate. Flavour is full creamy, roasted and malty. A bit of fruit and a well malted finish.
pours black small tan head with a little lacing.aroma sweet, malt,chocolate.coffee malt taste.Has a nice bitter sweet finish

Creamier than any stout I have ever experienced.  Tastes almost like they added a almost expired carton of cream to this.  
Very rich taste, roasted malt, creamy finish.
Excellent beer.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2008 [bottle] Pours a velvety black with a creamy looking tan head. Rich and creamy malt aroma. I¬íve never been able to smell cream this clearly in a stout before. Good strong coffee and cream taste that gives way to a smooth malty finish. Feels like silk in your mouth. MarkR, did you ever know that you¬íre my hero?

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2004 Bottle:  Aroma is very malty and creamy.  Faint coffee smell as well.  Pours black with very little head.  What head there is, is a dark tan.  Strong coffee and some cream flavor with some malt flavoring as well.  Slightly bitter.  Finished creamy with a medium bitter aftertaste.
Sweet malt rich Coffee with lots of cream. My first and hopefully not last milk stout. Easy on carbonation a plus. Mid-sip fruitiness from yeast. Black pour
Great stout.  You can taste the creaminess.  Very dark beer, a little bitter, and that creamy finish.  Thumbs up on this one.

This stuff is pretty darn good. Big brown frothy head that is long lasting. nose is malty and creamy and chalky. The taste is bitter and creamy and somehwat chalky and the middle is rusty but finishes creamy and bitter with some roasted malts. Quite good.

Fully dark in color, a deep, deep black, and a sturdy cocoa-y brown head. Aroma is rich and roasty, toasty, but still rather light. Perhaps that's where the cream comes in, I'd guess, though it's on the subtle side. Mouthfeel gets a great initial hop blitz , that mellows soon after., but not before giving off blasts of cherryish sweetness. Slight bitterness continues with every swallow, but is ultimately subsided. All in all, a very tasty, unique stout, soothing and delicious.
A wonderfully creamy stout.  It pours piutch black with next to no head - even if you try to get one.  A nice taste and aroma of coffee and chocolate.  A definite winner.

A black body with a brown beaded head. Great lacing through the whole beer. Aroma of lactose and milk chocolate with some vanilla in the backgrouond. The body is a little thin and is perpetuated by the amount of CO2. Not as good as other Bell's stouts. By the way, as a homebrewer I can guaruntee that this does in fact contain lactose.

a definte above average stout.  does NOT contain any lactose and was not as creamy or smooth as i thought.  label said contains 10 malts.  wow.  pretty roasty, but lacking the depth of the normal kalamazoo stout.
From bottle.  Nice brown head, lasts a while with nice lacing throughout.  Very roasted, malty aroma.  Rich mouthfeel, with a nice malty finish.  Smooth.  Nicely carbonated.

Pours very dark blackish, with a great head and great lacing.  Smells of coffee, prunes, dark chocolate, cognac, and licorice.  Tastes very roasty and creamy malty.  Finishes very smooth, with a creamy, roasty flavor.  Very bold.  This one reminds me of the Lancaster Milk Stout.  Very nice beer.

Bottle pours coffee black with a frothy tannish head. ¬† Lacing appears to be uber sticky. ¬† Sour cherries, semi-sweet chocolate, and cheesecake of all things greet the nose. ¬† Up front I get a large burnt malt flavor that quickly turns bitter towards the finish. ¬† Mouthfeel seems a tad thin, but not bad. ¬† Midway through an appearance by some bittersweet chocolate and sour cherries show up. ¬† Lingering burnt malt after the finish. ¬† Tastes like the blending of creamy cheesecake with sour cheeries and coffee. ¬† Quite enjoyable. ¬† Thanks goes out to TChrome for the trade!

Deep, deep brown in colur with a thin coffee coloured head.  Aroma was very roasty, with dark chocolate, coffee, cream and sugar.  The flavour was roasty, lots of chocolate malt, cream, pretty much a coffee beer.  Finishes with a short medium bitterness.  Thanks Michael.

Well I know it sounds like taking the easy way out, but holy smokes was this ever creamy. The rich dark dark brown body released the obligatory roasty malty coffee smells...but it was all enveloped in a buttery smoothness. And the flavour was more of the same with some chocolate tucked into the creaminess too. coats the tongue nicely and lingers without much bitterness at all. Yummy.
This is another really good Stout by Kalamazoo.  Sweet, malty, and roasty flavors.  Finishes bitter sweet, creamy, and dry.
Pours very dark brown with a tan head. Coffee aroma. Really roasty. Full bodied, coffee and cream like flavor. Nice coffee aftertaste. Enjoyable.

Bottle.  Poured dark brown and almost entirely opaque (however allowing garnet highlights when held to light) and giving rise to a small tan head that diminished quickly to a ring of creamy foam around the rim.  Aroma is dark roasted malts without smelling charred, bitter chocolate and cream.  Flavor is unlike any other stout I've had I think, sweet yet bittingly bitter upfront, charred malt taste, coffee and generous earthy hops.  Rich and smooth, a real pleasure to drink.

12 oz bottle courtesy of TCHROME. Pours very dark brown with a tan head. Coffe and cream aroma, with a touch of caramel and butterscotch. Full bodied, with a coffee and cream like flavor. Malt bitterness lingers in the finish, and so does a nice coffee aftertaste. Thanks Tad!
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Deep dark brown with small tan head. Rich malty aroma, almost vinous as it warms, definitely a touch of grapes in there. Bold chocolate and luscious cream. It smells thick. Full and generous sensuous mouthfeel with a gentle carbonation, as creamy as it gets, rich in flavours, very malty without much hop profile to balance, but not overly sweet. Rather short finish with a very mild trace of roast and bitterness, almost bland with not much going on. I like this more than I expected and I think it's the first stout my mom enjoys. Perhaps a little too rich/creamy toward the end from my point of view. Sounds like a fitting name for such a smooth beer.

limited sample.
Burnt aroma dominates.
Completely black, low creamyhead.
Somehow I couldn't really become friends with the flavor profile, all I got was a
burnt wood taste which stopped at a surprisingly light body and petered out into a ashen aftertaste. I don't know, must be me or the small sample....

Oh, Mama!  Pours a beautiful opaque black with a rich, foamy, dark tan head.  Tantalizing chocolate aroma.  Roasted chocolate malts in the taste.  Great mouthfeel.  This is an excellent stout for any stout lover.

Pours pitch black with a dense tan head.

Aroma is rich coffee beans, dark chocolate, and roasted malts.

Flavor is heavy on the coffee, with a decent bit of bitter dark chocolate. The roasted malts mellow towards the middle of the glass and the chocolate comes out to play a little more. It finishes slightly sweet but plenty creamy.

The mouthfeel is smooth, slick and creamy. The body is rich and the carbonation is calm and unimportant.

Drinkability is okay, it's a great brew but it's heavy, thick and I have a hard time drinking multiple roasted brews like this one.

A superb stout. Dense, luscious, tan head. Nearly impermeable to light. Very well balanced. An appropriate level of roastedness. Sweet and smooth but perfectly and crisply muted by the carbonation leading to a refreshing finish.

Roasted coffee bean, dark chocolate malt (H); light aroma of smoke.  Tall, creamy/frothy tan head is slowly diminishing and sits  on an opaque, black body. Heavily sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet, moderately bitter, lightly acidic finish.  I think the bitterness is from the roasted malts, not hops.  The acidity helps balance the sweetness quite nicely.  Heavy body, creamy/oily texture, soft carbonation.  The bottom line is: why don't I live in Michigan?
Delicious!  Wow, what a stout.  Smells of choclate and coffee.  Tastes like the ideal cup of coffee: creamy, chocolaty, smooth.

Wow, Bell's sure likes making stouts. And they do a good job.

As I was pouring this it didn't look like it was going to have much head so toward the end I poured a little more vigorously. That was a mistake, as I had to drink a lot of foam really fast to not make a mess. Huge head.

Pours very black with the aformentioned large head that lasted all the way through the beer leaving a really nice lace.

Smells of dark roasted malts and chocolate.

Tastes pretty good, but this isn't their best stout. The chocolate isn't as apparent in the taste. It's actually more like bitter coffee.

Mouthfeel is good and creamy with a bit of a mineral feel to it. Drinkability is okay, but not something I'd seek out again.

Ok.. much better here, pours dark with a small tan head. Very sweet aroma with chocolate and caramel presant. Flavor to match although ther was a bit of tanginess in the finish that took away from the overall. Good beer for specific occasions.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2004 Black, with a great brownish head. Has a wonderful aroma from toffee, butter and milk chocolate. Flavor is milk chocolate as well, some vanilla and with some cream. Very smooth and pleasant with a great hoppy finish. Also it leaves great lacing on the glass.
Very enjoyable stout, large tan head, black in color, very rich flavors, coffee & chocolate dominate, medium in body & not too thick or heavy, nice drinkable stout
Mixture of coffee and bitter chocolate.  A touch watery, but I have found this to happen with many of the Bell's.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2005 Appearance: BLACK, not dark brown, not slightly black, this mother is BLACK. No head.

Very faint coffee scent- wish there was more of a smell- because this beer has a nice look.

RICH and THICK. Coffee, chocolate... nice. Burnt rice..

Thin in the mouth for a thick brew.

A bit too thick in body and thin in mouth to warrent more than slightly above average drinkability.

Aroma smells like a double shot of cream got dumped in my glass, but there is a very nice malt backbone in the background.  Pours very dark, almost, if not black with a big tan head that refuses to go away.  Ther is nice lacing all the way around my glass at present.  Flavor is initially cream, but that quickly give way to bitter chocolate and a strong coffe flavor. Finish is a bit thin IMO.  Quite nice.

Light, flash-in-the-pan phead the fades to a ring of foam around the edges but stirs up easily with a small swirl. Chocolate and char on the nose. The flavor has an odd dry powdery flavor (can't quite describe it actually), that seems to intertwine itself with the chocolate malt flavors to give the impression of a mouthfull of cocoa powder. A bit milky in the flavor. I really imagined a stout called Double Cream to be a bit thicker, but it's not exactly thin. Definitely improves as it warms.
Draft - black brew with a surprisingly light colored head.  Still brown, but lighter than many.  A beautiful beer!  Roasty and chocolaty with a creamy mouthfeel.  I love it!

(sampled at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden) Black with a small creamy beige head. Coffee, cocoa, vanilla and spicy hops in aroma. Chocolate, sweet coffee, burnt sugar and cocoa in flavour. Smooth finish. Almost too drinkable. Excellent stout.

Pours black with little tan head. The smell is tremendous. Scents of mocha, roastedness, and slight yeast. The flavor is in line with the nose with a sweet roasted and chocolate taste along with just the right amount of coffee flavor. Alcohol is hardly noticeable at 7.5% This is a good one.

Poured black with no head. So i swirled the last inch or so of the beer in the bottle in order to garnish a head. The beer proceeded to bubble out over the top of the glass. Fortunately this generated a prominent aroma of sweet, roasted chocolate. Flavor was very sweet and smooth, coffee and chocolate, with a pleasant sweet finish. Quite good.
enjoyed the rich coffee like taste and the dark and appealing visuals bells best stout effort

Smells like vanilla and oak with a great frothy head on top of a soft and slippery dark body.  Taste is 4 fricking lbs. of Colombian roast jammed  into a 4 ounce sample.  WAY too much coffee for me, with a wierd porter-like tang on the finish.  This is my second lactic stout and I have to admit that I'm just not getting them.

Dark brown/red. Medium,khaki head leaves lasing ring of cream. Clean aroma of caramel,chocolate,vanilla,with slight roasty and hop undertones. Fizzy,creamy mouthfeel. Texture a touch watery. Flavors of chocolate,caramel,cream,and a nice roasty presence. Finish is clean,with roasty,vanilla flavors. Long and lingering finish. Aroma is a bit more interesting than the flavors,but still a great stout!
Excellent sweet aroma and nice chocolatey flavor which is a bit sweeter than a regular stout. Beautiful deep dark color. Great winter beer. Loved it - one of the best stouts that I've had.

I believe Indra is the one to thank for supplying me with this brew several months ago, Thanks! 
Vintage: 2002
I‚Äôve aged this beer for several months now and must concede to the temptations!
Holly Mother of Marry, this beer looks like a Champ! The body is black as space, the head is a rich caramel / toffee color. The aroma is O-mama! Full of carrot cake, vast notes of chocolate, spiced rum and or aged whisky, coconut, fresh cream, it‚Äôs divine! Damn, the flavor has Massive and amazing notes of coffee, chocolate and oak barrel aged whisky. The deeply kilned chocolate malt is so abundant with malleable and smooth palate. What a perfect warming and enjoyable finish; This beer is Dreamlike, Highly Recommended!
This poured jet black and was sooooo smooth.  A wonderful stout from a brewery that specializes in the style.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2003 a thick black, creamy beer.  slight tan head that recedes quickly.  smells like coffee and roasted malts....  goes down smoothly, with a savory and sweet roasted chocolate flavor with a bit of a bitter finish.  smooth.  creamy.  delicious.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2012 It¬ís been 7 years since I¬íve rated this so I¬ím doing it again. Thick and opaque with a fine chocolate head. A wonderful aroma of chocolate, roast, vanilla and toffee. A great mouthfeel, sweet coffee and a slight smokiness, yet very smooth. Carbonation is good with a tiny bitterness. Finishes well. Still very nice but not quite the beer I remember.

Pours a deep dark black with very dark ruby edges. No head or lace.  Some chocolate, some coffee in the aroma.  Flavors are a bit more than the aroma. Starts out with sweet malt, going to some more of the roastiness, finishes a bit bitter. There is a smokiness that underlying all the other flavors.  Big body and a creamy palate. Nice. Thanks ClarkVV

Oily black color with tawny black edges. No head, no lacing. Nose is very rich with straight forward coffee & chocolate with a bit of roast. Flavor is lightly sweet and malty with the light hops coming through in the end next to a bit of smoke. Not complex at all, but very straight forward. This is well made and could be called a benchmark stout in my book. Thanks ClarkVV

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2004 Aroma is primarily the burnt, roasted malts.  Flavor is smokey and coffee.  There appears to be some fruity notes underneath the smoke, but its hard to tell.  Some dry hops up front and a fairly bitter finish.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2011 Sampled November 2011
A vigorous pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a three-finger thick, frothy textured, brown head that leaves lots of lacing on the sides of my glass. The beer is a black, concentrated brown color and  is quite opaque. Rich malt aromas of blackened caramel, concentrated coffee, slightly tart roast / burnt notes, some sort of rich, cold coffee drink, dark chocolate and cocoa are all quite noticeable in the nose.  There seem to be some touches of roasted butterscotch here as well.

The beer feels thick and viscous, but lightens up as moves across the palate. A dry and roasted note in the finish is what allows this to lighten up and it serves as a nice foil for the dark malt sweetness up front.  This beer is roasted, burnt and slightly bitter throughout the flavor profile, but, especially towards finish.  The finish has a lingering toasted / roasted brown grain-bread character to it that adds some whole grain wholesomeness to the beer.  The texture has a smooth and creamy feel to it up front, but the middle gets a touch prickly from the carbonation, but also it is accentuated by some burnt tartness. Burnt toffee flavors up front meld well with some roasted nutty notes. The finish has some tartness from the ample roast malt.

This is much nicer than my previous encounter with a much too buttery version of this beer. This definitely hits the spot if you are in the mood for an amply roasted, but chewy, smooth stout.
Sampled December, 2003
Previous Score = 3, 5/4/5/4/12
This beer pours a deep brown, almost a black, color.  It forms a thick brown head when swirled in my glass.  The aroma is of a buttery roast malt.  The butter seems to dominate the aroma.  The butter component is in the taste as well.  This beer is creamy in consistency.  It has definite roast character as well, though befitting a cream stout, it is a soft roast flavor.  The stout is fairly thick bodied, with notes of coffee and chocolate.  The butter flavor seems to dissipate with time, though I could just be getting used to it.  I am not sure if the butter character is supposed to be here (my guess is that it is not), but it is no so strong that it horribly detracts from this beer.  It even helps to boost the perceived fullness of this beer.  Though in the end this beer would be much better without the butter component.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2004 Dark brown with a small head and fair lacing. Nice chocolate ice cream and warm fudge aroma, with faint sherry and butter notes. Very smooth with chocolate, toffee and caramel flavors, a restrained roasted coffee background with a hoppy note. Toasty and sweet with very little bitterness, it's a malty brew alright and superbly drinkable.

Dee-licious!  I think that the best beers just taste damn good and don't require analysis.  Like this one.  Just tasting good is enough.  If I had to break it down, I'd say that in this case the ten different malts came together to make a nice tasting beer, rather than a disjointed one like other multi-malt beers have turned out to be.  Thanks PsychProf!
Not much of a nose on it.  Looks very inviting. Sweet malt flavor tasting of burnt chocolate.  Warming but a very masked alcohol taste - a very balanced beer.  I'd like a bigger nose, though.

Intense, opaque brown with a thin velvety head. Inviting nose with notes of chocolate, smoke, raisin, and--I swear to god--beef. Front is smooth and creamy. Most of the flavor comes out in the middle--tremendous malt depth with all manner of dark malt flavors. But the most beautiful thing here is the palate--thick, velvety and not the least bit sticky. Finishes cleanly with a touch of dark chocolate bitterness. Another wonderful Stout by Bell's and flavorful enough to rival even the best imperials.

Black in appearance but not opaque, light, caramel fluffy head.  Burnt toffe aroma.  Stong, sweet flavor of roasted malt, espresso and vanilla.  Very creamy with a liqueur-like finish.  Not an everyday beer, but tasty.
thanks to dsquire, ruby tinted black, sweet aroma with vanilla and nutmeg.  palate is excellent. flavor starts slightly sweet but no overpowering and has a pleasent bitter finish

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a pitch black oily liquid light can not penetrate with a small amount of caramel colored head.  Aroma is of faint hop, molasses and strong malt (yummy!!).  Flavor is of molasses, vanilla, and slight to small hops ending and faintly dry.  Sampled at 70 degrees Fahrenheit.

The aroma speaks of malt, chocolate, and coffee. Not quite as harsh as some of Bell's other stoutly offerings. Opaque with no head at all. Body is creamy with elements of lactose and coffee. One of my favorite stouts!

Pitch black with a tinge of dark caramel at the edges. Head is small and dense. Aroma is of strong black coffee and charred malts. On the dry side and medium bodied but smooth. Flavor is strong bitter coffee. Not as sweet as I'd like. Overall pretty good though.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Poured black, not quite opaque with a soft creamy tan head and nice lacing.  Roasted, sweet, super creamy aroma.  Full mouthfeel with sweet tastes of chocolate, coffee, and vanilla.  This was very fulfilling, and I could drink many of these at a time.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2004 Malty,slight chocolate aroma-not very strong at first but picks up.Head disappeared quickly. Bitter chocolate and coffeelike flavor.Fairly thin mouthfeel,but enjoyable just left to linger in my mouth for awhile.dry,bitter, slightly acidic finish.Gives no clue to its ABV while drinking it which can sneak up on you.easy drinking,enjoyable stout. I plan to cellar a couple till next fall. 01/12/04-Couldn't wait. Aroma seems more pronounced this time. A little better balanced to me also. More sweetness noticed. Alcohol noticeable. Still no head. Still tasty.

Good aroma of grains typical of Bells. Head is good. I thought the taste was a little too sour and a little off. Very malty and full though. Pretty good aftertaste of roasted malts and chocolate. A little overrated.

The black body of this brew is topped by a medium thick to thick creamy, brown head with a good amount of lacing left behind.  The aroma is slightly bitter, roasty, bready and malty with a slight sweetness and a touch of coffee.  The flavor is roasty and malty with a bitter, sweet chocolate note and a touch of coffee.  Full bodied, smooth and a touch warming.

Big sweet, fruity (cherries?) aroma. Perfect jet black with tight, coffee coloured head. Flavour is a rather subtle (which is all too rare), roasted coffee and is also fruity. Yes it does taste like there is milk in the coffee as well. A fine effort. Thanks Clark VV

A very very nice sweet stout.  Great aroma with hints of chocolate and vanilla.  The taste is very breve.  Like drinking cocoa that has been steamed with half and half.  Very tasty and palatable.  A must try.

Pours pitch black with a thin tan head. Aroma of sweet malt, alcohol, and expresso. Taste of sweet roast malt, caramel, and alcohol which combined when (I tasted it) to produce a grape like aftertaste. It was very interesting but the palate was very thin.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2003 Very fruity in the nose (cherry).   Black beer with reddish-brown head, dissipates quickly.  Slick, rich body. No harsh roasty flavors here, quite bland, actually, the fruitiness comes through in the flavor and the tannic roast quality is subdued.  Reminds me of a Sam Smith's Imperial wanna-be.  This is a Teddy Roosevelt beer, speaks softly; carries a big stick.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2004 Pours nearly opaque black with medium diminishing tan head. Nice aroma filled with roast, buttermilk, coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Medium thick body. Velvety smooth with soft carbonation. Exceptionally creamy. Flavor with heavy roast, lots of sweet lactose tang, coffee, molasses, bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, and a hint of dark fruit.  The sweet lactose/sour milk/buttermilk quality can become a little overpowering as the beer warms.  Even so, it is more proof that bell's knows stouts.

Very dark brown, with a nice light brown head.  A hint of coffee to it in both flavor and aroma.  Maybe a touch of almond to it.  The aftertaste was smooth and mellow.  Felt more carbonated than I would have expected.
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2007 Opaque and dark.  Nose is roasty and a bit burnt, get some tobacco hints.  Taste coffee, chocolate, and cream, hoppiness has a subtle tartness to it.
From the Kalamazoo's tasting at the brickskeller:  A very light black with a light brown foam.  Could definalty pick out the coffee and cream flavors.  Another quality stout.
This stuff was so full of flavor I don't think they could pack any more in.  Great dark color. Awesome stoutie flavor that went down so smoothly.  I wonder what this would taste like mixed with milk.
Great aroma of apples and malt.  Black, no head.  Flavor of coffee, apple, and an herbal taste.  Kind of thin.  Finish of mildly bitter hops.
Very dark. Smells sweet. Chocolate and fruit. Bitter chocolate, burnt marshmallow, toffee flavor. Hops finish. A nice stout but could be a little smoother.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2015 Like the Expedition, but drinkable, oh so drinkable.  Pitch black with a perfect tan head that lasted through the entire beer.  Pinpoint carbonation.  Aroma doesn¬ít climb out of the glass to meet you, but lingers, inviting, with definite aromas of chocolate and pine.  The flavors roll through the mouth, spruce in the beginning, followed by loads of semi-sweet and milk chocolates.  As it warms, the spruce fades, and black cherries begin to emerge.  I wish stuff like this was brewed in my area.  RERATE:  I have tried this repeatedly over the years, and I should note that I think my early exuberance for this beer is slowly fading a bit.  My palate has become jaded by a tidal wave of imperials that leave the more subtle complexities of this beer gasping for air.  So if I had to be totally objective, I probably would lower this rating.  And probably fairly significantly.  But in this case, nostalgia rules the day, and I shall leave my initial, now almost 12 year old rating, intact in all its glory.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2007 This is still November of 2002¬ís.  Good looking stout, dark brown, opaque, with a somewhat frothy head.  Aroma is very much of chocolate.  The flavor is chocolate, burnt, and somewhat bitter, almost like the unsweeten chocolate used in cooking.  Mouthfeel is not as creamy as you¬íd expect for the name, slightly thicker than a porter.  Finish is somewhat bitter.  Good Stout.
Roasted coffee chocolade aroma with a hint of butter. Lovely buttery roasted taste. Light bitter burned aftertaste. A really nice beer.
A very creamy, carbonated stout.  Good roasted, sweet flavors.  Nice dessert beer, as advertised.
Black with ruby hints and a tan head. Aroma of coffee & chocolate liqueur. Creamy mouthfeel, flavour is roasty and sweet and fruity (cherries, dark grapes), finish is dry and slightly bitter.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2008 (1/1/08, 12oz bottle, thanks Peregrinari) Small tan head atop cola brown-black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, some roast/coffee, light vinous.  Taste is medium sweet, chocolate, coffee bitterness.  Smooth medium body.  (8/3/7/3/14)

(Brickskeller Bells 10/03) Dark brown with tan head.  Aroma is creamy, rich, coffee, chocolate, tobacco.  Taste is coffee, light chocolate, light sweet.  Medium body. (8/3/7/3/14) 

(WCC2003) Black body with small brown head.  Aroma is coffee, medium sweet, some chocolate.  Taste is rich, coffee, light chocolate, medium bitter.  Full body, fairly creamy. (8/4/8/4/16)
(Bottle) Strong cocoa nose. Brown head with opaque body. Cocoa, vanilla and nice linguring chocolate and coal.

Had from bottle on July 17th, 2003 - Day 17 of Blake's Beer Month¬ôGreat stuff - today I cracked open three Kalamazoos - the Double Cream Stout, Expedition Stout & Cherry Stout - of the three, this was my favorite.  The beer pours DARK black with a small, light brown head.  The aroma, as with most stouts is of strong coffee and a slight sweetness.  The flavoring is amazing - coffee, chocolate, fruits, malt, vanilla, it's all there.  Finishes smoothly with a little alcohol on the tongue and a very slight bitter flavoring.  Great stuff - better than the Expedition in my opinion - but both are great beers.  Not as sweet as the Cherry, not as strong as the Expedition - the perfect middle ground!

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2003 Dark, roasted coffee and cream in the aroma, with a hint of lactose, toffee and semi-sweet chocolate.  Opaque ebony color, bottle-conditioned, with a settling, tan head.  Rich, roasty and darkly sweet malt flavor, plenty of cocoa, some molasses and caramel, and finishing with a light dose of hop bitterness.  Exceedingly smooth mouthfeel.  A quality stout.
UPDATED: JUL 22, 2003 pours black, big beige head.  creamy, chocolate wafer and coffee aroma.  roasty flavours, with chocolate chip cookie-ish malt flavours, mild mocha finish.

I tried to pour this beer slowly, but the end result was a beer with a massive meringue head. The nose is very sweet, chocolaty, and rich. The palate is full and flavorful with rich fudge flavors. This is a chocolate fruit bomb of a beer with a hint of pineapple in the finish. Baby Expedition. The yeast profile reminds me of 3rd coast old ale.
Dark brown, creamy decent head. Buttery creamy aroma, sweet rich with roast notes. Softer, mellower coffee. Nice aftertaste.
Burnt coffee nose, deep brown, with a small toffee head. Fresh espresso flavour, some woodiness. Bitter dry finish. Full bodied, smooth and well balanced. Terrific!
Black w/ fine brown foam. Intense burnt, roast coffee flavour w/ an earthy nuttiness. Thick & creamy but chewy. Robust burnt coffee & bitter chocolate flavour. Very earthy, bitter finish.
Drinks like a meal.  Big rocky head, lots of espresso in the nose and mouth with really cool asphalt notes and some berry.  I dig.
RateBeer Summer 2003:  Ruby/black color with a brown head.  Roasted coffee aroma, creamy smooth mouthfeel.  Ends sweet and rich.  Nice lacing on the glass.
Poured very dark with a thin head. Has a roasty flavor with coffee and chocolate. Finishes way too sour for me.

Nice black color with dark brown highlights, large tannish head that really faded fast leading to just some small bubbles along the edge. Nice aroma of roasted malt and sweet hops with a chocolate tone and vanilla notes. Super smooth taste of well balanced roasted barley, sweet chocolate and hops, with a hint of vanilla. Well done. It reminded me of a warm chocolate shake with out the thickness. Good medium stout body, sort of heavy but the smoothness really keeps it from getting any heavier. Nice sweet vanilla tang in the mouth at the finish with hints of roasty a chocolate sweetness. Very drinkalbe stout!
Pitch black color.  Roasted malt aroma.  Chewy coffee, chocolate malt flavor.  A creamy oatmeal quality.  Great, great stout.

The best word to describe this beer is creamy... creamy pour, creamy head, and creamy mouthfeel... more than hints of mocha and bitterness. Good on special nights but the rule of too much of a good thing applies with this beer. A little to specific for a staple beer, but deliscious the same

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2006 What is the story? Sour, sour sour.  All of the sweet roastiness is there but it is overpowered by an immediate and lasting sourness.  I experienced the same thing with the Kalamazoo Stout.  I hope next year¬ís batch of stouts isn¬ít subject to whatever infected this year¬ís.  I¬íve had Bell¬ís stouts in the past and they can be the best around.  
7/5/4/2/11 2.9

Re-rate 1-06: Bells has clearly worked out their earlier infection issues. This version is a big, sweet and creamy glass of milk chocolate with a touch of bitterness. Good thickness for a sweet stout. Quite pleasing.

A dark nearly black opaque body with a huge creamy head and nice lace, full-bodied. While a coffee, chocolate, nutty aroma are present, I detected a surprising cherry smell. Nice caramel and coffee taste. Sweet and bitter balance on the palate which linger for a while. A world-class sweet stout. Yummy!

My goodness!  Like a coffee ice cream float.  Great coffee aroma - sweetness to start, very creamy and smooth, thick - then a slight bitterness to balance it out, with extreme coffee flavor - like a chocolate malt as a beer - this is one of the best stouts I've had in a while.

This is a great stout - sweet, but not overlly syrupy.  Perfect coffee flavor and coffee-with-cream in the aroma.  Perfectly balanced, and a rich, thick mouthfeel.  A hint of bittersweet chocolate in the finish.

Tightly packed, creamy head with a slightly ruby hue.  Some sediment, in a very dark body.  Good sweet aroma, a bit nutty with chocolate high lights.  Coffee flavors come out from hiding upon tasting when not apparent in aroma.  Good mouthfeel.  Had it before dinner, but would definitely be a good dessert beer.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2005 2004-sampled at the hop leaf in chicago, IL.  This beer has one of the most wonderful aromas i have ever wiffed in a beer.  i boosed the ratings a little.  
2003-nothing really different in the beer for the new version.  Still solid as ever.  Maybe only slightly more sour than last years version.  Lots of chocolate and creamy roasted notes.
2002 bottle-Poured jet black with a nice rocky beige head.  Aroma was like that of coffee, spices, and sweetness.  Tasted very nice-smooth, creamy and full of roasted notes.  The unfiltered nature left a resinous feel in the mouth.  long lasting finish!

Nice dark color with a small amount of carb, looks great.  Great first taste that only gets better as you go.  Sweet and bitter combine for a great sipping stout.

This beer pours a very dark color with a small head and moderate lacing on the glass.  It smells sweet but very strong of barley and yeast also.  The taste was sweet as well, but a little too sweet.  This is definitely deserving of the name stout.  It is very strong tasting and not for the faint hearted.  It was more enjoyable than many other strong tasting beers I've had, so I have to give it good marks for that.  The pungent taste stays on the palate for quite some time.
Near black color with a tall tawny head. Full toasty and chocolate malt aroma.  Rich, full and creamy feel.  Initial malt sweetness followed by a oily maltiness.  Small amount of fruitiness.
UPDATED: MAY 12, 2003 Creamy head. Smooth and thick going down. Coffee and chocolate is the main flavor.A little sweeter than the bells regular stout. Nice beer.

The Beer starts off with a big thick foamy head.  The beer is a dark walnut brown.  It has a very different tast, not quite coffee-ish or chocolate-ish or nutty.     Has a short finish, and seems to be fairly thin.  But also very filling.  Overall better then average, but not the type of beer I will buy regularly.

"Creamy" in the head and pour department, that's for sure; lovely black shake.  Huge roasty, semi-sweet nose.  Flavor is grapy-sweet, palate super-creamy; it's good but perhaps a bit too sweet, little to no bite and just a tiny bit thin at the very end.  Very good, don't get me wrong, but not perfect.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2003 The draft version I had poured with no head, but a bottled version I had later poured a large head of finely sized brown colored bubbles that left behind an opaque very dark black colored body with no visible carbonation and a fair lacing.  It had a very strong coffee and chocolate aroma in both cases.  It actually had a very mild coffee taste with a very thick mouthfeel and no after bite which allowed it to go down very smoothly.  The flavor was otherwise OK with nothing remarkable to say about it other than it was simply enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2003 Dark pour with a hint of darkness in the foam.  Thick flat and smooth going down the throat.  Good chocolate/coffee flavor that isn't supported by the aroma. I like it, but not what I was expecting from Bell's.

Interesting, though not my favorite to come out of Kzoo.  Pours reasonably thick with a hint of carbonation and little head.  Not an exceptional aroma and not suggesting the strong burst of roasted, chocolate, almost mocha coffee-like flavors.  I thought this was much more dry than I expected.  A bit of tang, almost a hint of sour before the roasted bitterness takes over in the finish.  I attribute that to the cream but other than a hint in the aroma and this odd flavor combination, I didn't pick up as much cream as I would have thought (and I've had a good bit of high-quality cream in my day).

On tap at the brewery.  Poured deep brown with a little head.  Chocolate-malt aroma.  Taste was yoo-hoo thick with a medicinal taste.  The label on a bottle and the thick taste take me back to the 1800's and make me think that this beer could cure the common cold or at least the sniffles.
Big roasty nose, lacing. Smooth mouthfeel. Somewhat bitter yet creamy. Complex. Cool.

Another nice offering from Bells in this one. Good flavor, color, and head. Very well rounded in flavor, and pretty smooth. The only weakness to this one is its aroma, which isn't bad by any means, but is a little weak. Good all around, though, and a worthy buy.

WOW! I knew this was going to be a good brew, but it was better than good, in fact, it was way good. It's pretty thick, but in a good, creamy kind of way. It has a pretty sweet flavor and aroma, kind of like some coffee/chocolate/maple syrup hybrid. I would HIGHLY recommend this to any stout fan, I see a few more 6's of this in my future.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2004 Updated 13 October 2003
Time to replace an earlier vague review.  Double Cream Stout is perhaps my favorite beer.  Pours deep brown with a thin tan head. Plenty of "floaties." Aroma is roasted malts with hints of sweet lactose.  The new label indicates this stout is brewed with 10 malts, so the flavor is quite interesting.  Roasted, slightly burnt chocolate rules the palate, and is infused with sweet and tangy notes of lactose and perhaps hints of dark fruit.  Licorice also peeks through the creamy morass.  Medium-thick body.  Always a treat and a major reason to look forward to fall.  However, what happened to the labels?  Bring back the orange and cream! 
Updated 1 November 2004.  On to the Fall 2004 release.  One thing about Bell¬ís is that their beers are not necessarily consistent year to year.  While I liked the 2003 Double Cream Stout, every bottle I sampled (from several sources) had a dominant licorice-like flavor that masked the roasted-sweet interplay, not what I remembered from 2002 and prior years, when this became my favorite beer.  The 2004 version is exactly as I first remember this beer.  Rich, soft roasted malts with hints of coffee and chocolate, much like the regular Kalamazoo Stout, but with a sweet, fruity (cherry) characteristic (lactose?) undeveloped in the former beer.  Rich, velvety, and amazing.  I can now once again state with confidence that this is my favorite beer.
Bells never fails. Be prepared for sweet molassas fragrance, chocolately persistant head and smooth yet robust flavor. Not too sweet, not overbearing. Good to the last drop.

Bottle.  Solid black with a laced dark brown head.  The chocolate and roasted malts jump out of the glass followed by a more subtle milk nose when its cold.  As the beer warms the dark fruits come alive.  Whether cold or warm, the dark fruit and tangy notes initially call for a pause on the palate before the chocolate and malts come.
Very dark brownish in color, with a medium sized chocolatey brown colored head. Aroma was creamy with just a bit of sweetness, with a similar flavor. A nice stout.

This beer poured a very dark, almost black color and formed huge medium tan bubby head much like a Guiness, leaving some nice lace. An aroma of malt, coffee and chocolate. A flavor of malt, coffee and dark chocolate. A slight burnt aspect to the finish. Another November Stout down, only 4 more to go(I think). Hopefully some of these will see longer rotation.
Very malty and a full, smooth mouthfull.  There is an assertive bitterness present supported by a host of black/toasted malts.  Very nicely done.  Not so sweet or creamy as the label lets on.

Deep inky black appearance.  Roasted grain aromas.  Small tan head.  Fruity and a little thin at first.  Light cherry notes, dark chocolate, olives?, medium bodied, but finishes long and slightly bitter, big malt.  Decent brew, although I feel this is over-rated.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2003 Sweet and creamy?  Had this on tap in IL.  My initial reaction on sipping this was drinking lemonade that has no sugar in it, very bitter in an unpleasant way.  No aroma at all, small head that dispersed quickly, taste was covered up by the bitterness.  Given the name of the beer this was the last thing I expected in this stout. 
Re-rate:  Bottle.  The tap must of been bad because the bottle version was quite tasty.  This time it was sweet and creamy along with the coffee and chocolate flavors.  Very nice.

A great beer.  Nice smooth malty flavor, with some coffe and a little chocolate.  There is very little carbonation, which I approve of in this beer.  The arroma is somewhat lacking but the flavor makes up for it.  Another great beer from Bell's.
Tart roasty aroma with no head. Medium body. Starts sweet with a roast finish. Bad bottle?
1/19/03:  bottle.  thin head with full bodied black color.  sweet malt smell with some toasted hints.  sour malt- (lactic acid sourness.)  similar to bell‚Äôs cherry stout.  like it a lot.

Black body with a thin, tan head.
Smelled malty with a hint of sourness.
Tasted milky and sweet. CH3CHOHCOOH acid is apparent in the flavor.
Low carbonation serves this beer well.
This is easily one of my favorite beers of the moment!
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2003 Poured like oil, smelled weak. Taste like Starbucks chocolate frappachino with alcohol. Goes great with t-bone steak.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 3, 2004 The nose of this is rather strange, somewhat reminds me of canned stew, but I dont know why.  No real bite, but a rich malt flavor throughout.  As soon as it was opened, the aroma of coffee was very present, but faded after a while.  Would go extremly well with a desert or a nice rich meal, but not something I would go for on it's own.
Gooey, ooey, rich and chewy.  If you like a full flavored, chocolatey stout you can¬ít go wrong here.  Just bowls you over with the endless flavor

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2009 Bottle... This beer rocks!... The nose is of milk chocolate, weak coffee and berries in cream. The color is black for the most part. Deep, dark copper when held up to a halogen bulb. Small, well-tanned head with a copper tint. Fully diminishing. The flavor is of cocoa powder and buttermilk up front. Even more intense tartness on the backside. Liquid joy. Liquid Fun. Full-bodied with lively carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Long, tangy, pungent finish with a small hint of prairie grass at the wee end. World class sweet stout.

As always, the Bells yeast is present. I usually drink the lighter stuff where the yeast kind of overpowers things. Not really the case here. Slippery mouthfeel, deep black color, not a lot of head (probably due to a soapy residue glass). Roasty malt flavor, maybe a little overbalanced in the hop direction. Moderate alcohol presence.

Black with a thin head and big bubbles.  Dark, oily alcohol nose.  Vanilla, with vinous acidity.  I found not much flavor and too much pucker.  Maybe my bottle was a little old, but it wasn¬ít that old.  Bell¬ís have many better stouts than this one.

ReRate: semi sweetened  chocolate and toasty nose.  Pitch black, big rocky brown head.  perfect presentation.  slightly vinous, very smooth and subtle.  very creamy as you would expect, an absolutely incredible body, a joy to drink.   This is going great with some intense Street Fighter 2.   Ryu may be a pacific islander but Blanka¬ís brazillian badness is untouched.

Rerate:  Slightly sour aftertaste this time knocks it down a notch.  In fact, this tastes like the Cherry Stout with 1/4 the cherries.


Excellent.  Very smooth all the way down and at 7.5% it is easy to get carried away with this beer because it goes down so well.  Recommended.
opaque..huge beige head.big coffee/chocolatey aroma..sweet. flavor is sweet, but there is some bitterness there to offset it. almost more of a sour feel than bitterness.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2008 It pours a deep, deep ruby, visible only with the strongest light &#40;we&#8217;ll just go with black&#41; and gives off a gorgeous toffee brown foam.  The aroma is espresso, red apple skin, chocolate and slight vanilla.  Flavor of dark, bitter chocolates, cocoa powder, coffee.  The mouthfeel of the beer is what imagine when i think the word "stout".  Exceptional beer and the second best offering &#40;that I&#8217;ve had" from this talented brewer.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2011 Chocolate milk, toasted bread, caramel and a handful of black grapes coalesce in this cohesive Sweet Stout...

Very sweet lactose smelling.  Soft roasted palate with even a touch of tartness.  Rolled oats and coffee ice cream flavors abound.  I would¬íve thought this was 4-5% alcohol.  Hearty and full of flavor, a dessert in and of itself.

Intense chocolate aroma. Hints of bitterness and malty sweetness present in the aroma as well. The flavor was huge in every respect...big chocolate...large smokiness...gigantic woodiness...yes, one huge flavor...very much like an imperial stout. Nice black color with a light brown colored head. Extremely smooth, creamy feel in the mouth and down the throat.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2003 2003 version: Black with a small brown head. Aroma of roast and chocolate. Creamy Chocolate and roasted flavors. Bitter dark chocolate finish. Definitly better than last years version.

Why is it that Bells stouts dont seem to have a very pronounced nose for me? Very creamy mouthfeel with a nice full roasted malt flavor. The usual coffee/dark chocolate notes but has an unusual slightly sour finish. Overall a great brew and very enjoyable.

Wow, one great stout after another. Today I went to the store and noticed all bells november stouts in singles! I snagged a variety sixpack of them....... As for the rate-- This was a very sweet stout. Not too creamy though..
Sweet but slightly rough malt flavor, thin body, decent finish.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2016 Previous review from draft:  Huge roasted aroma with lots of caramel, raisin, cocoa, coffee, and plum.  A hint of leather is in there as well.  Super slick, velvety, creamy, and soft palate.  Complex flavors of chewy caramel and a roasted chocolate middle.  Finished with a mild acidic snap and a medicinal blue cheese richness.  The bitter chocolate rounds this out nicely. (8, 4, 8, 4 = 4.0)  A revisit still finds the body  a wee thin, and halfway through the bottle the sugars become semi-fatiguing. Blessedly soft maltiness shows faint complementary grip of roast, yet predominant prune, licorice and lactic notes detract from the richer maltiness and keep this from becoming decadent and luxurious.  Still quite solid and enjoyable, but it¬ís just too sweet for me to wanna revisit more than once or twice a year. Curiously thin, too, which leaves the drinker somewhat dissatisfied, even after the sugary onslaught.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: I Also had the Draft Version here,creamy, made me think of a Quad Latte from Strabucks. Creamy. some coffee,caramel, acidic finish, & smooth,Perfect beer for a the  trip  to the mountains, get some it. a  true Winner !  Recommend

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2004 Pours black color with a nice creamy brown head that leaves good lacing in my glass, roasty malty aromas. Taste like bitter sweet chocolate and rich coffee, full bodied with a thick and creamy mouthfeel, finishes with a mild sweetness, alcohol is very well hidden, very drinkable and dangerous, this is a beautiful stout.
Reminds me a lot of Expedition, just toned down a wee bit. Strong vinous and plummy notes, rather sweet, some chocolate, and an appreciable amount of bitterness. Very full (creamy) mouthfeel.
Sweet and stinging.  Good thick coffee and chocolate tones.

More like an imperial stout than anything else.  Pitch black, with an umber head.  Very rich and roasty, with hints of chocolate, toffee, and even a nuance of cherry.  Wonderful after a rich meal.  Dessert beer to the max, dude.

Tasted at the Barrelhouse Brewing Company Microbrew Fest on November 9. This is an excellent Stout, which I understand is par for the course with Bell¬ís. I can¬ít wait to try the entire line! Pours black as night with a thin bone-white head and good lacing. Great smooth creamy flavor that I could enjoy all night.
Very good, exteremely dark, oily stout.  It¬ís still quite smooth besides all of the malt and hops kicking in.  Nice smoky flavor also... reminds me quite a bit of a thicker Dark Horse Bier.
black as an imperial, but has a lactic (duh, it¬ís a double cream stout) flavor. it¬ís sort of an inbetween stout, not sweet, not dry. it doesn¬ít quite do it for me.

A huge, light brown rocky head invited me in for a taste. . .how could I pass that up?  I dove in and roasted malts melted into a sweet thick chocolate, while raisins and cherries danced around me. . .don¬ít ever pass up an invitation from Bells.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2004  The bigger, badder version of Kalamazoo Stout. It has a Munich malt base with flaked grain to provide a bigger, richer, creamier feel, but lacks a bit in complexity, Sweet.  I had a very young version on tap and didn't get the smoky tones.

Well I¬ím usually a big fan of the ¬íZoo.  But I couldn¬ít really understand where they were trying to go with this ¬ísweet¬í stout.  It is smoky for sure, just like their porter, but somehow less enjoyable in this.  Sure there are other qualities to this like chocolate and coffee but the smoked taste is a bit too much for me.  I¬íll go for their Expedition or if I want a little more sweetness, Sam Smith¬ís Oatmeal is hard to beat.

I had this at the brewery, and maybe something was off because I at first I thought this might have been a smoked beer.  The beer was as dark as a beer gets.  Started out with good notes of chocolate, roasted malt, alcohol, coffee, and sugar.  After the beer warmed I noticed distinct smoked flavors, like bacon.  It didn¬ít detract from the beer, but was surprising.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2003 Re-rate:  I had to bump this up a just a bit.  It is a damn good beer.  Dark brown/black body that is creamy and sweet.  Chocolate, toast and roasted coffee.  Good stuff.  3.5 This one was pretty nice.  Loads of chocolate compliment a slightly roasted quality.   Also a bit of chocolate.  Quite enjoyable.
Pour is frothy, color is very dark.  Not a bad stout, not very sweet.  Chocolately.  I guess I should have had this with dessert.
Good cream flavor; reminds of cream soda... the coffee flavor quite stong... roasted malts.
An awesome brew.  Dark creamy and great great flavor.  Oh the flavor.  Very well hopped beer.  Blends very nicely with the roasty-malty medium body of this liquid.  Very nice indeed.
Looks good. Smells good. Tastes BAAAD. It tased like someone dumped four shots of vodka into the beer.  Way too much alcohol taste.
Quite sweet and very complex stout. Not quite as good as the Expidetion Stout but better than most of Bell¬ís other stouts.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2005 Bell¬ís double cream stout is the perfect dessert beer.  This is the one beer that you would be most tempted to create an ice cream float with.  The chocolate and roasted barley blend perfectly to produce a well balanced malt flavor - excellent hop balance.  The head tend to be a lot darker than many stouts.  A friend of mine who is a confirmed Budweiser drinker, makes this his only exception.  This might rerate at a perfect 5 someday in the future.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2004 2001 Bottle. Pours smooth and deep, with a nice creamy off-white head.  The taste is pure heaven.  Even and rich, without any carbonation to drag it down.
